Also up is MasterCard MA, -1.97%  and it is set to record a profit of 4.22 a share on revenue of $1.55 billion, if Wall Street’s best guess is on the mark. Other firms expected to post quarterly results include Owens Corning OC, -1.36%  , Sotheby’s BID, -3.00%  , Zipcar ZIP, -8.70%  and R.R. Donnelley RRD, -5.84%  . After the close Tuesday, CBS Corp. CBS, -1.46%  said that its second-quarter profit rose sharply, boosted by increases in licensing and advertising revenue. The company said it earned $395 million, or 58 cents a share, up from $150 million, or 22 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose 8% to $3.59 billion. Both the top and bottom lines exceeded analyst expectations. Also after the close, Navistar International Corp. NAV, -3.69%  said it will shutter a manufacturing plant in Chatham, Ontario, after being unable to make a deal with the Canadian Auto Workers union. Navistar added it also cut back at a plant in Oregon, affecting 450 workers, and close an Indiana chassis facility that employs 225. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers
title: Stocks to watch Wednesday: Clorox, CBS, MasterCard

content: Owens Corning OC, -1.23% first-quarter earnings declined by half, falling short of analysts' estimates, as the company's building-materials segment saw sales and earnings drop. "Owens Corning delivered profit in line with our expectations for the first quarter driven by continued strong performance in the composites and roofing businesses," said Chairman and Chief Executive Mike Thaman. The maker of building materials had suffered from slumping demand during the economic downturn as construction tumbled, though last spring, many construction-materials makers saw a boost from a first-time homebuyer tax credit that spurred the housing market. The company's composites business--less tied to the U.S. housing market--has been its revenue engine of late. Owens Corning reported a profit of $24 million, or 19 cents a share, down from $48 million, or 38 cents, a year earlier. The company's earnings when adjusted for its expected full-year effective tax rate fell to 20 cents a share from 42 cents. Revenue fell 2.1% to $1.24 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had most recently forecast earnings of 36 cents a share on revenue of $1.26 billion. Gross margin fell to 16.3% from 18.7%. Sales in the building-materials segment, the largest top-line contributor, dropped 7.2% as pretax profit declined 66%. The composites segment's sales rose 6.3% as profit increased 55%. Shares closed Tuesday at $37.05 and were inactive premarket. The stock has risen 24% over the past year. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots
title: Owens Corning profit halved by building weakness

content: SUGAR LAND, Texas (MarketWatch) — Backed by the potential for margins to widen and deal activity to provide abnormal returns, the leadership of chemical stocks seems sustainable. INVESTING COMMENTARY IN TRADING DECK Back to 1987 for stocks? Our Trading Deck has been home to a spirited debate over whether we're in for a crash. • L.A. Little: Don't worry | Michael Gayed: Worry • The warning signs of a 1987-style crash • Hulbert: Stocks as overvalued as at 2007 high Selected groups in the consumer discretionary and technology sectors like auto and computers led the way in 2009 as stock prices started to recover from the Great Recession. In 2010, the leadership shifted to groups like transportation. In recent months, stock prices in groups like auto, computers, and transportation have sputtered. The chemicals group is different in this regard. Shares here performed well in both 2009 and 2010 and they continue to fare well in 2011. Over the past year, the Dow Jones Chemicals Titans 30 Index DJACHE  is up 34% while the actively managed Fidelity Select Chemicals Fund FSCHX, +2.19%  is up 36% compared to the 12% advance of the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index SPX, -2.12% as of Wednesday. Looking For Gold Pullback? Wait For Summer With industry margins likely to widen and deal activity adding spice, chemical company stocks have a few things going for them that can help them sustain their leadership. Industry profits poised to rise Chemical companies cut costs to the bone during the downturn. With the economy now growing, product demand in individual industry segments is increasing. The resulting operating leverage is helping chemical companies widen their margins. Agricultural chemicals: The secular forces of global population growth and higher per-capita income in emerging economies are lifting commodity crop prices. The United Nations reports that global food costs are at record levels. High crop prices provide significant incentive for farmers to increase acreage and yields. The U.S. Department of Agriculture recently stated that U.S. corn acreage this year would be second highest in 67 years. Fertilizer producers like Potash Corporation POT, -2.17%  and Agrium AGU  as well as seed developers like Monsanto MON, -0.17%  and DuPont DD, +0.94%  stand to benefit from the drive to increase farm output. Petrochemicals and plastics: Demand for petrochemicals and plastics is rising from growth in emerging markets and recovery of the auto industry. About the author: Sam Subramanian founded independent investment research firm AlphaProfit Investments in 2003. AlphaProfit publishes the monthly AlphaProfit Sector Investors' Newsletter and AlphaProfit Fund Investors' Guide.  alphaprofit.com Global capacity utilization for ethylene production, a bellwether for plastics manufacture, is forecasted to increase to 90% by 2013 from 84% in 2009. The automotive industry accounts for 10% of U.S. chemical industry demand. Plastics manufacture should receive a boost as global auto demand approaches 76 million units. Dow Chemical DOW, -0.77% BASF Corp. BASFY, -1.81%  and LyondellBasell Industries LYB, -1.81%  are among the world’s top petrochemicals and plastics producers. Ample supply of shale natural gas particularly in the U.S. should help their margins. Specialty chemicals and building materials: Specialty chemical stocks typically tend to perform well in early to mid-cycle phases of economic recoveries as demand increases to drive volume growth. Solutia SOA, -1.06% which makes various chemical and engineered materials used in consumer and industrial applications, is well-positioned to benefit from increasing global construction activity. Building products manufacturer U.S. Gypsum USG, -1.88% roofing products manufacturer Owens Corning OC, -1.23% and paint manufacturers Sherwin Williams SHW, -1.61%  and Valspar VAL, +0.00% too can fare well in varying degrees. Deal activity adds to investment appeal Deal activity in the chemical industry is continuing at a healthy pace as valuation metrics are attractive and companies seek to grow revenue. Legendary investor Warren Buffett is seeing value in chemical companies. Berkshire Hathaway BRK.B, -2.51%  recently announced that it is acquiring Lubrizol LZ  for $9 billion. Earlier, DuPont offered to buy Denmark’s Danisco for $6 billion to expand into biofuels and food enzymes. Air Products & Chemicals APD, -1.08%  went after Airgas ARG, +0.00%  in hot pursuit until the latter succeeded in staying independent by getting court approval of its poison pill provision. Investing in the chemicals group There are several options available for investors to play the chemicals group. Among mutual funds, several index and actively managed funds invest in the materials sector. However, when it comes to the chemicals group in particular, Fidelity Select Chemicals is the only pure-play mutual fund that focuses on this group. In the exchange-traded funds space, there are no pure-pay chemical ETFs. However, several basic materials and agriculture ETFs can work as suitable proxies since many of them have 40% or more of their assets invested in chemical stocks. Market Vectors Agribusiness MOO, -2.05% Materials Select Sector SPDR XLB, -1.95% iShares DJ US Basic Materials IYM, -1.80% Vanguard Materials VAW, -1.94% and PowerShares Global Agriculture PAGG, -0.75%  fit this description and have net assets of over $100 million each. Sam Subramanian edits AlphaProfit’s Premium Investment Newsletter and makes recommendations on mutual funds, exchange-traded funds, and stocks. Subramanian owns shares in Fidelity Select Chemicals. (alphaprofit.com) More from MarketWatch Don’t ever do this with your credit card Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers
title: Investing in chemicals

content: Logitech second-quarter net profit nearly doubles (11:23 PM ET) TOKYO (MarketWatch) -- Logitech International SA LOGI, -1.50% (CH:LOGN)on Thursday reported that second-quarter net profit nearly doubled from a year earlier on strength in retail sales and raised its forecasts for sales and operating income for the fiscal year ending in March 2011. The computer-device maker said net income reached $41 million, or 23 cents per share in the second quarter, compared with $21 million, or 11 cents per share the same time a year ago. Sales were at $582 million, up 17% from a year ago. Looking ahead, Logitech expects sales of $2.35 billion to $2.4 billion, up from a previous estimate of up to $2.35 billion. It expects operating income of $170 million to $180 million, up from a forecast of up to $170 million. Teradyne sees sharp third-quarter profit increase (7:37 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Teradyne Inc. TER, -3.39% said Wednesday its third-quarter net income rose to $147.3 million, or 66 cents a share, from $6.7 million, or 4 cents a share in the same period last year. The semiconductor test-equipment maker said revenue for the period ended Oct. 3 rose to $502.1 million from $262.2 million. Excluding one-time items, Teradyne said earnings were 82 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected Teradyne to report earnings of 79 cents a share, and $508 million in revenue. For its current, fourth quarter, Teradyne said it expects earnings excluding items to be between 21 and 28 cents a share, and revenue to be between $300 million and $325 million. Owens-Illinois profit up 9%; shipments slip (5:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Owens-Illinois OI, -2.72% the world's largest glass container manufacturer for food and beverage companies, said late Wednesday third-quarter net income rose 9% to $139 million, or 84 cents a share, from $127 million, or 74 cents a share. Sales fell 7% to $1.74 billion, mostly due to foreign currency moves, the company said. Global shipments edged lower by 2% due to volume losses from restructured contracts. Owens-Illinois faces the potential loss of two plants its Venezuela, where President Hugo Chavez's government plans to take over the plants that make up 5% of the company's global-segment operating profit. The company said this could dent earnings in the fourth quarter. Owens-Illinois fell 15 cents to $27.90 in after-hours trade. Sourcefire quarterly profit jumps; outlook weak (5:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sourcefire Inc. FIRE, -4.55% late Wednesday reported its third-quarter net income jumped to $4.2 million, or 15 cents a share, from $2.7 million, or 9 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. On an adjusted basis, the cybersecurity software company would have earned 18 cents a share. Revenue increased 32% to $36.2 million. Sourcefire expects profit in a range of 14 cents to 16 cents a share and 16 cents to 18 cents a share on an adjusted basis while revenue is projected to come in at $37 million to $38.5 million in the fourth quarter. The outlook is below FactSet estimate of 21 cents a share earnings and $43.8 million in revenue. Shares of Sourcefire slumped 21% in after-hours activity. Apple says future gross margins may be lower (5:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Apple Inc. said in a regulatory filing Wednesday afternoon that gross margins in future periods may be lower as it focuses more on a higher mix of products "that have higher cost structures and deliver greater value to customers." In its 10-K filing, Apple AAPL, -1.10% reiterated its forecast from its Oct. 18 earnings call that gross margins will be around 36% for the Deecember quarter. The company ended its 2010 fiscal year on Sept. 30 with a gross margin of 39.4% - down slightly from 40.1% in the previous fiscal year. FMC Technologies third-quarter profit drops 11.7% (4:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- FMC Technologies FTI, -2.31% said late Wednesday its third-quarter profit fell to $81.4 million, or 67 cents a share, from $92.2 million, or 73 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. The company, a maker of oil and gas field production systems, cited lower subsea systems revenue, which weighed on the company's quarterly performance. Revenue for the Houston, Texas-based company fell 12% to $960 million. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected the company to earn 67 cents a share on revenue of $1.01 billion. The company raised its full-year 2010 guidance to a range of $2.90 to $2.95 a share, from its previous guidance of $2.70 to $2.90 a share. Cincinnati Financial quarterly profit falls (4:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cincinnati Financial Corp. CINF, -2.74% said late Wednesday that third-quarter net income came in at $156 million, or 95 cents a share, compered with net income of $171 million, or $1.05 a share, in the third quarter of 2009. Operating profit, which excludes net realized investment gains and losses, was $56 million, or 34 cents a share, in the latest period, the insurer reported. Cincinnati Financial was expected to make 35 cents a share, according to an analyst survey by FactSet Research. Ace quarterly net income rises 37% (4:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Ace Ltd. ACE, +2.34% said late Wednesday that third-quarter net income came in at $675 million, or $1.97 a share, up 37% from a year earlier when the insurer made $494 million, or $1.46 a share. Excluding net realized investment gains and losses, Ace said it made $688 million, or $2.01 a share, in the latest quarter. The company was expected to make $1.81 a share, according to an analyst survey by FactSet Research. Ace raised its full-year 2010 operating earnings guidance to $7.20 to $7.40 a share from $6.25 to $6.75 a share. Norfolk Southern posts 47% jump in profit (4:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Railroad operator Norfolk Southern Corp. NSC, -2.14% reported late Wednesday third-quarter net income rose to $445 million, or $1.19 a share, from $303 million, or 81 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter ended Sept. 30 rose 19% to $2.5 billion from $2.06 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had predicted the Norfolk, Va.-based transport company would earn $1.09 cents a share on $2.47 billion in revenue. "We continue to see an economy characterized by slow growth, but growth nonetheless," CEO Wick Moorman said in a statement. Norfolk Southern shares fell 35 cents, or 0.6%, to $61 in after-hours trade. The stock is up 33% over the past 12 months. Visa quarterly net income jumps 51% (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Visa Inc. V, -1.49% said late Wednesday that fiscal fourth-quarter net income came in at $774 million, or $1.06 per class A share. That was up 51% from a year earlier. On an adjusted basis, which excludes the revaluation of the company's Visa Europe put option, net income for the quarter was $695 million, or 95 cents per class A share, Visa said. The company was expected to make 95 cents a share, according to the average estimate of analysts in a FactSet Research survey. Net operating revenue in the fiscal fourth quarter was $2.1 billion, an increase of 13% over the prior year. That was driven by higher revenue from data processing and international transactions, the company explained. Visa shares fell 1.1% to $79.04 in after-hours trading Wednesday. Torchmark Corp.'s third-quarter profit jumps 15.6% (4:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Torchmark Corp. TMK, -2.23% said late Wednesday its third-quarter profit rose to $1.41 a share from $1.22 a share in the same quarter last year. Net operating income for the McKinney, Texas-based company rose $1.63 a share from $1.48 a share in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected the company to earn $1.57 a share on revenue of $846.3 million. The insurance and financial services holding company only provided per-share net income and net operating income figures. Allstate quarterly results miss analyst estimates (4:17 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Allstate Corp. ALL, -1.12% said late Wednesday that third-quarter net income came in at $367 million, or 68 cents a share, up 66% from a year earlier when the auto and homeowners insurer made $221 million, or 41 cents a share. Operating profit, which excludes net realized investment gains and losses, was $452 million, or 83 cents a share. That was down 16% from a year earlier. Allstate was expected to make 95 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 19 analysts in a FactSet Research survey. Net premiums written by Allstate's main Property-Liability business fell 0.6% in the third quarter of 2010 compared to the prior-year quarter. Allstate brand growth of 0.2% was more than offset by a 16.7% decline in the Encompass brand, reflecting actions to improve profitability, Allstate said. Allstate shares fell 3.1% to $31.48 in after-hours trading Wednesday. Las Vegas Sands swings to third-quarter profit (4:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Las Vegas Sands Corp. LVS, -1.89% late Wednesday reported it swung to third-quarter profit of $168 million, or 21 cents a share, from a loss of $123 million, or 19 cents a share, in the same period last year. On an adjusted basis, the gambling company earned 34 cents a share. Revenue jumped 67% to $1.91 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast earnings of 23 cents a share on revenue of $1.79 billion. Symantec profit falls, but tops Street views (4:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Symantec Corp. SYMC, -2.63% said Wednesday that its fiscal second-quarter net income fell to $136 million, or 17 cents a share, compared to $155 million, or 19 cents a share in the same period last year. The security software maker said revenue for the period ended Oct. 1 rose marginally to $1.48 billion from $1.47 billion. Excluding one-time items, Symantec said earnings were 34 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected Symantec to report earnings excluding items of 28 cents a share, and $1.46 billion in revenue. Akamai earnings climb 21% in third quarter (4:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Akamai Technologies Inc. said Wednesday that earnings jumped 21% in the third quarter thanks to growing demand for its Web content management tools. For the period ended Sept. 30, Akamai AKAM, -2.03% reported net income of $39.7 million, or 21 cents a share, compared to net income of $32.7 million, or 18 cents a share, for the same period the previous year. The company said earnings on a normalized basis would have been $64.2 million, or 34 cents a share. Revenue grew 23% to $253.6 million. Analysts were expecting earnings of 34 cents a share on revenue of $249.2 million, according to consensus estimates from FactSet Research. Teck Resources shares fall on weak coal sales (3:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Teck Resources Ltd.'s(CA:TCK.B)shares fell 1.9% Wednesday in Toronto trading, after the mining company late Tuesday said its third-quarter coal sales fell below previous guidance after being negatively affected by capacity constraints. The company reported a quarterly profit of $467 million, or 79 cents a share, up from $337 million, or 59 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. "Despite strong demand from our steelmaking customers, (coal) sales volumes decreased," the company said in a statement. Teck also cited a strike at its Coal Mountain mine, lasting from Aug. 6 through Sept. 29, which reduced its quarterly coal production volumes by approximately 300,000 tonnes. Life Tech shares rise on earnings beat, outlook (1:59 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Life Technologies Corp. LIFE, +1.92% shares rose more than 5% Wednesday after the biotech tools maker beat Wall Street estimates for its third-quarter results and full-year outlook. Late Tuesday, Life Technologies reported quarterly net income of $105.5 million, or 56 cents a share, on revenue of $867.1 million. On an adjusted basis, the company reported earnings of 87 cents a share on revenue of $868.7 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had estimated a quarterly profit of 78 cents a share on revenue of $855.2 million. The company also forecast full-year adjusted earnings of $3.48 to $3.52 a share, compared with a Street consensus of $3.42 a share on Tuesday. LoJack rises high on overseas sales (11:29 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- LoJack Corp. LOJN shares jumped more than 25% Wednesday after the developer of stolen car recovery technology reported a surge in overseas sales. Net income attributable to LoJack was $2.7 million or 15 cents a share, compared to a net loss of $13.4 million, or 78 cents a share, for the same quarter of the prior year. Consolidated revenue for the third quarter rose 7% to $38.5 million. Revenue in the company's North America segment fell 7% to $24.4 million. International sales jumped 47% to $13.4 million, driven by unit volume growth of 61% from LoJack's licensee business and continued expansion of the subscriber base in Italy. LoJack shares jumped 26% to $5.16 in morning action on Wednesday. Century Aluminum shares down 6% on weak earnings (11:12 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Century Aluminum Co. CENX, -0.67% shares fell 6% Wednesday after the company late Tuesday said it swung to a third-quarter net loss of $16.8 million, or 18 cents a share, from a profit of $40.1 million, or 45 cents a share, in same quarter last year. The Monterey, Calif.-based company said it was negatively impacted by high power costs and mark-to-market losses on forward contracts. "Global aluminum inventories remain high and economic activity in, and the state of finances of, developed regions remain a concern," said CEO Logan Kruger. "We thus continue to manage the company with a bias toward protecting the downside." ViroPharma gains on earnings report (10:58 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- ViroPharma Inc. VPHM gained in early action Wednesday after it issued a comparatively rosy earnings report. ViroPharma said that its third-quarter profit grew to $38 million, up from $20 million in the 2009 period. Revenue rose to $118 million versus $81 million. ViroPharma shares were up 6% at $16.35. DeVry shares rise following quarterly earnings (10:53 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- DeVry Inc. DV, +0.00% shares rose Wednesday after the for-profit education company beat Wall Street estimates in reporting fiscal first-quarter earnings late Tuesday. DeVry shares rose 7.3% to $45.86 in recent activity. DeVry posted quarterly net income of $73.6 million, or $1.03 a share, on revenue of $521.4 million, compared with an analyst consensus of 96 cents a share on $520.4 million. Illumina boosted by earnings report (10:51 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- A positive third-quarter earnings report boosted Illumina Inc. ILMN, -2.77% shares early Wednesday. Shares of Illumina were up 7% at $55.42. Late Tuesday, Illumina posted net income of $35 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with $17 million, or 12 cents a share, for the same period in 2009. Revenue shot up 50% to $237 million. The research tools maker said that it ended the quarter with $807 million in cash and marketable securities versus $694 million in the previous year's quarter. Whirlpool shares slide as sales growth slows (10:43 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Whirlpool shares WHR, -2.39% fell 5% to $80.02 early Wednesday after the household appliance maker cut its North America shipment forecast and warned sales growth has slowed from earlier this year. Whirlpool, whose brands include Maytag and KitchenAid, said North America shipment growth will now be 3%, down from its previous target of 5% growth. North America is Whirlpool's largest sales region. It accounted for $2.4 billion in sales for the quarter ended Sept. 30. The Michigan-based maker of washing machines left unchanged its 2010 earnings forecast. Whirlpool, which had cut its annual profit target Sept. 30, expects to earn between $7.80 to $8.30 a share. Analysts are looking for $8.86 a share. Compellent shares jump 27% on results, upgrade (9:41 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Compellent Technologies Inc. CML, +8.33% saw its shares surge more than 27% to $25.12 Wednesday morning - setting a new record high - after the maker of data-storage technology reported a 47% jump in earnings for the third quarter and issued a forecast for the current period that beat Wall Street's estimates. Piper Jaffray upgraded the stock to an overweight rating following the results, predicting that the company "can continue to grow at above-market rates while increasing the flow through to the bottom line." The stock has more than doubled in the last three months, in part thanks to growing buyout interest in the data storage sector. Molex shares shed 8% following forecast (9:32 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Molex Inc. MOLX shares fell $1.85, or 8%, to $20.72 in early trading Wednesday following a disappointing quarterly forecast from the electronics connector maker. Late Tuesday, Molex said that for its fiscal second quarter it expects to earn between 38 cents and 44 cents a share, while analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters had forecast the company to earn 45 cents a share. The forecast took attention away from Molex's first-quarter results, in which the company earned $75.1 million, or 43 cents a share, on $898 million in sales and turned around from a loss in the same period a year ago. Allegheny Energy profit climbs 49% (8:49 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Allegheny Energy AYE said its third-quarter profit climbed to $115.1 million, or 68 cents a share, from $77 million, or 45 cents a share, with revenue climbing to $1.04 billion from $793.7 million. The Greensburg, Pa. electric utility said it would have earned 73 cents a share excluding items including pretax expense related to its proposed merger with FirstEnergy. Analysts polled by FactSet expected earnings of 56 cents a share. Increased customer usage, transmission expansion and a rate increase in West Virginia helped boost profit and revenue, the firm said. Comcast profit falls 8.2% (8:47 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Comcast Corp. CMCSA, -1.68% the largest U.S. cable-television operator, said Wednesday that its third-quarter profit declined 8.2% on greater costs, including expenses related to its proposed acquisition of a controlling stake in NBC Universal. Comcast said it earned $867 million, or 31 cents a share, compared with a profit of $944 million, or 33 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Excluding items, the company said it would have earned $906 million, or 32 cents a share, in the latest three months. Revenue rose 7.3% to $9.49 billion. According to a survey taken by FactSet Research, analysts were expecting a profit of 31 cents a share on revenue of $9.53 billion. ConocoPhillips profit doubles, production dips (8:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ConocoPhillips COP, -3.51% said Wednesday its third-quarter profit doubled to $3.1 billion, or $2.05 a share, from $1.5 billion, or 97 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings rose to $1.50 a share, from 95 cents a share. Wall Street analysts expected the Houston oil fim to earn $1.45 a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. ConocoPhillips said its production fell to 1.72 million barrels of oil equivalent a day, from 1.79 million barrels, in the face of normal field decline and asset sales. Increased production from China, Australia, U.S. shale and the Canadian steam assisted gravity drainage projects partially offset the decrease. Constellation, EDF scrap nuke plant alliance (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Constellation Energy Group Inc. CEGR3, -0.03% and French power giant EDF(FR:EDF)said late Tuesday they would end their joint Unistar alliance. EDF will buy Constellation's 50% ownership in Unistar for $140 million. EDF will transfer to Constellation 3.5 million of the shares that it owns in Constellation and will give up its seat on the Constellation board. EDF gets the Calvert Cliffs 3 nuclear plant project and a potential fourth reactor at Calvert Cliffs. Constellation will also transfer to UniStar potential new nuclear sites at Nine Mile Point and R. E. Ginna in New York State. Constellation will provide some contractual services to UniStar. Northrop Grumman posts a higher quarterly profit (8:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Northrop Grumman Corp. NOC, -1.44% said Wednesday its third-quarter earnings rose to $497 million, or $1.67 a share, from $490 million, or $1.45 a share, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, the Los Angeles military contractor said it earned $1.64 a share. Sales rose to $8.71 billion from $8.35 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of $1.45, on average, with sales of $8.6 billion. Northrop Grumman raised its full-year guidance to a range of $6.85 to $7 a share, from $6.60 to $6.80 a share. Shares of Northrop Grumman closed Tuesday at $61.35, up less than 1%. General Dynamics quarterly profit rises 14% (8:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- General Dynamics Corp. GD, -1.40% said Wednesday its third-quarter earnings jumped to $650 million, or $1.70 a share, from $572 million, or $1.47 a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of $1.64 a share, on average. Revenue rose 3.8% to $8 billion, on the back of demand for its aerospace and defense products. Funded backlog at the end of the quarter was $45.6 billion, versus $46.8 billion a year ago, and total backlog was $61.8 billion, down from $66.25 billion. Shares of General Dynamics closed Tuesday at $64.09, up 3 cents. Sealed Air profit increases by 26% (7:57 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sealed Air Corp. SEE, -2.45% said Wednesday its third-quarter net income rose 26% to $76.5 million, or 43 cents a share, from $60.6 million, or 34 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings for the Elmwood Park, N.J. packaging maker totaled 43 cents a share. Revenue rose 5% to $1.13 billion. Wall Street analysts expected the company to earn 43 cents a share, on revenue of $1.13 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Sealed Air said it expects 2010 adjusted earnings of $1.56 a share to $1.62 a share, compared to its earlier forecast of $1.50 a share to $1.70 a share. Analysts are forecasting earnings of $1.60 a share. PSEG's quarterly net rises 16% (7:51 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Public Service Enterprise Group Inc. PEG, -0.74% Wednesday reported third-quarter net income of $567 million, or $1.12 a share, versus $488 million, or 96 cents a share, in the third quarter of 2009. "Our financial results in the third quarter were strong," said Ralph Izzo, PSEG chief executive, in the earnings release. "Warmer than normal weather and higher electric delivery rates in effect at the start of the summer helped to offset the impact of a slow economic recovery and lower realized energy prices," Izzo said, adding that the company is on track to deliver full-year earnings in the range of $3 to $3.25 a share. Southern Co. net income rises by 3% (7:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Southern Co. SO, -0.83% said Wednesday its third-quarter earnings rose to $817.2 million, or 98 cents a share, from $790 million, or 99 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $5.3 billion from $4.68 billion. "Warmer-than-normal weather for the period and a stronger-than-expected recovery in the industrial sector positively influenced third quarter earnings, as evidenced by increases in electricity usage and sales," the Atlanta-based power giant said. Increased operations and maintenance expenses, reflecting a return to more normal spending levels, bit into profit, the company said. Wall Street analysts expected Southern Co. to earn 97 cents a share on revenue of $5.36 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Hess Corp. proift jump, oil production falls (7:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Hess Corp. HES, -4.19% said Wednesday its third-quarter net income rose to $1.15 billion, or $3.52 a share, from $341 million, or $1.05 a share, in the year-ago period. The latest quarter includes an after-tax gain of $1.07 billion relating to an asset exchange and an after-tax charge of $347 million for an asset impairment. Oil and gas production fell to 413,000 barrels per day, from 420,000. The company's average selling price for oil, including the effect of hedging, was $64.81 per barrel, compared with $56.07 per barrel in the third quarter of last year. Total revenue rose to $8.95 billion from $7.38 billion. Wall Street analysts expected Hess to earn $1.04 a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Owens Corning's quarterly profit falls 28% (7:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -1.39% said Wednesday its third-quarter profit fell to $58 million, or 46 cents a share, from $80 million, or 63 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, the Toledo, Ohio, building materials company said it earned 35 cents a share. Sales slipped to $1.19 billion from $1.35 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 37 cents a share, on average, with sales of $1.25 billion. For the full year, Owens Corning forecast earnings before interest and taxes, or EBIT, to be in the range of $360 million to $390 million. Wall Street was looking for EBIT of $403.1 million. Shares of Owens Corning closed Tuesday at $28.20, off 2%. Sprint Nextel loss widens; subscribers up (7:27 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Sprint Nextel Corp., S, -0.61% the Overland Park, Kansas, telecoms major, reported a wider third-quarter loss on 1.4% higher revenue. The losses were $911 million, or 30 cents a share, against $478 million, or 17 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue reached $8.15 billion from $8.04 billion. In the quarter, Sprint Nextel said in a Wednesday statement, it added a net 644,000 subscribers, more than half of them post-paid customers. That's the best subscriber figure since 2006, Sprint Nextel said. And net subscriber results should improve in the fourth quarter from the third period, the company said. Demand for smartphones remained strong, the company said, mentioning particularly the Samsung Epic 4G and the HTC Evo 4G models. Legg Mason's quarterly net rises (7:27 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Legg Mason Inc. LM, -2.53% before Wednesday's opening bell reported fiscal second-quarter net income of $75.3 million, or 50 cents a share, compared with $47.9 million, or 30 cents a share, in the same quarter of 2009. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Legg Mason said assets under management rose 4% from June 30 to $673.5 billion as market gains of $40.8 million more than offset net outflows of $12.7 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had forecast profit of 34 cents a share, on average. NRG pledges $300 million for solar thermal project (7:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- NRG Energy NRG, -0.88% on Wednesday said it would invest up to $300 million in the 392-megawatt Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System in California's Mojave Desert being built by BrightSource Energy. The system, which is billed as the largest solar thermal project in the world, is expected to go into operation in 2013. Office Depot swings to quarterly profit (7:19 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Office Depot Inc. ODP, -2.56% Wednesday said it swung to a third-quarter profit of $62.9 million, or 18 cents a share, from a loss of $399 million, or $1.51 a share, in the year-ago quarter. The company said total sales slipped 4% to $2.9 billion. Procter & Gamble proift dips, sales up 2% (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Procter & Gamble Co. PG, -1.92% said Wednesday its first-quarter earnings fell 7% to $3.08 billion, or $1.02 a share, from $3.3 billion, or $1.06 a share, in the year-ago period. Breaking out a one-time boost of 9 cents a share for discontinued operations in the year-ago period, earnings rose to $1.02 a share from 97 cents a share. Sales rose 2% to $20.1 billion. Wall Street analysts expected the consumer products giant to earn $1 a share on revenue of $20.27 billion, according to a survey of analysts by FactSet Research. For its second quarter, Procter & Gamble expects earnings of $1.05 a share to $1.11 a share, with net sales growth of 3% to 5%. Wall Street analysts expect earnings of $1.11 a share. The company said it's facing higher commodity costs and marketing spending in the coming quarter. International Paper's quarterly profit rises 7% (7:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- International Paper Co. IP, -4.23% said Wednesday its third-quarter earnings rose to $397 million, or 91 cents a share, from $371 million, or 87 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales for the paper and packaging company rose to $6.72 billion from $5.92 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 79 cents a share, on average, with sales of $6.55 billion. Shares of International Paper closed Tuesday at $23.87, down a fraction. Praxair net income up 16%; lifts 2010 guidance (6:39 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Industrial gases company Praxair Inc. PX, -1.16% on Wednesday reported third-quarter net income rose 16% to $377 million, or $1.21 a share, against $325 million, or $1.04 a share, in the year-ago period. The company said sales rose to $2.54 billion against $2.29 billion, due to strong volume growth in all geographic regions. A survey of analysts polled by FactSet Research was forecasting net income of $1.20 a share on sales of $2.56 billion. The company said overall sales growth was comparable to that of the second quarter as growth in Asia and South America offset seasonally lower sales in Europe. For the fourth quarter, Praxair sees diluted EPS in the range of $1.18 to $1.23, against a FactSet forecast of $1.22. For 2010, Praxair sees sales of around $10 billion, and lifted guidance for adjusted, diluted EPS to a range of $4.67 to $4.72. Thermo Fisher lifts outlook as Q3 profit rises (6:32 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc TMO, -1.75% on Wednesday posted a 21% increase in third-quarter net profit to $268.5 million, or 66 cents a share, from $221.2 million, or 53 cents a share, earned in the year-earlier period. Excluding exceptional items, adjusted earnings came in at 90 cents a share compared to 78 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. Analysts, on average, expected the company to earn 83 cents a share, according to FactSet Research. Revenue rose 6% to $2.68 billion. The lab-equipment company raised its 2010 adjusted earnings outlook to the range of $3.47 to $3.53 a share compared to an earlier forecast of $3.40 to $3.50 a share. Thermo Fisher also lifted its revenue outlook to a new range of $10.72 billion to $10.80 billion from an earlier forecast of $10.60 billion to $10.75 billion. Whirlpool net off 9.2% on 0.5% higher sales (6:29 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Whirlpool Corp., WHR, -2.39% the Benton Harbor, Mich., appliance major, reported third-quarter net income fell 9.2% on 0.5% higher sales. Earnings fell to $79 million, or $1.02 a share, from $87 million, or $1.15, in the year-earlier quarter. Adjusted earnings were $2.22 a share versus $1.67. Sales edged up to $4.52 billion from $4.5 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of $1.71 of profit on $4.5 billion of revenue. For all of 2010, Whirlpool estimated that it would earn $7.80 to $8.30 a share, or an adjusted $9.56 to $10.06. FactSet's survey is looking for $8.82 a share. Stora Enso swings to profit; sales up 18% (2:43 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Stora Enso, SEOAY, -5.15% (FI:STERV)the Helsinki paper-, packaging- and wood-products major, swung to a third-quarter profit from a year-earlier loss on 18% higher sales. Profit was 194.3 million euros, or 0.25 euro a share, compared with a loss of 519.7 million euros, or 0.66, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were 0.23 euro a share against 0.12. Sales were 2.62 billion euros versus 2.23 billion a year earlier. A survey of analysts by Dow Jones Newswires produced consensus estimates of 135.7 million euros of profit on 2.6 billion euros of revenue. The "market outlook remains generally favorable," but cost pressures, weakness in some product areas, and outages for maintenance will cause fourth-quarter earnings to come in below the third-quarter level, Chief Executive Jouko Karvinen said in a statement. Stora Enso also said it would acquire 51% of Inpac International, a Chinese producer of packaging for consumer products, particularly mobile phones. Inpac's enterprise value is 82 million euros, Stora Enso said. Deutsche Bank swings to third-quarter loss (2:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Deutsche Bank AG(DE:DBK) DB, -2.18% said Wednesday it swung to a third-quarter net loss of 1.21 billion euros ($1.7 billion) compared to a profit of 1.38 billion euros in the same period a year ago. Excluding a 2.3 billion euros charge related to its investment in Deutsche Postbank(DE:DPB), Deutsche Bank's net profit for the third quarter was 1.1 billion euros. Deutsche Bank said on Sept. 21 that it expects to report a net loss for the third quarter of this year because of the charge related to Postbank. Third-quarter sales and trading revenues were 2.9 billion euros compared to 3.0 billion euros in the same period a year ago. BBVA attributable income slips to EUR1.14 billion (2:14 AM ET) MADRID (MarketWatch) -- Spanish banking giant BBVA(ES:BBVA) BBVA, -1.96% on Wednesday said third-quarter attributable net income fell to 1.14 billion euros ($1.57 billion) against €1.38 billion in the prior-year period. On a per share basis, BBVA earned 0.30 euro against 0.37 euro. Net interest income for the group was €3.25 billion against €3.43 billion. Analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires were forecasting net income of €1.16 billion. Core capital in September was 8.2%, while its Tier 1 was 9.2%. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -1.44% said Wednesday its third-quarter profit fell to $58 million, or 46 cents a share, from $80 million, or 63 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, the Toledo, Ohio, building materials company said it earned 35 cents a share. Sales slipped to $1.19 billion from $1.35 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 37 cents a share, on average, with sales of $1.25 billion. For the full year, Owens Corning forecast earnings before interest and taxes, or EBIT, to be in the range of $360 million to $390 million. Wall Street was looking for EBIT of $403.1 million. Shares of Owens Corning closed Tuesday at $28.20, off 2%.
title: Owens Corning's quarterly profit falls 28%

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Shares of the following companies were making notable moves in the U.S. stock market on Monday: Advancers Altair Nanotechnologies Inc. ALTI gained 3.8% to 72 cents after the provider of fast-response battery-systems technology said Canon Investment Holdings Ltd. agreed to acquire 51% of the company for nearly $49 million. MARKETS | • The Tell: Market news and analysis • | Canada section • Columns: Stocks | Oil | Gold | Bonds | Dollar  TOOLS AND DATA | • My Portfolio: Know where your funds are? • Real-time currency exchange rates • After-hours stock screener Chelsea Therapeutics International Ltd. CHTP shares rose 13% to $5.73 after the biopharmaceutical developer reported its hypotension drug met a top goal in a late-stage study. Diamond Hill Investment Group DHIL, -1.65%  shares gained 19% after the provider of investment management services said it would pay a special dividend of $12 a share in December. IGo Inc. IGOI, -3.91% shares gained 11% after the producer of mobile accessories said it would team with Cisco Systems Inc. CSC, +3.70%   to create products for Cisco’s Flip Video cameras. Internet Brands Inc. INET, +1.02%   shares jumped 45% after the operator of e-commerce sites said it would be acquired by a private-equity firm for $640 million. Read more on Internet Brands’ buyout offer. L-1 Identity Solutions Inc. ID, +3.85% shares were up 20% after the producer of solutions to protect assets and identities with biometrics agreed to a buyout valued at $12 a share with Safran SAFRF, +3.04%  the Paris aerospace and defense firm. Read more on Safran’s deal for L-1. Lennar Corp. LEN, -4.55% shares added 8.2% after the home builder returned to profitability for its third quarter and beat analysts’ expectations. Netezza Corp. NZ, +20.00% shares advanced 15% after the developer of technology to reduce the time required to load historical data agreed to be acquired by International Business Machines Corp. IBM, -2.21%  for about $27 a share. Shares of another data-storage company, Teradata Corp. TDC, -0.45%  , rose 7.5%. Read more on IBM-Netezza deal. digits: Apple Pushes Publishers Towards iPad Office Depot Inc. ODP, -2.79%   shares rose 10% after Janney Montgomery Scott LLP said in a note the office-supply chain was effectively managing its balance sheet. Prestige Brand Holdings Inc. PBH, -1.01%   shares rose 13% after the maker of Comet cleaner agreed to acquire Blacksmith Brands for $190 million. Rovi Corp. ROVI, +2.06%   shares rise 9.1% after the digital entertainment technology company announced a licensing deal with Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.94%   ValueClick Inc. VCLK  shares gained 9.4% after Benchmark Co. hiked its rating on the Internet advertising company to buy from hold. Decliners International Paper Co. IP, -4.17%  shares closed down 6.4% and Temple-Inland Inc. TIN, +0.00%  shares fell 5.9% after brokerages reassessed their outlooks for the sector after an article in Pulp & Paper Week said containerboard prices did not rise as much as previously forecast in August. Read more on paper, packing stocks. Owens Corning Inc. OC, -1.47%   shares fell 4.2% after the maker of insulation projected U.S. demand for roofing shingles will be down about 10% this year versus 2009. SouFun Holdings Ltd.’s SFUN, -0.10%  U.S.-listed shares declined 9.1% as investors took profits after a more than 70% climb in the Chinese real estate website’s market debut on Friday. More from MarketWatch This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Monday’s biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: Murphy Oil boosting dividend by 10% (6:39 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Murphy Oil Corp. MUR, -4.02% said Wednesday it'll boost its annual dividend by 10% to $1.10 a share, from $1 a share. Murphy Oil stock rose 1.8% to close at $56.73. On July 22, the company said it'll exit the refining business by putting its two U.S. refineries and its British refining and retail operations on the block. Avis Budget swings to profit in second quarter (5:54 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Avis Budget Group Inc. CAR, +0.38% said late Wednesday it swung to second-quarter net income of $26 million, or 22 cents a share, from a loss of $6 million, or 6 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Excluding certain items, the rental car company would have earned 29 cents a share. Revenue decreased to $1.29 billion from $1.31 billion a year ago. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research estimated a quarterly profit of 19 cents a share on revenue of $1.31 billion. Avis said it is continuing its efforts to reduce costs and boost productivity and expects its initiatives will result in total annual savings of $465 million to $485 million in 2010. News Corp: iPad has transformed view of mobile (5:36 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- News Corp. NWSA, -1.87% NWS, -2.02% Chief Operating Officer Chase Carey said Wednesday that Apple Inc.'s AAPL, -0.74% iPad has "transformed" the media industry's expectations around mobile devices, and News Corp. sees a number of related opportunities. "Not only does it provide a much richer environment for video, but for newspapers, like the Wall Street Journal, it's a lot better than reading on a PC." Chairman Rupert Murdoch, on the same conference call, reiterated that the iPad is "a game changer." Chance to re-energize 'American Idol:' News Corp. (5:24 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- News Corp. NWSA, -1.87% NWS, -2.02% Chief Operating Officer Chase Carey told analysts Wednesday that the departure of Simon Cowell offers Fox a chance to "re-energize" the perennially top-rated reality series "American Idol." Carey and News Corp. Chairman Rupert Murdoch said the U.S. launch of Cowell's "The X Factor" in the fall of 2011 will allow Fox to reap the benefit of having both shows on the schedule. Murdoch: 'We are not buying any sports teams' (5:09 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- News Corp. NWSA, -1.87% NWS, -2.02% Chairman Rupert Murdoch said Wednesday that the company is "not buying any sports teams." His comments come days after speculation that News Corp. might enter into bidding for baseball's Texas Rangers. News Corp. is the parent of MarketWatch, the publisher of this report. Murdoch: 'Very confident' about next six months (5:03 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- News Corp. NWSA, -1.87% NWS, -2.02% Chairman Rupert Murdoch said Wednesday that he is "very, very confident" about the stability of the world economy over the next six months. However, he added, "there is sufficient fragility for us not to be overconfident about the mid-term." Murdoch spoke to analysts during a conference call following News Corp.'s release of fiscal fourth-quarter earnings. News Corp. is the parent of MarketWatch, the publisher of this report. News Corp.'s Carey: Ad sales strong at TV networks (4:58 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- News Corp. NWSA, -1.87% NWS, -2.02% Chief Operating Officer Chase Carey said Wednesday that advertising sales at Fox Broadcasting and the company's cable television networks are selling at a brisk pace, with strong pricing. The Fox network is seeing ad rates that are up by a double-digit percentage from those charged during this spring when it made sold airtime for the fall season, Carey said. Ad rates are even better at the cable networks, he added. News Corp's cable channels, which already represent more than 50% of the company's profits, will continue to grow in importance, Carey said. Tesla Motors loss widens in first public report (4:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Tesla Motors, Inc. TSLA, -3.95% in its first quarterly earnings report since going public in late June, posted late Wednesday a second-quarter loss of $38.5 million, or $5.04 a share, compared with a year-ago loss of $10.9 million, or $1.56 a share. Revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose 5% to $28.4 million from $26.9 million a year ago. Shares of the Palo Alto, Calif.-based electric car maker fell as much as 3% to $20.60 in after hours-trade. The stock debuted at $17 a share on June 29. Transocean profit falls 11% (4:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Transocean Ltd. RIG, -2.98% late Wednesday reported second-quarter net income attributable to controlling interest of $715 million, or $2.22 a share, down from $806 million, or $2.49 a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell to $2.5 billion from $2.8 billion. Transocean, owner of the Deepwater Horizon rig that caught fire on April 20 and sank in the Gulf of Mexico, said it booked expenses of $82 million in the quarter related to the accident. The company did record a $267 million gain resulting from insurance recoveries from the sunken oil rig. Ahead of the earnings report, Transocean shares closed at $53.56, up 6%. Sonic Solutions trims first-quarter loss (4:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sonic Solutions Inc. SNIC on Wednesday reported a fiscal first-quarter loss of $1.1 million, or 3 cents a share, on revenue of $25.4 million, compared with a loss of $1.8 million, or 7 cents a share, on $25.5 million in the same period a year ago. Excluding one-time items, the media-content technology company would have earned $600,000, or two cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast Sonic to lose 3 cents a share on $25 million in sales. Sonic Chief Executive Dave Habiger said that deals with retailers and technology companies would help the Sonic have its technology installed in 20 million TVs and other devices by the end of the year. Hartford quarterly net income $76 million (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hartford Financial Services HIG, -2.37% said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income came in at $76 million, or 14 cents per common share. That compares to a net loss of $15 million, or 6 cents per common share, in the same period a year earlier. Core earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses and other items, was $92 million, or 17 cents per common share. Hartford was expected to make 79 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 18 analysts polled by FactSet. Hartford shares fell 4.1% to $22.87 in after-hours trading on Wednesday. News Corp. moves to profit as ad sales increase (4:24 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- News Corp. NWSA, -1.87% NWS, -2.02% said Wednesday that it turned a profit in its fourth quarter, reversing a year-ago loss, on improved ad sales at its television stations and cable networks. The results were well ahead of most analyst estimates. The company said it earned $875 million, or 33 cents a share, in the period ended June 30. A year earlier, it took a loss of $203 million, or 8 cents a share. Revenue rose 6% to $8.11 billion. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research were expecting a fourth-quarter profit of 20 cents a share on sales of $7.87 billion. News Corp. is the parent of Dow Jones & Co., which includes The Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones Newswires, Barron's and MarketWatch, the publisher of this report. Jack in the Box profit jumps 24% but revenue falls (4:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Jack in the Box Inc. JACK, -1.39% late Wednesday reported third-quarter net income of $24.2 million, or 44 cents a share, up from $19.6 million, or 34 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Earnings were dragged down by 6 cents a share in special items. Revenue dropped to $523.3 million from $575.7 million a year ago. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast the fast-food chain to report earnings of 53 cents a share on revenue of $525 million. Linda Lang, chief executive and president, said in a statement that revenue was impacted by high unemployment in major markets for Jack in the Box's key customer demographics. Prudential quarterly net income $798 million (4:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Prudential Financial PRU, -2.45% said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income came in at $798 million, or $1.70 per common share. That compares to net income of $538 million, or $1.25 per common share, in the same period a year earlier. Operating income, which excluded net realized investment gains and losses, was $708 million, or $1.51 per common share, in the latest quarter, the life insurance and annuity giant added. Prudential was expected to make $1.35 a share, according to the average estimate of 17 analysts surveyed by FactSet. Allstate quarterly net income falls 63% (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Allstate Corp. ALL, -1.13% said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income came in at $145 million, or 27 cents a share, down 63% from a year earlier when the auto insurer made $389 million, or 72 cents a share. Operating profit, which excludes net realized investment gains and losses, was $441 million, or 81 cents a share, in the latest period. Allstate was expected to make 75 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 21 analysts surveyed by FactSet. Unum shares slip on unemployment concern (11:14 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Unum Group shares UNM, -1.68% slipped more than 3% during Wednesday morning trading after the disability insurer reported quarterly results. Unum said late Tuesday that second-quarter profit, excluding net realized investment gains and losses, came in at $228.6 million, or 69 cents a share. That topped analyst forecasts, but the shares were pressured by concern about lingering unemployment in the U.S. Unum offers disability insurance through companies, so if payrolls stagnate, growth could be restrained. "We remain on the sidelines as elevated unemployment levels could hold back fundamental top- and bottom-line performance, relative to less payroll-exposed life insurance peers," Randy Binner and Kevin Barker, analysts at FBR Capital Markets, wrote in a note to investors Wednesday. Unum shares were down 3% at $22.04 in morning trading Wednesday. Time Warner CEO: DVD sales up on Netflix delay (11:11 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Time Warner Inc. TWX, -0.02% Chief Executive Jeff Bewkes said Wednesday that DVD sales at Warner Bros. are on the rise thanks to the studio's new strategy of requiring Netflix Inc. NFLX, -3.59% to wait 28 days before it can rent new-release discs to the public. Speaking during a conference call, Bewkes said the early evidence has shown that Warner's DVD sales are particularly strong in the first two to four weeks after a new title has been put up for sale. The Warner Bros. discs for "The Blindside" and "Sherlock Holmes" were among the beneficiaries of the new plan, he explained. Bewkes added that studios that have opted not to delay rentals by a month have seen their DVDs "underperform" in the marketplace since Warner Bros. implemented its strategy. CNO climbs 5.7% on 'refreshingly boring' results (10:58 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CNO Financial Group shares CNO, -0.65% rose almost 6% in morning trading Wednesday after the insurer reported what one analyst called "refreshingly boring" quarterly results. CNO said second-quarter net income rose 20% while operating profit came in at $44.9 million, or 16 cents a share. That beat analyst estimates, which averaged 14 cents a share. "Another refreshingly boring quarter," Paul Sarran, Mark Finkelstein and Jiyang Zhang, analysts at Macquarie Research, wrote in a note to investors. "CNO reported a second consecutive quarter free of major one-time charges or adjustments for the first time in recent memory." CNO shares gained 5.7% to $5.60 in morning action Wednesday. R.R. Donnelley triples earnings, shares up 4% (10:42 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co. RRD, -5.61% rose as much as 4% to $17.82 in early trades Wednesday after the printing and communications company reported a three-fold jump in second-quarter results, helped by a sharply lower tax rate and fewer restructuring charges. For the three months ended June 30, R.R. Donnelley's net income rose to $88.8 million, or 42 cents a share, from $25.2 million, or 12 cents, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, the Chicago-based company earned 47 cents a share, up from 37 cents a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 2.2% to $2.4 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had been looking for earnings of 35 cents a share. The stock is up 23% over the past 12 months. Dendreon rallies on quarterly sales report (10:36 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch)-- Dendreon Corp. DNDN shares rallied early Wednesday, moving up 13% to $38.24. Late Tuesday, Dendreon reported that sales of its recently-approved prostate cancer treatment Provenge were swift, garnering the company $2.8 million in revenue for the second quarter. Provenge received U.S. regulatory approval in April following a lengthy review process. Whole Foods shares fall on sales expectations (10:10 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Whole Foods Markets WFMI shares slid 7% to $36.60 early Wednesday after the natural foods retailer eased its sales expectations. Momentum investors had high hopes ahead of Whole Foods' earnings report Tuesday afternoon as the company's sales at existing grocery stores have grown the past three consecutive quarters. Whole Foods forecast suggests the company is "obviously not immune from macro headwinds affecting an increasingly wide range of consumer staples and discretionary stocks," said analyst Ajay Jain of Hapoalim Securities, who rates Whole Foods shares a sell. He has a $30 price target on the stock. On average, analysts think the stock is worth $42.30 a share long term, according to FactSet. Earnings beat lifts PulteGroup, builders (9:53 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of PulteGroup Inc. PHM, -4.44% were up 2.5% in early trade Wednesday after the home builder said it swung to a quarterly profit of 20 cents a share, easily topping the consensus estimate of a loss of a penny a share. "We note that results included an $82 million tax benefit, which contributed 21 cents to EPS; excluding this benefit, we estimate results were slightly below our estimate and slightly ahead of the Street's consensus," said J.P. Morgan analysts in a research note Wednesday. Shares of Beazer Homes USA Inc. BZH, -5.83% and Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. HOV, -2.46% also rose more than 2%. Energy stocks rise ahead of weekly supply data (9:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy stocks rose Wednesday ahead of weekly petroleum supply data, as Wall Street mildly cheered a drop in weekly jobless claims. The NYSE Arca Oil Index XOI, -2.56% rose 0.3% to 1,021. The NYSE Arca Natural Gas Index XNG, -3.68% added 0.9% to 535. The Philadelphia Oil Service Index OSX, -3.65% jumped 1% to 189. Devon Energy DVN, -4.28% rose 1.8% to $65.49. El Paso EP, +0.00% rose 1.6% to $12.84. PG&E Corp. net income drops 14% (9:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PG&E Corp. PCG, -1.34% said Wednesday its second-quarter earnings fell to $333 million, or 86 cents a share, from $388 million, or $1.02 per share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings at the San Francisco-based utility rose to 91 cents a share, from 83 cents a share. Revenue rose to $3.23 billion, from $3.19 billion. Wall Street analysts expected the company to earn 90 cents a share, on revenue of $3.3 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. PG&E Corp. continues to expect 2010 earnings of $3.35 a share to $3.50 a share. Devon Energy net income jumps 125% (8:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Devon Energy DVN, -4.28% said Wednesday its second-quarter net income more than doubled to $706 million, or $1.58 a share, from $314 million, or 70 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income in the latest period totaled $1.53 a share. Revenue rose to $2.23 billion, from $1.82 billion. Wall Street analysts expected earnings of $1.39 a share and revenue of $2.38 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. The Oklahoma City, Okla., company said higher prices for oil, natural gas and natural gas liquids drove its earnings, while overall production fell 3%. El Paso profit rises 86% (7:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- El Paso Cop. EP, +0.00% said Wednesday its second-quarter net income climbed 86% to $147 million, or 21 cents a share, from $79 million, or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The natural gas and pipeline firm's adjusted net income totaled 22 cents a share. Revenue rose to $1.4 billion, from $1 billion. Wall Street analysts expected El Paso to earn 20 cents a share, on revenue of $1.2 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. El Paso said its pipeline earnings before interest and taxes were up sharply due to the impact of expansions and a gain from the sale of Mexican assets. Looking ahead El Paso expects 2010 adjusted earnings of 90 cents to $1 a share, compared to the Wall Street target of 98 cents a share. Owens Corning profit jumps (7:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning Inc. OC, -1.48% said Wednesday its second-quarter profit rose to $937 million, or $7.33 a share, from $33 million, or 26 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The earnings were boosted by an $844 million income tax benefit. On an adjusted basis, profit was $73 million, or 57 cents a share, compared to an adjusted $62 million, or 49 cents a share, in the second quarter of 2009. Sales rose 13%, to $1.38 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research expected, on average, profit of 59 cents a share on sales of $1.38 billion. The Toledo, Ohio, building materials firm also said that its board has authorized the buyback of up to 10 million shares. Intercontinental Exchange profit rises (7:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Intercontinental Exchange, Inc. ICE, -2.16% said on Wednesday that its second quarter profit rose to $101.7 million, or $1.36 a share, from $72.1 million, or 97 cents a share a year ago. Revenue at the company rose to $296.2 million, from $250.4 million a year ago. On an adjusted basis and excluding items related to the firm's acquisition of the Climate Exchange, net income for the second quarter was $113 million, or $1.51 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had expected the company to earn $1.42 a share, on revenue of $294.2 million. Qwest's second-quarter earnings fall about 25% (7:34 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Qwest Communications International Inc. Q, +1.01% said Wednesday that its second-quarter earnings fell to $158 million, or 9 cents a share, from $212 million, or 12 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The latest quarter's per-share results included a 2-cent charge for severance, realignment and merger-related expenses and a 1-cent gain related to accounting treatment of convertible debt. Operating revenue declined 5% to $2.93 billion. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research were expecting the Denver-based telecommunications provider to earn 10 cents a share on $2.91 billion in revenue. PulteGroup swings to quarterly profit (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PulteGroup Inc. PHM, -4.44% said Wednesday it swung to a second-quarter profit of $76 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with a loss of $189 million, or 74 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Quarterly revenue rose to $1.3 billion, from $678.6 million last year, driven largely by the company's merger with Centex Corp. completed last August. Analysts on average had expected the home builder to post a loss of a penny a share, according to a Thomson Reuters poll. AOL posts $1 billion loss, revenue off 26% (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AOL Inc. AOL said Wednesday it swung to a second-quarter loss of $1.1 billion, or $9.89 a share, from net income of $153.7 million, or 86 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The New York-based web service firm's loss included a goodwill impairment charge of $1.4 billion. Revenue fell 26% to $584.1 million. Garmin posts smaller second-quarter profit (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Garmin Ltd. GRMN, -1.60% said Wednesday its second-quarter profit declined to $134.8 million, or 67 cents a share, from $161.9 million, or 81 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, the Swiss maker of navigation and communication equipment said it earned 85 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings of 73 cents a share, on average. Total revenue rose 9% to $729 million, versus the Wall Street consensus for sales of $677.3 million. For the full year, Garmin forecast pro forma earnings in the range of $2.75 to $3.15 a share. Analysts' mean estimate is for 2010 earnings of $2.90 a share. Shares of Garmin closed Tuesday at $29.35, up less than 1%. Quanta Services profit slips 1.3% (6:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Quanta Services Inc. PWR, -2.02% said Wednesday that its second-quarter net profit fell 1.3% to $33 million, or 16 cents a share, from $33.4 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. The company, which provides infrastructure services to the electricity, natural gas and telecoms industries, said revenue for the quarter grew 7% to $870.5 million, helped by the acquisition of Price Gregory. The group said adjusted earnings for the quarter were 22 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 18 cents a share. The group said it expects earnings for the year of between 85 cents and 90 cents a share. Standard Chartered profit up 11% (2:53 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Emerging markets focused bank Standard Chartered(UK:STAN)said Wednesday that its first-half net profit rose 11% to $2.15 billion pounds as lower risk provisions more than offset an increase in costs. The group said provisions in the period fell to $437 million from $1.09 billion a year earlier. Net interest income rose 12% to $4.16 billion, but was offset by a fall in non-interest income. Higher staff costs helped drive a 7.9% rise in operating expenses to $4.34 billion. The board declared a 10% rise in the bank's interim dividend to 23.35 cents a share. "Recently we have seen more positive sentiment in the markets, and encouraging upticks in some businesses. However, we remain somewhat cautious. We don't expect a smooth recovery, and we anticipate further bursts of volatility," the bank said. Lloyds beats forecasts as impairments fall sharply (2:42 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Lloyds Banking Group LLOY, -0.39% LYG, -0.81% topped earnings expectations as impairment losses on bad loans shrank by more than half compared to a year earlier. The group reported a statutory profit of 596 million pounds ($950 million), down from 7.1 billion pounds a year earlier when results were skewed by the accounting effect of its HBOS acquisition. On a combined business basis, the group said it swung to a pretax profit of 1.6 billion pounds from a loss of 3.96 billion pounds. Impairment charges for the period fell to 6.55 billion pounds from 13.4 billion pounds. Analysts had been expecting a pretax profit of 858 million pounds. The group said its Tier 1 capital ratio rose to 10.3% at the end of June, from 9.6% at the end of December. Adidas lifts outlook as quarterly profit surges (2:38 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- Adidas AG(DE:ADS)said Wednesday its second-quarter net profit soared to 126 million euros ($167 million) from €9 million in the same period a year ago, as it increased its full-year outlook. Sales surged 19% to €2.92 billion. The firm now expects full-year earnings per share to increase to a level between €2.50 and €2.62; previously, it projected an increase to a level between €2.05 and €2.30. In 2009, Adidas reported diluted earnings per share of €1.22. "We had an outstanding first half year driven by the FIFA World Cup 2010 and the resurgence of the Reebok brand in North America," said Chief Executive Herbert Hainer. Societe Generale profit more than triples (2:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French bank Societe Generale(FR:GLE)said Wednesday that its second-quarter net profit more than tripled to 1.08 billion euros ($1.43 billion) from 309 million euros a year earlier. The group reported stronger earnings from its French retail banking network, which helped offset a lower profit from its investment banking arm. The bank's corporate centre also booked a 254 million euro gain from the revaluation of its own debt, after the division booked a loss a year earlier. Analysts had been expecting SocGen to report a net profit of 777 million euros. The group said net allocations to provisions in the quarter fell 6% to 1.01 billion euros and added that its Tier 1 capital ratio was 10.7% at the end of June. Munich Re's second-quarter profit up 3.5% (2:25 AM ET) FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- Munich Re AG(DE:MUV2)said Wednesday its second-quarter net profit rose 3.5% to 709 million euros ($938 million) from €685 million in the same period a year ago. Gross premium revenue increased 6.1% to €10.96 billion. The firm's net investment result rose 19.7% to €2.62 billion from €2.19 billion. Analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires expected net profit of €478 million, gross premium revenue of €11.14 billion and net investment result of €2.26 billion.
