It now sees adjusted earnings between $3.85 and $3.95, down 27 to 31 cents from an earlier view, citing global econoimc conditions as well as 5 cents a share of currency move. Of the job cuts, nearly half will come through attrition of temporary workers. SPX posts in-line profit rise, trims top end of 2008 view (6:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Charlotte infrastructure products maker SPX Corp. SPW, -4.73% said third-quarter net income rose to $117 million, or $2.13 a share, from $92.9 million, or $1.71 a share. Revenue rose 29% to $1.51 billion. Adjusted earnings from continuing operations were $1.66 a share, up from $1.39 in the year-earlier quarter and in line with FactSet-compiled analyst estimates. It cut the top end of its earnings outlook for the year by 10 cents a share, with a new view of earnings between $6.40 and $6.50 a share, citing the recent strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the euro and British pound. Newmont Mining 3rd-quarter net off 51%, revenue off 14% (6:23 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Newmont Mining Corp., NEM, +1.15% the Denver gold and copper miner, reported third-quarter net income fell 51% on 14% lower revenue. Earnings fell to $196 million, or 43 cents a share, from $397 million, or 88 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings from continuing operations were 39 cents against 73 cents. Revenue fell to $1.39 billion from $1.62 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 42 cents of profit on $1.37 billion of revenue. Newmont sold 1.28 million ounces of gold at an average cost of $480 an ounce and a realized price of $865 an ounce. Revenue from gold sales rose 22% to $1.3 billion while revenue from copper sales fell 84% to $90 million. Headwaters to take $205 million impairment charge (6:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Headwaters Inc. HW., +1.69% said Wednesday that it will take a non-cash goodwill impairment charge of $205 million due to the impact of depressed residential housing and remodelling markets on its building products segment. The group said it will take the charge in its September quarter. It added that during the quarter it paid $35 million to retire the balance on its revolving credit line and pre-paid $10 million on its senior secured debt. Praxair third-quarter net income rises to $355 million (6:14 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Praxair Inc. PX, -1.57% on Wednesday said third-quarter net income rose to $355 million, or $1.11 a share, from $305 million, or 94 cents a share, in the same period last year. Consensus expectations were for earnings of $1.06 a share, according to a survey of analysts by FactSet Research. Sales rose to $2.852 billion in the quarter from $2.372 billion in the third quarter of 2007, the Danbury, Conn.-based industrial gases firm said. Praxair CEO Steve Angel said the company expects manufacturing output in the U.S. and Europe to contract due to the financial crisis, while a stronger dollar could impact sales and earnings growth by around 8% at current exchange rates. Praxair said it expects fourth-quarter earnings of $1.03 to $1.08 a share. Aetna profit drops 44% on investment losses; trims 2008 view (6:06 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Aetna AET, -1.01% said its third-quarter profit dropped 44% to $277.3 million, or 58 cents a share, after capital-market hit of 48 cents a share and a 6 cents a share allowance recorded against a reinsurance recoverable from a subsidiary of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. Operating earnings rose 15% to $1.12 a share, in line with analyst estimates. It cut its 2008 view to a range of $3.90 to $3.95 a share on lower fourth-quarter net investment income, down from its previous forecast of $4 a share. For 2009, it sees earnings up 3% to 5% including an increase in pension expense due to 2008 equity market performance. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected 2008 earnings of $4 a share and 2009 earnings of $4.43. Frontier Air posts 2nd-quarter loss of $29.7 mln (5:39 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Frontier Airlines Holdings Inc., FRNTQ the Denver carrier, reported late on Tuesday that for the second quarter ended Sept. 30, it had a $5.8 million operating loss and a $29.7 million net loss. For September, the operating loss was $10.4 million and the net loss was $20.8 million. Companies operating under Chapter 11 of U.S. bankruptcy law must report results monthly to the U.S. trustee as well as to the Securities and Exchange Commission, Frontier said. In September, compared with a year earlier, fuel costs were 54% higher and capacity 14% lower, Frontier said. Update: Zebra Tech net off; will buy back 8% of stock (4:31 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Zebra Technologies Corp., ZBRA, -0.75% the Vernon Hills, Ill., provider of specialty on-demand printers that turn out items like bar codes, smart labels, and photo-ID cards and tags, reported on Wednesday that third-quarter net income fell 4.4% on 12% higher sales. And it said it would buy back 5 million, or 8%, of its shares outstanding. Earnings fell to $25.8 million or 40 cents a share, from $27 million, or 39 cents, in the year-earlier period. Business-exit costs and integration expense cut the latest net by 4 cents a share, while special items added 3 cents. Shares outstanding fell 6.3% to 64.7 million. Sales reached $244.1 million from $217.2 million. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 40 cents of profit on $243.2 million of revenue. In the fourth quarter, Zebra expects to earn 30 cents to 38 cents a share on sales of $225 million to $241 million. The outlook reflects $2.8 million of business-exit costs and integration expenses, Zebra said. FactSet's survey is looking for 44 cents and $256.3 million. (Adds impact of costs and special items for latest quarter.) Stagecoach trading meeting expectations (3:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Bus and rail operator Stagecoach Group(UK:SGC)said Wednesday that trading since its August interim report has been in line with management expectations. The group said comparable 24-week revenue growth in its rail arm was 8.4%, and in its bus division was 9.2%. The U.S. business saw 5-month revenue grow 8.4% on a comparable basis. It added the outlook for the group remains positive as customers are switching from motoring to its value offers, such as its Megabus business in North America. BankAtlantic narrows 3rd-quarter loss; provision lower (3:19 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- BankAtlantic Bancorp Inc., BBX, +0.00% the Fort Lauderdale, Fla., bank-holding company, narrowed its third-quarter net loss as it made a smaller provision for possible losses on bad loans than it did a year earlier. The loss was $6.1 million, or 54 cents a share, against $29.6 million, or $2.61, in the year-earlier period. Continuing operations -- excluding additional proceeds from the February 2007 sale of Ryan Beck -- produced losses of 98 cents a share against $2.61 a share. The net interest margin, the difference between what a bank takes in on loans and pays out on deposits, was 3.56% in the latest quarter against 3.59% a year earlier. BankAtlantic Bancorp, with $6 billion of assets, also said that its annual assessment of goodwill may show that goodwill in one or more of its units is impaired. Any charge resulting from goodwill impairment won't affect operations or capital levels, the firm said. The bank said it continues to be well-capitalized with strong liquidity. Suncor 3rd-quarter net up 30% on pricing; revenue up 86% (2:44 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Suncor Energy Inc., SU, -1.87% (CA:SU)the Calgary, Alberta, integrated energy producer, reported third-quarter net income rose 30% on 86% higher revenue. Earnings reached C$815 million (US$642 million), or C$0.86 a share, from C$627 million, or C$0.66, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to C$8.95 billion from C$4.8 billion. The earnings increase reflected primarily higher prices for oil-sands products, Suncor said in a statement on Wednesday. The pricing was offset in part by higher operating costs, product purchases, and royalties it pays the government out of its oil-sands business. Sony Corp. second-quarter net drops 72% on-year (2:38 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Sony Corp.(JP:6758) SNE, -0.58% Wednesday said its fiscal second-quarter net income dropped 72% to 20.8 billion yen ($216 million), or 19.83 yen a share, because of a sharp appreciation in the yen and weak performance of its electronics and financial services divisions. Quarterly sales were flat at 2.07 trillion yen. The company's announcement comes a week after it cut its full-year profit forecast by 38% to 150 billion yen, from its July estimate of 240 billion yen. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -1.84% said Wednesday that it swung to a net loss of $810 million, or $6.36 a share, from a profit of $112 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier, due to an $899 million non-cash accounting charge. The group said sales for the quarter increased 28% to $1.63 billion and adjusted earnings from continuing operations rose by around two-thirds to $94 million, or 72 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting the building materials group to report adjusted earnings of 28 cents a share on revenue of $1.51 billion. Owens Corning said it continues to expect adjusted 2008 earnings before interest and taxes will be at least $265 million. The company also said the non-cash charge will have no impact on its ability to utilize the net operating losses to offset future U.S. profits.
title: Owens Corning swings to loss after charge, sticks to targets

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- David Brown, chief market strategist for Sabrient Systems, says it's time for investors to be "very, very careful, [but] a time to be nibbling" at some great individual stocks available at a discount. In an interview with Chuck Jaffe, MarketWatch senior columnist, Brown said that while the market's decline has boosted the value score on many securities, an appropriate reaction to current market conditions is to be nervous about just what comes out as a "buy" and to focus instead on stocks rated as a "strong buy." Brown said the energy and materials sectors look promising, but anyone concerned about a long recession might focus instead on health care and consumer staples companies. He said that industrials and technology stocks could be on the "outside looking in" for any market rebound. During his appearance on "Your Money with Chuck Jaffe," Brown followed through on that, labeling several energy stocks as buys, but saving his highest praise for a few strong buys, notably in shipping stocks. Brown put the "strong buy" label on Excel Maritime Carriers EXM, -5.77% -- which he said is the sixth-highest rated stock in his firm's database of 6,000 securities -- along with Frontline FRO, +0.11% and LDK Solar LDK Graham Corp. GHM, -2.01% is also one of his favorite picks, and Brown said he considers it a strong buy, although he noted that on Sabrient's proprietary scale it is currently rated as only a buy, due to a thin following of analysts. If just one more analyst tracked the company and confirmed what appears to be a healthy financial future, Brown said the stock would earn the strong buy label. Brown put several other stocks on the buy list, noting that they are good enough to purchase based on the Sabrient model. Those issues include BP Prudhoe Bay Royalty Trust BPT, +1.88% Arch Coal ACI, -0.18% and Regions Financial RF, -3.07% As for stocks to sell, Brown suggested that investors jettison James River Coal JRCC Owens Corning OC, -1.85% and Brookfield Asset Management BAM, -1.05% He labeled GT Solar SOLR, -7.14% and McDermott International MDR, -4.76% as "holds," although he liked the prospects for both issues and noted that MDR was teetering on the brink of becoming a buy based on several factors that seem to be turning positive for the company. Listen to the highlights of Your Money with Chuck Jaffe. Chuck Jaffe's podcasts features expert reviews of stocks and mutual funds suggested by MarketWatch readers; to request a stock or mutual fund for review by an expert in a future podcast, send your name, hometown and the ticker symbols that interest you to cjaffe@marketwatch.com. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Don’t ever do this with your credit card Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle
title: Energy and shipping sectors are bargain-priced

content: David Brown, chief market strategist for Sabrient Systems, says that it's "Time to be very, very careful [but} a time to be nibbling" at some great individual stocks available at a discount. In a MarketWatch interview, Brown said that in these market conditions, he is suggesting that investors bypass stocks that have met regular buying criteria to focus on the strongest of buy recommendations. loading... More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Related Topics Mutual Funds Investing U.S. Stocks Exchange Traded Funds
title: Be careful, but nibble at the strongest opportunities

content: DTE Energy profit falls (5:43 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- DTE Energy Co. DTE, +0.10% parent of Detroit Edison, reported late Wednesday second-quarter net income fell to $28 million, or 17 cents a share, from $385 million, or $2.20 a share, a year ago. The year-ago results included a one-time gain of $1.91 a share on the sale of the company's Antrim Shale gas business. Excluding one-time items, second-quarter earnings fell to 16 cents a share from 38 cents a year ago, with most of the decline pinned to mark-to-market trading losses and the company's stock buyback plan. Revenue for the quarter rose to $2.25 billion from $1.69 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated earnings of 52 cents a share on $2.01 billion in revenue. The company stuck by its earlier full-year earnings estimate of $2.80 to $3.20 a share. Shares of the Detroit-based power provider rose 1.2% to close at $41.55 ahead of the report. The stock is down 12% over the past 12 months. Murphy Oil profit jumps on higher oil price, asset sale (5:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Murphy Oil Corp. MUR, -4.68% reported late Wednesday second-quarter net income rose to $627 million, or $3.27 a share, from $250 million, or $1.32, a year ago, propelled by higher oil prices and output volumes. The latest results also included a one-time gain on the sale of its Lloydminster properties in Canada while year-ago results included a 13-cent per-share charge from the closure of 55 retail gasoline stations. Revenue rose to $8.36 billion from $4.61 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research estimated earnings of $2.14 a share. Shares of the El Dorado, Ark.-based oil company rose 6.8% to close at $79.09 ahead of the report. The stock is up 27% over the past 12 months. Visa quarterly net climbs 41% (4:47 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Visa Inc. V, -1.85% said late Wednesday that fiscal third-quarter net income came in at $422 million, or 51 cents per class A share, up 41% from a year earlier when the payment processing giant made $299 million. Visa was a private company a year ago, so it didn't have publicly-traded shares. Adjusting for certain costs from litigation and other issues, net income was $457 million, or 59 cents per class A common share, in the latest quarter, the company said. Net operating revenue in the fiscal third quarter 2008 was $1.6 billion, driven by strong contributions from service fees, data processing fees, and international transaction fees as payment volumes and processed transactions rose across all regions worldwide, Visa explained. CORRECT: Disney profit rises (4:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Walt Disney Co. DIS, -1.90% on Wednesday reported a fiscal third-quarter profit of $1.28 billion, or 66 cents a share, up from $1.18 billion, or 57 cents a share, a year ago. The most recent quarter included a one-time, per-share gain of 4 cents. The Burbank, Calif.-based entertainment giant posted sales of $9.24 billion, up from $9.05 billion a year earlier. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings, on average, of 61 cents a share with sales of $9.08 billion. (This version corrects year-ago revenue figure.) Allied Waste earnings rise to $111.4 million (4:44 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Allied Waste Inc. AW on Wednesday reported a second-quater profit of $111.4 million, or 25 cents a share, compared to earnings of $81.9 million, or 21 cents a share a year ago. The waste-management company's sales rose to $1.58 billion from $1.55 billion in the year-ago period. Excluding merger-related costs, Allied Waste would have earned 27 cents a share. By that measure, analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast Allied Waste to earn 26 cents a share on $1.59 billion in sales. Prudential quarterly net falls 31% (4:33 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Prudential Financial PRU, -3.03% said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income came in at $575 million, or $1.35 per common share, down 31% from a year earlier when the life insurance and annuity giant made $835 million, or $1.80 per common share. After-tax adjusted operating income, which excludes net realized investment gains and losses, was $868 million, or $2.02 per common share. Prudential was expected to make $1.85 a share, according to a survey of analysts by FactSet Research. The company stuck to a previous forecast for full-year operating earnings of $7.50 to $7.80 a share. Las Vegas Sands swings to a loss in second quarter (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Las Vegas Sands Corp. LVS, -1.92% late Wednesday reported it swung to a net loss of $8.8 million, or 2 cents a share, in the second quarter from a net income of $34.4 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier due in part to operating expenses related to its opening of The Venetian in Macao and The Palazzo in Las Vegas. Excluding loss on disposal of assets, pre-opening expense, development expense, and loss on early retirement of debt, Las Vegas Sands would have earned 9 cents a share. Revenue almost doubled to $1.11 billion from $612.9 million, said the Las Vegas hotel and gaming company. Analysts had forecast earnings of 12 cents a share on revenue of $1.11 billion, according to a survey by Thomson Reuters. Unum quarterly net rises 57%; insurer lifts forecast (4:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Unum Group UNM, -2.46% said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income came in at $240.3 million, or 69 cents per common share, up 57% from a year earlier when the disability insurer made $153.5 million, or 43 cents per common share. Excluding after-tax net realized investment gains and losses, Unum reported quarterly profit of $223.2 million, or 65 cents per common share. The company was expected to make 59 cents a share, according to an analyst survey by FactSet Research. The benefit ratio in Unum's U.S. group disability business was 90.5%. The insurer increased its forecast for full-year operating profit to between $2.46 and $2.51 per common share. That's up from a previous target of between $2.37 and $2.42 per share. Unum also sees continued improvement in the benefit ratio of its U.S. group disability line to within a range of 88% to 89% by late 2008 to early 2009. THQ loss rises to $27.2 million (4:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- THQ Inc. THQI on Wednesday reported a first-quarter loss of $27.2 million, or 41 cents a share, up from a loss in the year-ago period of $9.3 million, or 14 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the video-game publisher would have lost $25.4 million, or 38 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had forecast THQ to lose 37 cents a share. The company reported net sales $137.6 million, an increase of more than 31% from a year ago. Excluding deferred revenue from certain online game sales, THQ's sales came in at $121.1 million, which was in line with analysts' estimates. For its second-quarter, THQ said it expects to report a net loss of between 35 cents and 39 cents a share on sales in a range of $160 million to $170 million. Starbucks swings to loss (4:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -3.49% reported late Wednesday a fiscal third-quarter net loss of $6.7 million, or a loss of a penny per share, down from a profit of $158.3 million, or 21 cents, in the year-ago quarter. Revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose 9.1% to $2.57 billion from $2.36 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had predicted the Seattle-based coffee shop chain would earn 18 cents a share on $2.6 billion in sales. Starbucks shares closed ahead of the report with a loss of 2.1%, or 32 cents, at $14.67. Symantec beats estimates with profit, sales gains (4:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Symantec Corp. said Wednesday its fiscal first-quarter net income rose to $187 million, or 22 cents a share, from $95 million, or 10 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. Cupertino, Calif.-based security software maker Symantec SYMC, -2.80% said revenue for the quarter ended in July rose to $1.65 billion from $1.4 billion. Excluding special items, Symantec said earnings for the period would have been 40 cents a share. Analysts had estimated Symantec would post earnings excluding special items of 35 cents a share, and $1.57 billion in revenue, according to FactSet Research. EarthLink shares recover slightly following after-hours drop (2:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of EarthLink Inc. regained some ground Wednesday, following an after-hours drop the previous day. The shares were down over 5% by early afternoon Wednesday, to $9.05. Late Tuesday a report in the online edition of The Wall Street Journal had spurred speculation that EarthLink ELNK may try to acquire AOL's TWX, -0.08% dial-up Internet access business. Hess sticks to production forecast, ups Bakken presence (10:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Hess Corp. HES, -4.96% said on a conference call with analysts that it has increased its acreage position in the Bakken Play in North Dakota to about 500,000 acres. Hess currently has seven rigs operating in the Bakken and will add one additional rig in the fourth quarter. For the full year, Hess said capital and exploratory expenditures are forecast to be about $5 billion, up $600 million from its view in January. Hess Corp. stuck to its 2008 production forecast of 380,000 to 390,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day. Centex CEO sees no relief for housing this year (10:12 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Centex Corp. CTX, -0.17% Chief Executive Tim Eller during a conference call Wednesday said the housing market worsened during the June quarter "and we don't see any improvements in market conditions the remainder of this fiscal year." The home-builder CEO said foreclosures are rising "dramatically" in most markets while employment growth is slowing. "Mortgage interest rates are on the rise, and we're seeing stricter mortgage-qualification requirements for home buyers. Energy costs have increased substantially for our subcontractors, suppliers and customers," Eller said. "All of these factors are causing consumer confidence to erode further. This uncertainty reflected directly in our diminished traffic and sales volumes, compared to last quarter and a year ago." Analysts see improvement in Centex's cash flows, impairments (9:50 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Centex Corp. CTX, -0.17% gained more than 5% early Wednesday after the company reported a quarterly loss but analysts found bright spots in the builder's cash flows and lower impairment charges. "Now that Centex has $1.24 billion in cash on its balance sheet, the urgency to harvest assets through land sales, divestitures and aggressive pricing has diminished," said Deutsche Bank analysts in response to Centex's earnings report released after Tuesday's closing bell. "Impairments of $80 million were also down dramatically and at their lowest level in two years." Despite a tough housing market, "we believe Centex has the right approach through its pricing transparency and asset-light strategy," added Soleil Securities Group analysts. "We were encouraged by the solid cash generation and relatively low amount of impairments taken in the quarter." Lubrizol quarterly profit slips to $78 million (9:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Lubrizol Corp. LZ said Wednesday its second-quarter profit totaled $78 million, or $1.13 a share, from $81 million, or $1.15 a share, in the same quarter a year before. Analysts had expected earnings on average of $1.04 a share, according to a FactSet Research survey. Revenue for the quarter was $1.35 billion compared to $1.15 billion in the year-ago period. Lubrizol also said it now sees 2008 earnings coming in at $4.20 to $4.35 a share or adjusted earnings of $4.43 to $4.58. Allergan's second-quarter profit rises (9:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Allergan Inc. AGN, -3.01% said Wednesday that second-quarter earnings rose to $147.3 million, or 48 cents a share, from $137.8 million, or 45 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were $193.4 million, or 63 cents a share, compared with $166.7 million, or 54 cents a share. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research expected earnings of 62 cents a share. The Irvine, Calif., drugmaker's total revenue rose to $1.17 billion from $977.9 million. For the third quarter, Allegan expects adjusted earnings of 64 cents to 65 cents a share and total product net sales of $1.09 billion to $1.12 billion. For 2008, Allergan expects adjusted earnings of $2.57 to $2.59 a share and total product net sales of $4.47 billion and $4.58 billion. Meredith earnings drop to 41 cents a share in quarter (8:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Meredith Corp. MDP, -2.23% said Wednesday that fourth-quarter earnings fell to $19 million, or 41 cents a share, compared to $52 million, or $1.05 a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding the special charge for restructuring its book publishing business, earnings per share were 76 cents. Fourth-quarter revenue was $385 million, compared to $428 million in the prior-year quarter. Energizer Holdings net income up 7% (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energizer Holdings Inc. ENR, -7.44% on Wednesday said third-quarter net income for the three months ended June 30 rose to $66.7 million, or $1.13 a share, from $62.5 million, or $1.06 a share in the year-ago period. Breaking out one-time charges, earnings in the latest period were $1.23 a share. Revenue rose to $1.07 billion from $800 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet forecast earnings of $1.28 a share and revenue of $1.08 billion, on average. "General economic conditions continue to impact our battery business, and it remains to be seen if category softness will impact the upcoming holiday season," the St. Louis company said. Temple-Inland's second-quarter profit tumbles (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Temple-Inland Inc. TIN, +0.00% said Wednesday that its second-quarter net income fell to $8 million, or 7 cents a share, from $66 million, or 62 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Austin, Texas-based maker of packaging and building products said that quarterly revenue fell to $991 million from $1.02 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research forecast, on average, a loss of 4 cents a share. Taiwan's UMC sees quarterly profit cut in half (8:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- United Microelectronics Corp. UMC, -1.93% said Wednesday its second-quarter net profit halved from a year earlier, partly on a sharp fall in income from share divestments, according to results reported in The Wall Street Journal. UMC, the world's second-largest contract chip manufacturer by revenue after Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. TSM, -2.66% also warned global economic uncertainties are depressing demand in the usually strong third quarter. The company said net profit in the April-June period was 2.4 billion New Taiwan dollars (US$78.7 million), down 51% from NT$4.91 billion a year earlier, while revenue was flat at NT$25.2 billion from NT$25.1 billion, the report said. UMC didn't elaborate on its results but analysts had expected a decline in second-quarter earnings because of weak demand for communications chips in the recent quarter, the Journal reported. Imperial Sugar swings to 3rd-quarter loss (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Imperial Sugar, IPSU the Sugar Land, Texas, marketer of sugar under the Imperial, Dixie Crystals and Holly brands, swung to a fiscal third-quarter net loss from a year-earlier profit on 51% lower revenue. The loss was $12.5 million, or $1.07 a share, against net income of $7.6 million, or 64 cents, in the year-earlier period. The loss from continuing operations was $1.07 against profit of 95 cents a year earlier. Revenue fell to $106.9 million from $216.4 million. The current figures reflect a pretax charge of $5.2 million tied to a refinery explosion and fire in February. The year-earlier results include a pretax gain of $6.8 million after the company settled certain arbitration claims. Pinnacle West reports rise in second-quarter earnings (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Pinnacle West Capital Corp. PNW, -0.74% parent of the Arizona Public Service electric utility, said Wednesday that its second-quarter net income rose to $133.9 million, or $1.33 a share, from $79.0 million, or 78 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The company cited $30 million of tax-related credits and a $19 million gain from an asset sale for the higher results. Ongoing earnings for the quarter came in at $1.03 a share. Revenue for the three months ended June 30 increased to $926.2 million from $862.9 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research had expected the Phoenix-based company to report earnings of 76 cents a share. Sealed Air's second-quarter profit falls 15%; sets job cuts (7:57 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sealed Air Corp. SEE, -2.55% said Wednesday that its second-quarter net income fell 15% to $62.6 million, or 34 cents a share, from $73.9 million, or 40 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding items, earnings would have been 38 cents a share vs. 41 cents. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research expected earnings of 40 cents a share. The Elmwood Park, N.J., specialty packaging materials maker said sales rose 12% to $1.28 billion from $1.15 billion. Sealed Air cut its full-year guidance to a range of $1.41 to $1.51 a share from its prior range of $1.64 to $1.74. Excluding charges, it sees 2008 earnings of $1.55 to $1.65 a share, compared to its previous expectation of $1.75 to $1.85. It also set plans to reduce its workforce by 5%, or 900 to 1,000 jobs, and to close or consolidate some of its smaller facilities. Reynolds American earnings per share rise 12.7% (7:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Reynolds American RAI said Wednesday that earnings for the second quarter rose to $364 million, or $1.24 a share, compared to $325 million, or $1.10 a share a year ago. Sales inched lower to $2.34 billion, compared to $2.35 billion a year ago. FactSet analysts, on average, estimated earnings per share of $1.18 on sales of $2.30 billion for the cigarette maker. Southern quarterly profit slips to 54 cents a share (7:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Southern Co. SO, -0.56% said Wednesday its second-quarter profit totaled $416 million, or 54 cents a share, down from $429 million, or 57 cents a share, in the same quarter a year before. Those earnings included a charge of 9 cents per share related to three leveraged leases from the 1990s and 2 cents a share in synthetic fuel earnings. Analysts had expected earnings on average of 57 cents a share, according to a FactSet Research survey. Revenue for the quarter was $4.22 billion compared to $3.77 billion in the year-ago period. IAC/Interactive swings to loss; adjusted net higher (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- IAC/Interactive Corp., IACI, +0.00% the New York company with media and other businesses, reported a second-quarter net loss against year-earlier net income, 2% lower adjusted net income, and 6.9% higher revenue. The net loss was $421.6 million, or $1.51 a share, compared with profit of $94.6 million, or 31 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted profit was 35 cents a share versus 34 cents. Revenue reached $1.6 billion from $1.49 billion. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced consensus estimates of 31 cents of profit on revenue of $1.6 billion. "We are now right around the corner from the separation of IAC into five separate companies and the dissolution of the complexity urrounding the combined structure," Chairman and Chief Executive Barry Diller said in a statement on Wednesday. Hess Corp. net rises 62% on oil production hike (7:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Hess Corp. HES, -4.96% on Wednesday said second-quarter net income rose to $900 million, or $2.76 a share, from $557 million, or $1.75 a share in the year-ago period. Oil and gas production rose 4% to 393,000 barrels a day from 378,000 barrels a day. Wall Street expected Hess Corp. to earn $2.62 a share, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Kimco Realty funds from operations drop (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Kimco Realty Corp. KIM, +0.11% said Wednesday that its funds from operations, the standard measure of a REIT's financial results, slipped to $171.1 million, or 66 cents a share, from $184.2 million, or 71 cents a share a year ago. Revenue rose to $184.1 million from $169.3 million. Kimco also said that it expects funds from operations for all of 2008 to be in the range of $2.70 a share to $2.78 a share. Owens Corning ups earnings outlook as sales rise (7:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -1.91% upped its annual earnings outlook after saying second-quarter net income rose to $31 million, or 24 cents a share, from $29 million, or 22 cents a share. Sales rose 23% to $1.57 billion on the company's composites acquisition, strong global demand for glass fiber reinforcements and price increases in roofing and asphalt. On an adjusted basis, the Toledo firm earned 25 cents a share, compared to FactSet-compiled earnings estimates of 21 cents a share. Owens Corning now estimates that 2008 adjusted earnings before interest and tax will be at least $265 million, a 10% increase from its prior estimate of at least $240 million. Analysts expected an annual EBIT of $266 million. Corning Inc.net up sharply on $2.4 bln tax allowance (7:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Corning Inc. GLW, -2.67% on Wednesday said second-quarter net income for the three months ended June 30 rose sharply to $3.2 billion, or $2.01 a share, from $489 million or 31 cents a share in the year-ago period. The latest period included a $2.4 billion net special gain for the release of U.S. deferred tax asset valuation allowances. Excluding special items, earnings per share in the latest period were 49 cents a share, within its 47-50 cent target. Sales increased 19% to $1.69 billion. Analysts surveyed by FactSet forecast earnings of 48 cents a share on revenue of $1.7 billion. Lazard profit grows 17% (7:34 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Lazard Ltd LAZ, -1.66% said Wednesday that its second-quarter net profit rose 17% to $34.3 million, or 54 cents a share, from $29.3 million, or 52 cents a share a year earlier. Total revenue for the period rose 13% to $504 million. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting earnings of 50 cents a share. Lazard said its financial advisory, M&A and asset management divisions all posted revenue growth in the quarter. The group said the outlook for market activity for the remainder of the year remains unclear. Visteon loses 32 cents a share in quarter (7:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Visteon Corp. VC, -2.60% said Wednesday that it lost $42 million, or 32 cents a share in the second quarter. In the year-ago period Visteon lost $67 million, or 52 cents a share. Total sales for second quarter 2008 were $2.9 billion, a decrease of $69 million from the same period a year ago, including $17 million of lower services revenue. Analysts polled by FactSet estimated a second-quarter loss of 41 cents a share on sales of $2.7 billion. Visteon is adjusting its full year 2008 sales down $100 million from $10.1 billion to $10.0 billion. Garmin's second-quarter profit climbs (7:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Garmin Ltd. GRMN, -1.90% said Wednesday that its second-quarter profit rose to $256.1 million, or $1.19 a share, from $214.4 million, or 98 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Excluding foreign exchange, earnings were $1.18 a share compared to the year-ago $1.00. On average, analysts polled by FactSet Research expected a profit of $1.01 a share. Revenue for the three months ended June 28 rose 23% to $912 million from $742 million. The company, which makes GPS devices, also said it expects to report full-year earnings of $4.13 a share, excluding foreign exchange, on revenue of $3.9 billion, citing macroeconomic conditions and high fuel prices. Jones Apparel swings to 13-cents-a-share quarterly profit (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Jones Apparel Group, Inc. JNY said Wednesday its second-quarter profit totaled $10.6 million, or 13 cents a share, from a loss of $47.1 million, or 44 cents a share, in the same quarter a year before. Adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations were 20 cents, as compared with 17 cents for the same period last year, while analysts had expected that figure to come in at 12 cents a share, according to a FactSet Research survey. Revenue for the quarter was $829 million compared to $904 million in the year-ago period. Cameron net climbs 23% on drilling boost (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cameron CAM, -1.67% said second-quarter net income rose 23% to $152 million, or 65 cents a share from $123.2 million, or 54 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Houston oil services firm said revenue increased 30% to $1.5 billion. Gains in the company's subsea and drilling product lines drove profit growth, the company said. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research forecast earnings of 61 cents a share on revenue of $1.36 billion. Office Depot swings to loss as sales slip (7:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Office Depot ODP, -2.79% said it swung to a second-quarter loss of $2 million, or a penny a share, as sales fell 1% to $3.6 billion and comparable-store sales in the U.S. and Canada dropped 10%. The Delray Beach, Fla. company earned $106 million in the year-earlier period. On an adjusted basis, Office Depot's earnings fell to 4 cents a share from 41 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected earnings of 19 cents a share. It added it's received recently an unsolicited $430 million non-binding proposal from its partner in its Mexican joint venture and said it hasn't yet engaged in substantive discussions. Moody's 2nd-quarter net off 48%; year outlook affirmed (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Moody's Corp., MCO, -2.41% the New York provider of financial services including credit ratings, reported on Wednesday second-quarter net income fell 48% on 25% lower revenue, and it affirmed its full-year earnings estimate. Earnings fell to $135.2 million, or 54 cents a share, from $261.9 million, or 95 cents, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding fell 10% to 248.1 million. Revenue fell to $487.6 million from $646.1 million. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of 48 cents of profit on $465.5 million of revenue for the period. Moody's affirmed its full-year earnings estimate of $1.90 to $2 a share, based on its "solid base of recurring revenue from the ratings business and good growth from Moody's Analytics, together with" cost controls, the company said. FactSet's survey is looking for $1.94. Interpublic earnings per share fall to 17 cents in quarter (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Interpublic IPG, -1.85% said Wednesday that second-quarter earnings fell to $88.1 million, or 17 cents a share, compared to $121.5 million, or 24 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $1.8 billion, compared to $1.7 billion. On average, analysts polled by FactSet estimated second-quarter earnings for the advertising and marketing company of 17 cents on revenue of $1.8 billion. Huntsman swings to a gain on 17% revenue growth (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Huntsman Corp. HUN, -3.90% swung to a second-quarter gain of $23.7 million, or 10 cents a share, from a loss of $7.3 million, or 3 cents a share in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income fell to 9 cents a share from 36 cents a share. Revenue rose 17% to $2.9 billion for the Woodlands, Texas chemical firm. Analysts expected earnings of 16 cents a share and revenue of $2.7 billion, according to a survey by FactSet Research. Looking ahead, Huntsman said it's encouraged by the recent moderation in crude oil and natural gas prices in recent weeks. SPX net up; year outlook lifted for second time in 2008 (6:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- SPX Corp., SPW, -4.73% the Charlotte, N.C., manufacturer of systems for energy and power applications, reported on Wednesday that second-quarter net income rose 48% on 29% higher revenue, and it boosted its full-year earnings outlook for the second time in 2008. Earnings reached $94.8 million, or $1.74 a share, from $63.9 million, or $1.12, in the year-earlier period. Continuing operations generated profit of $1.70 a share against $1.24. A survey of analysts by FactSet Research produced a consensus estimate of $1.56 for the quarter. Shares outstanding fell 4.9% to 55 million. Revenue rose to $1.56 billion from $1.21 billion. Internally generated revenue grew 3.7% while completed acquisitions added 21%. Currency changes boosted revenue by 4.5%, SPX reported. SPX now expects to earn $6.40 to $6.60 a share this year. That's up from the previous estimate of $6.20 to $6.40. The company had lifted the estimate for the first time in April, from a range of $6 to $6.20. Rockwood second-quarter net income rises to $78 million (6:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Chemicals-maker Rockwood Holdings Inc. ROC, +0.00% on Wednesday said second-quarter 2008 earnings rose to $78 million, or $1.01 a share, from $28 million, or 37 cents a share a year ago. This year's results included 33 cents of income tied to non-recurring, after-tax valuation gains from interest-rate hedges, the New Jersey-based company said. A FactSet Research survey of analysts had produced a consensus forecast of 59 cents a share. Rockwood said second-quarter net sales were $945.5 million, up 17.8% from last year. In a news release, CEO Seifi Ghasemi said the company remained on track to meet its 2008 goal of boosting top-line growth by at least 8% while maintaining margins of more than 19%. American Tower ups goals after swinging to profit (6:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- American Tower AMT, -0.78% upped its annual earnings and sales goals after swinging to a profit of $158.8 million, or 38 cents a share during the second quarter. Revenue rose 10% to $393.7 million. Excluding items including a $106.1 million tax benefit, and it earned 12 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected earnings of 13 cents a share. For the year, the wireless tower operator sees adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization between $1.08 billion and $1.1 billion and rental and management segment revenue between $1.54 billion and $1.55 billion. Analysts expected an annual EBITDA of $1.08 billion. Monaco Coach posts loss on 40% sales drop (6:12 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Recreational vehicle maker Monaco Coach MNC, -38.46% swung to a second-quarter loss of $9.7 million, or 33 cents a share, as revenue dropped 40% to $201.9 million. It earned $4.5 million in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by FactSet expected a loss of 17 cents a share on sales of $252 million. Monaco Coach said it's received a waiver for non-compliance with certain financial covenants as of the end of the second quarter from its current syndicate of banks and signed a commitment letter for a three-year, $100 million facility. The RV maker is seeking approximately $30 million to $40 million in subordinated debt financing. Tyco Electronics back to profit, tightens annual outlook (6:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Tyco Electronics TEL, -3.12% said it swung to a third-quarter ending June 27 profit of $330 million, or 68 cents a share, with sales climbing to $3.91 billion from $3.29 billion. From continuing operations, it earned 66 cents a share. Tyco Electronics lost $1.37 billion during the same period last year as it was spun off from Tyco International. It sees annual earnings between $2.63 to $2.65 a share and its board added the authority to add $750 million to its existing stock buyback program. Tyco Electronics previously expected annual earnings between $2.60 and $2.66 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected earnings of 67 cents a share for the quarter and $2.66 for the year. Next comparable sales down 2.4%, remains very cautious (2:53 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. clothing retailer Next(UK:NXT)said Wednesday that its total sales returned to growth in the second quarter, edging up 0.2% after falling 3.9% in the first quarter. The growth was driven by its directory business, while full-price comparable sales at its retail stores fell 2.4% in the second quarter. "We remain very cautious about the outlook for the second half and can see no reason for any improvement in consumer spending, indeed, the economic risks appear to us to be on the downside," the group said. Rising food, fuel and mortgage costs will weigh heavily on consumer spending, Next added. It is therefore planning for retail full-price comparable sales in the second half to fall a similar amount to the 6% drop seen for the whole of the first half. Aviva posts loss on asset declines, eyes U.S. listing (2:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British insurer Aviva(UK:AV)said it swung to a 81 million pound ($160 million) loss during the fiscal first half of the year, or a loss of 1.28 billion pounds on a European embedded value basis, a popular way for insurers to measure earnings. Aviva said the loss is down to a reduction in value of the group's assets. Its operating profit rise of 12% to 1.72 billion pounds edged past company-compiled analyst estimates. Aviva also said a new finance program will bring it into Sarbanes-Oxley compliance, which would enable a U.S. listing next year. It's raising its dividend by 10% to 13.09 pence a share. It also reached a 1 billion pound deal to give policyholders surplus assets. NTT DoCoMo net rises 41%, leaves forecast unchanged (2:42 AM ET) HONG KONG (MarketWatch) -- Japan's largest mobile phone operator NTT DoCoMo Inc.(JP:9437)Wednesday said its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 41% on lower operating expenses. Net income increased to 173.5 billion yen ($1.8 billion), or 4,082 yen a share, from 122.8 billion yen. Operating revenue slipped 1% to 1.17 trillion yen. NTT left its full-year forecast of 503 billion yen in net income and 4.77 trillion yen in operating revenue unchanged. Cadbury profit down 38%, sees revenue at top of target range (2:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Cadbury(UK:CBRY)said Wednesday that its first-half net profit fell 38% to 113 million pounds, while revenue grew 14% to 2.65 billion pounds. Excluding restructuring costs and other one-off charges, underlying operating profit rose 48% to 248 million pounds. Cadbury said revenue growth was ahead of its goal range and underlying margins were 1.9 percentage points ahead of a year ago. Cadbury added higher prices have offset rising input costs and said it's expecting revenue growth for the year to be around the top end of its 4% to 6% goal. Siemens net down 31% but tops estimates (2:35 AM ET) MUNICH (MarketWatch) -- Siemens AG SI Wednesday said third-quarter net profit fell 31% due to a one-time gain a year earlier, but order intake and revenue rose, showing the industrial conglomerate's resilience so far to the economic downturn. Net profit for the period ending June 30 was EUR1.42 billion compared with EUR2.07 billion in the prior-year quarter when the figure was boosted by a EUR1.7 billion non-cash gain related to the Nokia Siemens Networks joint venture with Nokia Corp. Siemens reported its third quarter results for the first time under the new company structure which divides the company into three sectors: industry, energy and healthcare. Order intake in the period was EUR23.68 billion, up 21% from the prior year, while sales rose 10% to EUR19.18 billion from EUR17.52 billion. The results beat analysts' expectations, which called for sales of EUR18.68 billion, order intake of EUR21.94 billion, and net profit of EUR948 million. Siemens confirmed its outlook for fiscal year 2008, reiterating it expect to grow at twice te rate of global GDP growth and group profit from operations and income from continuing operations are expected to match fiscal 2007 levels. Siemens also said it expects the profit of its three main sectors to come in a range of EUR8.0 billion to EUR8.5 billion in its fiscal year 2009. In fiscal 2007, the profit of the three main sectors was EUR6.66 billion. Lloyds TSB profit falls 63% after write-downs (2:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. bank Lloyds TSB(UK:LLOY) LYG, -0.94% said Wednesday that its first-half net profit fell 63% to 576 million pounds as its results were hit by the impact of market dislocation and volatility relating to its insurance business. Pretax profit fell 70% to 599 million pounds, and was short of market expectations. The group said total impairment losses rose 31% to 1.1 billion pounds, mainly due to rises in wholesale and international banking. Lloyds said it took a 62 million pounds charge against its portfolio of collateralized debt obligations and wrote-down the value of protection from a bond insurer by 170 million pounds. Volatility in equity and fixed income markets also contributed to 505 million pounds of losses in its insurance arm. The group also said it will increase its interim dividend by 2% to 11.4 pence. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -2.16% upped its annual earnings outlook after saying second-quarter net income rose to $31 million, or 24 cents a share, from $29 million, or 22 cents a share. Sales rose 23% to $1.57 billion on the company's composites acquisition, strong global demand for glass fiber reinforcements and price increases in roofing and asphalt. On an adjusted basis, the Toledo firm earned 25 cents a share, compared to FactSet-compiled earnings estimates of 21 cents a share. Owens Corning now estimates that 2008 adjusted earnings before interest and tax will be at least $265 million, a 10% increase from its prior estimate of at least $240 million. Analysts expected an annual EBIT of $266 million.
title: Owens Corning ups earnings outlook as sales rise

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Shares of the following companies were among that made notable moves in the U.S. stock market Wednesday. Advancers Cephalon Inc. CEPH said a Joint Advisory Committee to the Food and Drug Administration voted not to recommend approval of an expanded label for the painkiller Fentora. The panel expressed concerns about minimizing risks potentially associated with an expanded indication of Fentora, the drug company said. Fentora is used for the management of breakthrough pain in opioid-tolerant patients with cancer. An FDA decision on an expanded label for Fentora to treat chronic pain is expected by Sept. 13. DirecTV Group Inc.'s DTV, -0.41% first-quarter net income rose 10% amid higher net subscriber additions and a lower subscriber cancellation rate. DirecTV, the nation's largest satellite-TV firm, reported net income of $371 million, or 32 cents a share, up from $336 million, or 27 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 17% to $4.59 billion. The mean estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters were for earnings of 31 cents a share on revenue of $4.47 billion. DirecTV said U.S. net subscriber additions rose 17% to 275,000, putting the total at 17 million, up 5.2%. Average revenue per subscriber increased 8.6% and average subscriber-acquisition costs climbed 6.7%. The monthly churn rate - the percentage of customers that left - fell to 1.36% from 1.44%. Walt Disney Co. DIS, -1.83% said second-quarter net income was $1.13 billion, or 58 cents a share, compared with $931 million, or 44 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Reporting after the close, the Burbank, Calif.-based entertainment giant said sales were $8.71 billion versus last year's $7.95 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected Disney to earn 51 cents a share on sales of $8.51 billion. See full story. Frontier Oil Corp. FTO, +1.91% said its first-quarter profit totaled $46.0 million, or 44 cents per share, from $74.7 million, or 68 cents per share, in the same quarter a year before. Analysts had, on average, expected earnings of 24 cents per share, according to a FactSet Research survey. Revenue totaled $1.19 billion versus the year-ago quarter's $1.05 billion. Marsh & McLennan Cos. MMC, -2.48% swung to a first-quarter net loss of $210 million, or 40 cents a share, from a profit of $268 million, or 47 cents a share a year earlier. Excluding a non-cash goodwill-impairment charge of $425 million, or 81 cents a share, and other items, the insurer posted non-GAAP income from continuing operations of 46 cents a share. New York-based March & McLennan said revenue rose 8% to $3.05 billion from $2.81 billion, helped by results from Mercer and Marsh. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected per-share earnings of 45 cents on revenue of $2.92 billion. Analysts' estimates usually exclude some items. See full story. Owens Corning OC, -2.36% reported a first-quarter loss of $15 million, or 12 cents a share, from a gain of $1 million, or 1 cent a share, in the year-ago period. The Toledo, Ohio-based maker of building materials said sales climbed to $1.35 billion from $1.12 billion last year. Analysts polled by FactSet Research expected, on average, first-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share on sales of $1.2 billion. Pioneer Natural Resources Co.'s PXD, -4.20% first-quarter net income surged to $129.7 million, or $1.09 a share, from $29.6 million, or 24 cents a share, a year ago. Pioneer said 2008 results included a $7 million, or 6 cents a share, refund of Alaskan Petroleum Production Tax credits. The Irving, Texas, energy company said revenue increased to $584.2 million from $367.3 million, while average daily oil and gas sales rose 24% to 110,298 barrels oil equivalent per day. Pitney Bowes Inc. PBI, -1.56% reported a first-quarter profit of $119.1 million, or 56 cents a share, down from $144.8 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding restructuring charges, earnings came to 66 cents a share. Revenue for the postage meter machine maker rose 11% to $1.6 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet Research were looking for earnings, on average, of 65 cents a share on sales of $1.49 billion. The Stamford, Conn.-based company also raised its adjusted 2008 earnings target to a range from $2.80 to $2.90 a share. Wall Street previously forecast a profit of $2.85 a share. Decliners Avis Budget Group Inc. CAR, +0.09% swung to a first-quarter loss of $12 million, or 11 cents a share, from a net income of $13 million, or 12 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue increased to $1.12 billion from $1.08 billion a year earlier. Analysts polled by FactSet Research had forecast earnings of 7 cents a share on average on revenue of $1.38 billion. Avis expects its 2008 revenue to increase over 2007 revenue of $6 billion. Analysts are predicting the company to report revenue of $6.22 billion in 2008. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. BMY, -3.34% reaffirmed its expectation that earnings excluding items from continuing operations will grow at a minimum of 15% compounded annual growth rate, from its 2007 base through 2010. The New York health- and personal-care product maker said its view doesn't include its plans to sell its ConvaTec business unit and other items. In addition, Bristol-Myers said it is evaluating its 2008 forecast and isn't reaffirming it at this time. Bristol said it will update its 2008 earnings guidance by the end of the second quarter. Cisco Systems Inc. CSCO, -4.33% reported third-quarter net income of $1.77 billion, or 29 cents a share, compared with net profit of $1.87 billion, or 30 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Revenue was $9.79 billion, up from $8.87 billion. Adjusted income was 38 cents a share. Analysts expected Cisco to report earnings of 36 cents a share on revenue of $9.74 billion, according to a consensus survey by FactSet Research. See full story. Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp. CTSH, -2.04% said its first-quarter profit totaled $102 million, or 34 cents per share, from $75 million, or 25 cents per share, in the same quarter a year before. The result compared with 33 cents per share analysts had expected, according to a FactSet Research survey. Revenue for the quarter totaled $643 million compared to $460 million in the year-ago quarter. The Teaneck, N.J. company said that second-quarter revenue should "be at least $680 million," with earnings for the quarter seen between 34 cents and 35 cents. Devon Energy Corp.'s DVN, -5.47% first-quarter net income increased 15% to $749 million, or $1.66 a share, from $651 million, or $1.44 a share, a year earlier, due in part to increased oil and gas production and higher prices for oil, gas and natural-gas liquids. Excluding items, earnings were $2.74 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected, on average, earnings of $2.33 a share. Analysts' estimates usually exclude items. The Oklahoma City company said revenue increased 20% to $2.98 billion from $2.47 billion the previous year. Harman International Industries Inc. HAR, +4.17% swung to a fiscal third-quarter loss of $3.3 million, or 6 cents a share. A year ago, it earned $71 million, or $1.07 a share. Harman said sales rose to $1 billion, from $883 million in the year-earlier period. Hospira Inc. HSP, +0.18% said it swung to a first-quarter profit of $65.4 million, or 41 cents a share, from a loss of $29.4 million, or 19 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted net income fell to 55 cents a share from 59 cents a share. Net sales rose 13.5% to $888.7 million from $782.8 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet Research forecast earnings of 55 cents a share, on average. The Lake Forest, Ill. pharmaceutical and medication delivery company said it still expects adjusted 2008 earnings of $2.45 to $2.55 a share, compared to the Wall Street target of $2.50 a share. Billionaire investor Carl Icahn on Wednesday reported raising his stake in Motorola Inc. MSI, -1.50% to 7.6% from 6.4%. Icahn beneficially owns about 172.18 million shares of the Schaumburg, Ill., cellphone maker, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Icahn previously reported holding about 144.56 million Motorola shares in late March. RF Micro Devices Inc. RFMD swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of $16.5 million, or 6 cents a share, from a year-earlier profit of $30.1 million, or 14 cents a share, as the company announced a restructuring program under which 350 employees will be let go. Excluding certain items, earnings for the latest quarter were 1 cent a share, compared with 13 cents a share a year earlier. The Greensboro, N.C., mobile communications company said revenue for the latest quarter fell 14% to $221.9 million from $257.3 million a year ago. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 1 cent on revenue of $222 million. For the fiscal first-quarter, RF Micro expects a loss of 3 cents to 4 cents a share on revenue of $230 million to $245 million. THQ Inc. THQI swung to a loss for its fourth fiscal quarter of $34.5 million, or 52 cents a share, compared to net income of $6.5 million, or 9 cents a share, for the same period last year. Excluding certain charges, the company said net losses would have come in at 37 cents a share. Revenue grew 8.6% to $187 million. The company said revenue would have totaled $217.6 million were it not for the impact of deferred revenue from "Frontlines: Fuel of War." Analysts were expecting a loss of 4 cents a share on revenue of $200.4 million, according to estimates from FactSet Research. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau 2 sexy ways to get paid to save My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Wednesday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Wednesday's session are Limited Brands Inc., Salesforce.com Inc., and Nortel Networks Corp. Limited Brands LTD, +0.52% is forecast to post earnings of 93 cents a share in the fourth-quarter, according to analysts surveyed by FactSet Research. Salesforce.com CRM, -1.62% is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 4 cents a share. Nortel Networks NT is forecast to post earnings of 45 cents a share in the fourth-quarter. Dollar Tree Stores Inc. DLTR, -1.21% is projected to post a fourth-quarter profit of $1.02 a share. Dress Barn Inc. ASNA, +1.00% is estimated to report a profit of 8 cents a share in the fiscal second quarter. Dynegy Inc. DYN, -2.59% is estimated to report a profit of 2 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Petrohawk Energy Corp. HK, -4.11% is likely to report a fourth-quarter profit of 15 cents a share according to analyst estimates. McDermott International Inc. MDR, -5.81% is expected to report earnings of 66 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Magna International Inc. MGA, -3.67% is projected to post a fourth-quarter profit of $1.64 a share. Noble Energy Inc. NBL, -5.45% is expected to report earnings of $1.55 a share in the fourth quarter. Owens Corning Inc. OC, -2.77% is likely to report a fourth-quarter profit of 19 cents a share according to analyst estimates. MetroPCS Communications Inc. PCS is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 12 cents a share. Mylan Laboratories Inc. MYL, -4.15% is likely to report a fiscal third-quarter profit of 8 cents a share. Public Storage PSA, -0.41% is estimated to report a profit of 26 cents a share in the fourth quarter. RR Donnelley & Sons Co. RRD, -6.41% is forecast to post earnings of 71 cents a share in the fourth-quarter. SPX Corp. SPW, -4.73% is expected to report earnings of $1.67 a share in the fourth quarter. Toll Brothers Inc. TOL, -4.12% is forecast to post a loss of 50 cents a share in the fiscal first-quarter. URS Corp. URS, +1.00% is projected to post a fourth-quarter profit of 55 cents a share. Washington Post Co. WPO is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of $8.73 a share, according to analyst estimates. After Tuesday's closing bell, shares of biotech drug maker Amgen Inc. AMGN, -3.53% and health care giant Johnson & Johnson Inc. JNJ, -3.03% fell in the extended session after the Journal of the American Medical Association published a study showing that popular anemia drugs known as erythropoiesis-stimulating agents increased the risk of certain blood clots and death among cancer patients. The study showed that patients treated with such drugs had a 57% higher safety risk. The two companies are the largest suppliers of the drugs. Watch list Allstate Corp. ALL, -2.17% said Chairman Edward Liddy and Chief Financial Officer Dan Hale will retire on April 30 and March 31 respectively. Separately, the Northbrook, Ill., insurance company raised its quarterly dividend to 41 cents from 38 cents and approved a $2 billion share repurchase program. Autodesk Inc. ADSK, -2.55% lowered its first-quarter earnings outlook range to 35 cents to 37 cents a share, with a range of adjusted earnings of 46 cents to 48 cents a share, and analysts expecting 47 cents a share. The company said its fourth-quarter profit rose slightly to $96.5 million, or 40 cents a share, while revenue rose to $599.1 million from $497.4 million. Delta Air Lines DAL, -6.22% Chief Executive Richard Anderson told employees in a memo the airline wouldn't be rushed into reaching a merger agreement with Northwest Airlines NWA according to media reports. In the memo, Anderson also stressed that the seniority of Delta's people "are protected," reports said. DreamWorks Animation SKG Inc. DWA said it swung to a fourth-quarter profit of $94.1 million, or 98 cents a share, with a tax benefit accounting for 7 cents a share in the latest quarter, and revenue rising to $290.2 million. Analysts estimated a quarterly profit of 77 cents a share on revenue of $279.8 million. HealthExtras Inc. HLEX said its fourth-quarter profit rose slightly to $11.6 million, or 27 cents a share, with revenue up to $531.9 million. Analysts estimated a quarterly profit of 27 cents a share on revenue of $534.4 million. The company sees 2008 earnings of $1.17 to $1.25 a share on revenue exceeding $2.5 billion, with analysts estimating an annual profit of $1.23 a share on revenue of $2.49 billion. MBIA Inc. MBI, -4.10% is finished raising significant capital that dilutes the holdings of existing investors in the bond insurer, Chief Executive Jay Brown told CNBC late Tuesday. "We're through raising significant dilutive capital," he said. Later in the interview, Brown added that MBIA may "need a little bit more capital to do one more interesting transaction." Warnaco Group WRNC reported a fourth-quarter profit of $22.9 million, or 49 cents a share, with adjusted earnings from continuing operations of 43 cents a share. Revenue at the New York-based clothing company rose 6% to $473 million. Analysts expected a profit, on average, of 41 cents a share on revenue of $467.7 million. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks in focus for Wednesday

content: (In Fannie Mae item, corrects reference to London interbank offered rate.) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are likely to see active trading Friday are Kellwood and Sirona Dental Systems. Kellwood Co. KWD is expected to report third-quarter earnings of 14 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Sirona Dental Systems Inc. SIRO is forecast to post earnings of 29 cents a share in the fourth quarter. After Thursday's closing bell, UnitedHealth Group Inc. UNH, +1.13% said it has completed its review of past option grants and practices involving several former officers and directors. It said former Chairman and Chief Executive William W. McGuire will surrender $320 million in stock options, in addition to other perks. Combined with the previous repricing of stock options, McGuire will relinquish a total value of $600 million. The company's special litigation committee reached settlement agreements with McGuire, former General Counsel David J. Lubben and former Director William G. Spears. The committee valued the total amounts to be relinquished pursuant to these settlement agreements, together with the value previously and voluntarily relinquished by current and former executives through the surrender and repricing of options, at about $900 million. See full story Watch List American Software Inc. AMSWA, -2.31% said its fiscal second-quarter net income rose to $2.5 million, or 10 cents a share, from $1.8 million, or 7 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue in the quarter totaled $23.6 million, up from $20.2 million in the same period last year. Cascade Corp. CAE, -0.65% reported its net income for the third quarter of fiscal 2008 rose to $12.4 million, or $1 a share, from $12.3 million, or 94 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended Oct. 31 rose 17% to $143.1 million from $122.8 million. Analysts had forecast the company would hand in earnings of $1.08 a share on $139 million in revenue. Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp. CTSH, -2.09% said its board authorized the company to purchase an additional $100 million of stock. The information technology and business process outsourcing services company said the authorization expands the company's share repurchase program to $200 million. Dow Jones & Co. DJ Chief Executive Richard Zannino said he'll step down after News Corp.'s NWS, -3.11% pending acquisition of the company closes, beginning what is expected to be a series of high-level executive changes in connection with the change in ownership. The Wall Street Journal's online edition reported Zannino will be replaced by Les Hinton, News International's executive chairman, and Robert Thomson, editor of News Corp.'s Times of London, is set to be named publisher of the Journal, replacing Gordon Crovitz. See full story Ecolab Inc. ECL, -2.79% said its board increased the company's quarterly cash dividend 13% to 13 cents. The dividend will be paid Jan. 15 to shareholders of record as of Dec. 18. Esterline Technologies Corp.'s ESL, -2.87% fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose to $20.9 million, or 78 cents a share, from $18.4 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier. The aerospace products supplier's sales increased to $370.7 million from $270.3 million. Analysts had expected earnings of 78 cents a share on revenue of $344 million. The company expects 2008 earnings of $3 to $3.20 a share. Fannie Mae FNM, -11.67% said it priced a sale of $7 billion in new shares as the mortgage giant bolsters its capital after subprime-related losses recently. The 280 million non-cumulative perpetual fixed-to-floating rate preferred shares are being sold for $25 each and will be issued on Dec. 11, Fannie said. The stock will have a fixed dividend of 8.25% until the end of 2010. After that, it will pay an annual dividend of the greater of 7.75% or 423 basis points over the 3-month London interbank offered rate, the company said. Forest City Enterprises Inc. FCE.A, -1.68% swung to a third-quarter loss of $10.8 million, or 11 cents a share, from prior-year earnings of $45.9 million, or 45 cents a share, due primarily to large disposition gains in 2006. The real-estate company said revenue rose to $333.6 million from $262.5 million a year ago. Forest City said comparable property net operating income rose 6.9%. Halliburton Co. HAL, -3.50% said it is eliminating the position of chief operating officer to streamline its executive ranks. Andrew Lane, the current COO, will retire effective Dec. 31, the company said. Herley Industries Inc.'s HRLY fiscal first-quarter loss narrowed to $2.59 million, or 19 cents a share, from $6.01 million, or 43 cents a share, in the prior-year period. The microwave technology designer and manufacturer said revenue for the period ended Oct. 29 fell 12% to $35.1 million from $40.1 million last year. Analysts had estimated earnings of 18 cents a share. MBIA Inc. MBI, -4.21% said it is working on a plan to bolster its capital if rating agencies decide the bond insurer needs to set aside extra cash to preserve its crucial AAA rating. The comments are in the wake of Moody's Investors Service remarks Wednesday that MBIA was less likely to have enough capital to maintain its top ratings because of potential mortgage-related losses. See full story National Semiconductor Corp. NSM, -0.39% reported second-quarter income of $90.6 million, or 33 cents per share, for the period ended Nov. 25, compared to $91.4 million, 27 cents, for the year-ago period. The chipmaker reported revenue of $499 million, compared to $501.6 million for the same period last year. Analysts had expected the company to report earnings 31 cents a share on revenue of $498.4 million. National Semiconductor said it expects third-quarter sales to decline 1% to 5% from the second quarter. Optium Corp. OPTM said it swung to a fiscal first-quarter loss of $1.1 million, or 4 cents a share, from prior-year net earnings of $2.8 million, or 13 cents a share. The optical subsystems supplier said revenues for the period ended Nov. 3 rose 20% to $36.1 million from $30 million a year ago, boosted in part by higher sales of its new product lines. Optium expects its second-quarter revenue for the period ending Feb. 2 to be $38 million to $39 million. Owens Corning OC, -2.61% said Mike Thaman assumed primary executive responsibility as chairman, president and chief executive. Thaman succeeds Dave Brown, who retired as a director and officer of Owens Corning on Dec. 6. Palm Inc. PALM, +0.00% said it expects a second-quarter loss of 22 cents to 24 cents a share and adjusted loss of 8 cents to 10 cents a share. The handheld devices company cut its revenue forecast for the period to $345 million and $350 million from its previously stated guidance of $370 million to $380 million. The expected shortfall is primarily due to a shipping delay. Analysts had expected second-quarter adjusted earnings of 4 cents a share and revenue of $376 million. Prudential Financial Inc. PRU, -3.46% will offer $3 billion in convertible senior notes due 2037. The life insurance firm has granted the initial purchaser of the notes an over-allotment option to buy up to an additional $450 million worth in notes. The company will use the offering to fund operating needs and to buy short short-term investment grade fixed-income investments. Gunmaker Smith & Wesson Holding Corp. SWHC posted a second-quarter profit of $2.94 million, or 7 cents a share, up slightly from $2.85 million, or 7 cents a share, a year ago. Sales jumped to $70.8 million from $50.8 million a year earlier helped by an acquisition and strong demand for the company's firearms from law enforcement. Analysts had expected a profit, on average, of 6 cents a share on sales of $69.5 million. Source Interlink Cos. SORC swung to a third-quarter loss of $4.46 million, or 9 cents a share, from a profit of $4.83 million, or 9 cents a share in the year-ago period. The information and management services company said adjusted income from continuing operations was $12.6 million, or 24 cents a share. Revenue grew 37% to $639.1 million from $467.9 million a year earlier. Analysts had projected earnings of 6 cents a share on revenue of $629.4 million. Synopsys Inc. SNPS, -3.04% said its net profit surged more than 300% for its fourth fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31. The maker of software used in the design of semiconductors reported earnings of $41 million, or 27 cents a share, compared to earnings of $10.1 million, or 7 cents per share, for the same period last year. Revenue grew 11% to $315.2 million. Analysts were expecting earnings of 36 cents a share on revenue of $308.2 million. Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. WPI, +3.53% said it settled a patent dispute with Novartis AG NVS, -1.56% on the Alzheimer's drug Exelon. Under the agreement, Watson was granted a license to its U.S. patents covering Exelon for a generic version of it. Watson won't start marketing the general equivalent of the drug until sometime prior to the expiration of the patents covering Exelon. Watson's new drug application for the generic version has been tentatively approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Yum Brands Inc. YUM, -2.06% said it expects earnings growth of at least 10% for the 2008. The company said also said it expects the expansion of its U.S. refranchising to bring company ownership to below 10% by year-end 2010 from approximately 20% at year-end 2007. Revenue in the U.S. are also expected to be flat as a result of refranchising activity during 2007 and 2008, said the company, adding this will negatively impact 2008 revenue growth by at least four percentage points. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: CORRECT: Stocks in focus for Friday

content: Con Edison profits rise 35% on rate increases (5:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Consolidated Edison Inc. ED, -1.09% the power company that serves most of New York City, reported late Thursday third-quarter net income rose to $312 million, or $1.15 a share, from $231 million, or 92 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose nearly 6% to $3.6 billion from $3.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast the utility would earn $1.06 a share on $3.51 billion in revenue. Shares fell 1.7% to close at $46.27 ahead of the report. CORRECT--Napster cuts loss to $5.1 million as sales rise 24% (4:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Napster Inc. NAPS, +0.00% on Thursday reported a second-quarter loss of $5.1 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with a loss of $9 million, or 21 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the digital-music service provider rose 24% to $31.6 million from the same period last year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast Napster to lose 15 cents a share on $30 million in revenue. Napster said it ended the quarter with about 750,000 paid subscribers, down from 770,000 in its fiscal first quarter. Going forward, Napster expects to report third-quarter sales of $33 million. (This corrects an earlier version which reported too many paid subscribers for Napster's quarter.) CBS CEO: 'No material impact' foreseen if writers strike (4:48 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- CBS Corp. Chief Executive Les Moonves told analysts Thursday that the company foresees "no material impact" on its financials should there be a strike by Hollywood screenwriters. Moonves, speaking following CBS's CBS, -1.75% release of third-quarter results, said the network has "a full slate" of programming "ready to go" should the Writers Guild of America stage a walkout, as many observers expect, possibly as early as Friday. Moonves added that CBS's slate of comedies repeats "extremely well." Las Vegas Sands swings to third-quarter loss (4:38 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Las Vegas Sands Corp.
