LVS, -1.89% had a third-quarter loss of $48.5 million, or 14 cents a share, for the period ended Sept. 30, the company said after the close Thursday. A year ago, the Las Vegas-based resort operator reported net income of $97.3 million, or 27 cents a share. Sales were $694.3 million vs. last year's $578.9 million. Excluding various charges, the company would have reported earnings of $41.8 million, or 12 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 31 cents a share on sales of $783 million. Shares ended trading Thursday down $7.78, or 5.9%, to $125.30. After hours, the stock dropped another 17% to $104.07. Napster cuts loss to $5.1 million as sales rise 24% (4:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Napster Inc. NAPS, +0.00% on Thursday reported a second-quarter loss of $5.1 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with a loss of $9 million, or 21 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the digital-music service provider rose 24% to $31.6 million from the same period last year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast Napster to lose 15 cents a share on $30 million in revenue. Napster said it ended the quarter with about 755,000 paid subscribers, down from 770,000 in its fiscal first quarter. Going forward, Napster expects to report third-quarter sales of $33 million. Electronic Arts swings to a loss on accounting change (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Electronic Arts Inc. swung to a loss for its second fiscal quarter due to a change in how it accounts for revenue from sales of certain types of video games. For the period ended Sept. 30, the video game publisher ERTS reported a loss of $195 million, or 62 cents a share, compared to earnings of $22 million, or 7 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue slipped to $640 million from $784 million. The company said the accounting change resulted in a $296 million increase in deferred net revenue that will be recognized in future periods. Analysts were expecting earnings of 20 cents a share on revenue of $896.2 million, according to data from Thomson Financial. ACS reports 8 percent increase in first-quarter profit (4:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCSICO (MarketWatch) - Affiliated Computer Services reported net income of $66.1 million on revenue of $1.49 billion for the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared to a profit of $61.4 million on revenue of $1.38 billion for the same period last year. The company also reported an adjusted non-GAAP earnings per share of 77 cents. Analysts had expected the company to report earnings per share of 84 cents on revenue of $1.49 billion. Leapfrog Enterprises narrows loss on higher toy margins (4:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Leapfrog Enterprises Inc. LF a maker of technology-based learning toys, late Thursday reported a narrower third-quarter loss on declining sales. Leapfrog reported a net loss of $2.8 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $49.7 million, or 79 cents a share, in last year's same period. For the three months ended Sept. 30, Leapfrog said sales fell 22% to $144 million due to fewer sales of toys the company is phasing out. On a brighter note, the company said its gross margin improved to 42.2% of sales vs. 26.6%, helped by lower charges for excess and obsolete inventory and purchase-order cancellations. Looking ahead, Leapfrog said it 2007 revenue will be 10% to 15% below 2006. It estimates a significant improvement in gross margin and net losses. CBS profit rises 8.3% (4:11 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- CBS Corp. reported a higher third-quarter profit on Thursday even as revenue decreased. The New York-based media conglomerate CBS, -1.75% said it earned $343.3 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with a profit of $316.9 million, or 42 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Revenue slipped 3% to $3.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had, on average, been expecting CBS to post a profit of 43 cents as share on revenue of $3.33 billion. In 2007, CBS expects revenue to fall 2-3%, reflecting the divestiture of "lower-margin, slower-growth assets" including 39 radio stations, nine television stations, UPN, and the non- renewal of several of its urban outdoor transit contracts. GlobalSantaFe Corp. up 3% after earnings (2:31 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- GlobalSantaFe Corp. GSF, +0.28% shares rose 3% to $83.37 in recent trades on the heels of its earnings update after the bell on Wednesday. Robert Van Batenburg of Louis Capital Markets said in a note to clients said the oil service firm turned in "blow out results" amid rising remand for its deep-water business and a slight uptick in bidding for Gulf of Mexico work in the last four weeks. Rowan's third-quarter income rises 50% (9:47 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Rowan Cos. RDC, -3.86% the Houston provider of contract energy-drilling services, reported third-quarter net income rose 50% on 20% higher revenue. Profit was $130.8 million, or $1.16 a share, compared with $87 million, or 78 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. The earnings reflected gains on asset sales of 1 cent a share in the latest period and 2 cents a year earlier. The year-ago number also included 1 cent of profit from discontinued operations. Revenue reached $502.2 million from $417.1 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of $1.14 of profit on $530 million of revenue. Rowan's offshore- rig utilization was 99% during the third quarter of 2007, up from 91% in third-quarter 2006, with the day rate up 8% to $11,400. Rowan's land-rig utilization was 96% during the quarter, down from 98% a year ago. Administaff profit edges higher (9:38 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Administaff Inc. said Thursday that its third-quarter profit grew modestly on greater use of its human resource services by small and medium-sized businesses across the U.S. The Houston-based firm NSP, -2.80% said net income was $12.2 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with a prior-year profit of $12.1 million, or 43 cents a share. Revenue rose 13.3% to $383.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a profit of 43 cents a share on revenue of $382.1 million. Energy shares fall as Exxon Mobil weighs on sector (9:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Energy shares fell Thursday as lower-than-expected earnings from sector giant Exxon Mobil XOM, -3.06% weighed. Exxon Mobil fell 2.4% to $89.77 in early trades. The Amex Oil Index XOI, -2.86% dropped 0.8% to 1,484. The Amex Natural Gas Index XNG, -3.78% dropped 0.8% to 569. Tesoro TSO, +0.00% fell 3.4% to $58.48 after its earnings update. Sunoco SUN, -1.92% gave up 4% to $70.55 after its profit report. Marathon Oil MRO, -4.84% dipped 22 cents to $58.91. Williams WMB, -1.89% rose 25 cents to $36.74. Washington Post reports lower third-quarter income (9:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Washington Post Co.'s WPO third-quarter earnings fell to $72.5 million from $73.3 million, a year earlier. On a per-share basis, earnings for the quarter were unchanged from the year-ago period at $7.60 a share. The company said results for the most recent quarter included a 62 cents a share gain from the sale of property at its television station in Miami. In addition, the Washington publisher said revenue rose to $1.02 billion from $946.9 million, boosted by higher test preparation revenue, and strong growth in its education and cable television divisions. CenturyTel reports higher third-quarter earnings (9:23 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- CenturyTel CTL, -0.91% the Monroe, La., provider of communications, high-speed Internet and entertainment services, reported third-quarter earnings were up 48% on 14% higher revenue. Earnings reached $113.2 million, or $1.01 a share, from $76.3 million, or 64 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were 97 cents a share compared with 66 cents. Revenue reached $708.3 million from $619.8 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 89 cents of profit on $682 million of revenue. PG&E profit drops 29% after year-ago gains (9:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Utility PG&E Corp. PGE, +2.44% said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit fell 29% to $278 million, or 77 cents a share, from $393 million, or $1.09 a share, a year earlier. Total operating revenue for the period rose 3.5% to $3.28 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 86 cents a share on revenue of $3.5 billion. The company said the result leaves it on track to meet expectations of earnings in the upper half of its guidance range of $2.70 to $2.80 per share. The drop in earnings from a year ago was mainly due to several one-off gains in the year-ago quarter. The company also reaffirmed its guidance for 2008 earnings of $2.90 to $3 a share. Sempra Energy's third-quarter earnings decline (9:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sempra Energy SRE, -1.28% said Thursday that its third-quarter net income fell to $305 million, or $1.15 a share, from $653 million, or $2.49 a share in the year-earlier period, which included $1.21 a share in gains. Earnings from continuing operations were $1.24 a share. Revenue declined slightly to $2.66 billion from $2.69 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of $1.03 a share and revenue of $2.84 billion, on average. Sempra Energy also said it expects to report full-year earnings of more than $4 a share, compared to previous guidance of $3.75 to $3.95. Analysts are expecting $3.95 a share in earnings for 2007. Analyst praises Exxon's overseas refining and marketing (9:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Lehman Brothers analyst Paul Cheng on Thursday said in a note to clients that Exxon Mobil's XOM, -3.06% results, "will have a slightly negative impact on the stock due to lower than expected oil and gas production volume as well as slightly lower than consensus earnings." He said it's unclear if there are any "one off" operating items included in the result such as assets sales gain, foreign exchange, or inventory gain/(loss) since the oil giant does not break out these items as specials. Exxon Mobil beat his target of $1.67 a share with earnings of $1.70 a share, "primarily driven by a better than expected international refining and marketing results." Mylan reports higher profit, helped by Matrix acquisition (9:11 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Mylan Inc. MYL, -4.18% reported higher fiscal second-quarter earnings early Thursday, due largely to the recent acquisition of Matrix. For the quarter, Mylan posted net income of $149.8 million, or 60 cents a share, compared with $77.5 million, or 36 cents a share, for the same period last year. Excluding various charges, Mylan would have reported adjusted earnings of 31 cents a share. Revenue jumped to $477.1 million, from $366.7 million. A poll of analysts by Thomson Financial saw the generic drugmaker posting adjusted earnings of 25 cents a share, on revenue of $471 million. Lawsuits drive Health Net to loss (9:06 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- The settlement of a trio of class-action lawsuits drove Health Net deep into the red in the third quarter, the HMO said Thursday. Health Net HNT, +0.00% reported a loss of $103.8 million, or 93 cents a share, on the period -- a turn from a profit of $90.9 million, or 76 cents a share, in the same quarter of 2006. Included in the latest numbers is the impact of $296.8 million in pretax charges from its agreement to settle the suits, along with a proposed resolution of regulatory problems with the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance and various other litigation matters. FTI Consulting swings to a gain (9:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- FTI Consulting Inc. FCN, -0.85% said Thursday its third-quarter net income rose to $22.9 million, or 50 cents a share, from a loss of $286,000, or a penny a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $253.3 million from $162 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 48 cents a share and revenue of $237.3 million, on average. Rite Aid October same-store sales inch higher (8:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Drugstore operator Rite Aid Corp. RAD, -2.68% on Thursday said October same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least one year, rose 0.4%. Pharmacy same-store sales increased 1.3%, which included a negative impact of about 429 basis points from new generic introductions. Front-end same-store sales, which include general merchandise, fell 1.4%. For the four weeks ended Oct. 27, total drugstore sales rose 50.7% to $1.99 billion compared to $1.32 billion for the same period last year. Prescription revenue accounted for 69% of drugstore sales, and third party prescription revenue represented about 96% of pharmacy sales. Total sales include all of the stores operated during the period, including stores acquired in the Brooks Eckerd acquisition on June 4, while same-store sales figures exclude these acquired operations. Regal Beloit's third-quarter earnings rise (8:57 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Regal Beloit Corp. RBC, -4.36% said Thursday its third-quarter profit rose to $31.2 million, or 92 cents a share, from $29.7 million, or 89 cents per share, in the year-earlier quarter. A Thomson Financial poll of analysts had predicted earnings of 92 cents a share. The Beloit, Wisc.-based maker of power-generation products said net sales increased to $449.4 million from $419.3 million the year before. It forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 67 to 74 cents a share. PSEG net income rises 35% (8:56 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Public Service Enterprise Group PEG, -1.13% on Thursday said third-quarter net income rose to $506 million, or $1.99 a share from $374 million, or $1.48 a share in the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations rose to $500 million, or $1.97 a share, from $372 million, or $1.47 a share. Excluding an item, operating earnings for the latest period rose to $2 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of $1.81 a share, on average. The Newark, N.J. utility increased its 2007 earnings forecast to $5.15-$5.45 a share, from $4.90-$5.30 a share. Dominion third-quarter income more than triples (8:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dominion Resources Inc.'s D, -0.85% third-quarter income more than tripled to $2.32 billion, or $7.24 a share, from $654 million, or $1.85 a share, a year earlier. Operating earnings, which, in the most recent period, excluded items such as a a $1.4 billion net benefit from the sale of a unit, were $1.72 a share, compared to $1.88 a share in the year-earlier period. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of $1.70 a share and revenue of $3.64 billion. The Richmond, Va., utility holding company said operating revenue fell 10% to $3.59 billion from $3.97 billion a year ago. The company increased its quarterly common stock dividend rate 11% to 79 cents per share and set a policy to achieve a 2010 payout ratio of 55%. Dominion also said it is "well positioned" to achieve its operating earnings forecast of $6.10 to $6.25 per share next year. Radian swings to 3rd-quarter loss on negative net revenue (8:38 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Radian Group Inc., RDN, -2.34% the Philadelphia credit-risk-management company, swung to a third-quarter loss from a year-earlier profit on negative total revenue. The loss totaled $703.9 million, or $8.78 a share, compared with net income of $112 million, or $1.36, in the year-earlier period. The total revenue figure was a negative $104.4 million compared with a positive $321.8 million. The negative revenue reflected a change in the fair value of derivatives of a negative $643.9 million. Despite the loss, Radian's book value is $42.86 a share "and we are well positioned with our strong capital and liquidity position to weather the challenging credit cycle," Chief Executive S.A. Ibrahim said in a statement. "While mortgage-insurance credit losses will continue to impact our results for the foreseeable future, I'm encouraged by the positive trends in mortgage insurance penetration and by the resiliency of our financial guaranty business." Progress Energy reports flat third-quarter earnings (8:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Progress Energy Inc.'s PGN, -0.73% third-quarter earnings remained flat at $319 million, as revenue rose 12%. On a per-share basis, earnings decreased to $1.24 from $1.27 a year ago, as the number of average weighted shares outstanding rose. The energy company said third-quarter ongoing earnings rose to $1.14 a share from $1.09 last year, helped by favorable weather, lower income taxes at the core businesses and increased wholesale sales. Core ongoing earnings for the third quarter, which exclude ongoing earnings from the coal and synthetic fuels operations, rose to $1.21 a share from $1.06 a share a year earlier. Revenue for the full year rose to $3.1 billion from $2.78 billion a year ago. For the full year, the company reaffirmed its core ongoing earnings view of $2.70 to $2.90 a share. Blockbuster posts wider third-quarter loss (8:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Blockbuster Inc.'s BBI, -5.13% third-quarter net loss widened to $35 million, or 20 cents a share, from a year-earlier loss of $24.7 million, or 15 cents a share. The Dallas video retail chain said revenue fell 5.7% to $1.24 billion from $1.31 billion a year ago, due to the closure and sale of 526 company-operated stores worldwide. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected a loss of 18 cents a share and revenue of $1.28 billion. Worldwide same-store rental revenues for the period were up 1.1% from the year-ago period. The company has implemented a plan to reduce annual overhead costs by about $45 million through the elimination of "staffing and operational redundancies and through improvements in other operating efficiencies." Blockbuster also said it will concentrate on the growth of its total membership, as opposed to only its online subscriber count. Morningstar's net income rises 47% (8:09 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Investment research firm Morningstar Inc. MORN, -1.48% Thursday said its third-quarter profit rose to $19.9 million, or 41 cents a share, from $13.5 million, or 29 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Chicago-based company's revenue rose to $111.9 million from $81.8 million a year earlier. Quarterly results included $10.2 million in revenue from acquisitions over the past year, Morningstar said. Assets under management in its investment-consulting business climbed to $91.4 billion from $47.6 billion the prior year. More than 20% of revenue is coming from outside the U.S., said Chief Executive Joe Mansueto in a statement. The stock closed Wednesday up 1.9% to $74.42. International Game Technology fourth-quarter income rises (8:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- International Game Technology IGT, -2.54% said Thursday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose to $122.6 million, or 38 cents a share from a year-ago $114.9 million, or 33 cents a share. Revenue increased in the latest three months to $353.3 million from $333.8 million in the year-earlier period. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 38 cents a share. The stock closed Wednesday at $43.61. Smith & Nephew profit drops 86% after charges (7:58 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Medical technology group Smith & Nephew(UK:SN) SNN, -1.52% said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit fell 86% to $13 million, or 1.6 cents a share, from $92 million, or 9.8 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the period rose 24% to $845 million. Trading profit, which excludes restructuring, acquisition and legal costs, rose 28% to $169 million. "Trading conditions across the business continue to be characterised by good volume growth tempered by a tight pricing environment in some geographies," Smith & Nephew said. Shares in the group fell 3.5% in London trading. Williams net income nearly doubles; sets 2008 profit range (7:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Williams Companies Inc. WMB, -1.89% on Thursday said third-quarter net income nearly doubled to $198 million, or 33 cents a share, from $106.2 million, or 18 cents a share in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 38 cents a share, on average. Williams boosted its 2008 segment profit target for exploration and production to $1 billion to $1.3 billion from $950 million to $1.25 billion. "Higher expected net realized prices and production volumes, partially offset by higher costs, are the factors driving the increase," the company said. For 2008, it sees profit of $1.50 to $1.90 a share, compared to the analyst target of $1.81 a share. Separately, Williams Partners L.P. WPZ, -1.92% said it'll pay $750 million to buy from Williams Companies a membership interest in the limited liability company that owns the Wamsutter systems. Cameron Int'l 3rd-quarter net up 69% on 21% higher revenue (7:46 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Cameron International Corp., CAM, -1.67% the Houston provider of flow equipment products, systems and services to worldwide oil, gas and process industries, reported that third-quarter net income rose 69% on 21% higher revenue. Earnings reached $150.7 million, or $1.31 a share, from $89.3 million, or 78 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were $1.14 against 80 cents. Revenue rose to $1.19 billion from $978.8 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of $1.09 of profit on $1.21 billion of revenue. At Sept. 30, the backlog totaled $4.13 billion, up 4% from the end of the second quarter and up 22% from the end of third-quarter 2006. Cameron estimates earnings for 2007 at$4.24 to $4.27 a share. Thomson's estimate is $4.17. Cameron also reduced the amount of pre-tax charges it expects to record for its plan to end its pension plan to $67 million from $85 million. It will take the charges from the fourth quarter of 2007 through the first quarter of 2009. It will need to add $10 million to $15 million to the plan in late 2008 or early 2009. Owens Corning posts profit, sees weak U.S. housing market (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Owens Corning OC, -2.59% on Thursday reported third-quarter net income of $112 million, or 86 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, it earned 40 cents a share. Net sales fell to $1.27 billion from $1.39 billion. The Toledo, Ohio-based company, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, said third-quarter results reflected continued weakness of the U.S. new residential construction market, partially offset by stronger global markets in its composites business. As part of Owens Corning's annual operations planning, the company said it is evaluating various cost-reduction projects to deliver significant savings in operating and corporate costs. These projects include capacity and job cuts, elimination of operational costs, and reduced general corporate expenses. Some of these cost-reduction projects have begun, Owens Corning said. The majority of the projects are expected to be completed by the end of the fourth quarter, resulting in a leaner cost structure that better positions the company to compete in a weaker housing market in 2008. This cost-reduction initiative is intended to reduce company-wide operating costs by about $100 million. The company no longer believes that it will surpass its earlier EBIT guidance from continuing operations of $365 million. Based on the deeper and prolonged weakness in demand for building materials in the U.S., the company now believes $335 million is a more appropriate estimate for 2007 adjusted EBIT from continuing operations. Timberland profit, sales slip; sees soft market conditions (7:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Timberland Co. TBL, +0.00% on Thursday said third-quarter net income fell to $25.9 million, or 42 cents a share, from $55.6 million, or 88 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding restructuring costs mostly related to the company's decision to close certain retail locations, it earned 49 cents a share. Revenue fell to $433.3 million from $503 million. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 49 cents a share on revenue of $437 million, according to Thomson Financial. For the fourth quarter, Timberland anticipates revenue declines in the mid-single digit range reflecting soft market conditions in the U.S. and Europe and operating margin declines in the range of 200 basis points, excluding restructuring costs. For 2008, Timberland is targeting mid-single digit first half revenue declines and improved operating results. The footwear and apparel maker expects soft market trends will be offset by its "efforts to drive operational efficiencies" and its decision to close about 50 retail stores by the end of the first quarter of 2008. The company also said it would realign its U.S sales team and global product development organization to "eliminate redundancies and improve efficiencies." Eastman Kodak back to profit, while sales slip (7:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Kodak Co. EK on Thursday reported third-quarter net income of $37 million, or 13 cents a share, swinging from a net loss of $37 million, or 13 cents a share, for the same period last year. In its quarterly report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Rochester, N.Y., camera and film company said its net sales for the period ended Sept. 30 totaled $2.58 billion, slightly lower than the $2.6 billion reported for the third quarter of 2006. Kodak also said earnings from continuing operations swung to $29 million, or 12 cents a share, from a loss of $53 million, or 29 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 27 cents a share. Nymex Holdings net income rises 54% (7:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Nymex Holdings Inc. NMX, -3.79% said Thursday third-quarter net income rose 54% to $62.57 million, or 66 cents a share, from $40.7 million, or 47 cents a share. Revenue rose to $173.2 million from $138.3 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 64 cents a share and revenue of $171.4 million, on average. The parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange OK'd a special dividend of $100 million and set plans for a work force reduction of 120 people over the next five quarters. It also hired Cushman & Wakefield to evaluate a sale of its headquarters in Lower Manhattan. MarineMax 4th-quarter net off 47% on 1.7% lower revenue (7:12 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- MarineMax Inc., HZO, -3.21% the Clearwater, Fla., recreational-boat retailer, reported fiscal fourth-quarter fell 47% on 1.7% lower revenue. Earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30 were $6.6 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with $12.6 million, or 66 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell to $318.2 million from $323.6 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 20 cents of profit on $305 million of revenue. Same-store sales fell 1% for the quarter. MarineMax said that "visibility is limited but industry data suggests that retail sales have not improved." For fiscal 2008, MarineMax estimates earnings per share of 60 cents to 80 cents on a decline in the low sing-digits percent in same-store sales. Thomson's survey is looking for 77 cents. Amerisource Bergen net income falls 28% (7:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Amerisource Bergen ABC, -4.55% on Thursday said net income fell 28% to $87.6 million, or 50 cents a share, from $122 million, or 61 cents a share for its fourth-quarter ended Sept. 30. The Valley Forge, Pa. pharmacy services firm said revenue rose 5% to $16.39 billion. Earnings from continuing operations were 63 cents a share, which included a write-down of 10 cents a share for the market value of its tetanus-diphtheria vaccine inventory and a benefit of 3 cents a share from special items. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 64 cents a share and revenue of $16.47 billion, on average. The company forecast 2008 earnings of $2.77 to $2.95 a share, compared to the analyst target of $2.88 a share. I2 profit up 17%, plans review of strategic options (7:09 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Supply chain company i2 Technologies Inc. ITWO said Thursday that its third-quarter profit rose 17% to $5.3 million, or 17 cents a share, as it also revealed a strategic review of options, including the possible sale of the group. Revenue slipped 7% to $66.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 12 cents a share on revenue of $64 million. The group said it's formed a committee of independent directors to consider different strategic options. It added the review is expected to conclude at the end of January. The company said it expects earnings for the year in the range of 55 cents to 65 cents a share. Alliant Techsystems net up 28%, lifts FY view (7:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Alliant Techsystems ATK reported second-quarter net income rose 28% to $51.2 million, or $1.44 a share, and increased its guidance for the year. Sales rose 24% to $1.03 billion during the quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of $1.39 a share. For the year, it expects earnings between $6.20 and $6.30 a share, including the 9-cent charge taken in the quarter for the write-off of debt issuance, which is 5 cents a share better than a previous forecast. Sales are now seen above $4.1 billion, from a previous view of $4 billion to $4.1 billion at the Minneapolis weapons and space systems maker. Myriad Genetics narrows loss, says CFO to leave (7:02 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Myriad Genetics Inc., MYGN, -1.90% the Salt Lake City biotech company, narrowed its third-quarter loss on 44% higher revenue. The net loss was $8 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with $12.4 million, or 31 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $48.3 million from $33.5 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call estimated a loss of 23 cents a share on revenue of $48 million. Iinitial sales of the company's newest product, TheraGuide 5-FU, are "encouraging," Myriad Genetics said. The company also said Chief Financial Officer Jay Moyes decided to retire "to pursue his passion -- race car driving." Jim Evans, currently vice president of finance, succeeds Moyes as CFO. Capella Education net up 70% as enrollment grows (6:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Capella Education CPLA, -1.60% said third-quarter net income rose 70% to $5.1 million, or 29 cents a share, with revenue up 26% to $55.5 million as enrollment increased 23.8%. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 26 cents a share on revenue of $54 million. For the fourth quarter, it expects enrollment up 22.5% to 23.5%, revenue up 25.3% to 26.3% and operating margins between 18% and 19%. Oshkosh profit jumps 74% following acquisition (6:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oshkosh Truck Corp OSK, -3.86% said Thursday that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 74% to $85.4 million, or $1.14 a share, from $49.2 million, or 66 cents a share, a year ago. Net sales rose 98% to $1.79 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of $1.07 a share on revenue of $1.85 billion. Revenue growth was due to the acquisition of JLG Industries, which contributed $840 million of sales, as well as further growth from its defense business. Oshkosh also reaffirmed its guidance for 2008 earnings of $4.15 to $4.35 a share. EDO 3rd-quarter net jumped on 39% higher revenue (6:40 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- EDO Corp., EDO the New York developer of solutions for defense electronics, communications and other applications, reported that third-quarter net income jumped on 39% higher revenue. Profit reached $11.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from $2.1 million, or 11 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted for tax benefits, the latest earnings were 30 cents a share against break-even a year earlier. Sales rose to $256.8 million from $184.4 million. Revenue excluding acquisitions rose 13%. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 39 cents of profit on $267 million of revenue. EDO has agreed to be acquired by ITT Corp. ITT, -3.39% for $56 a share. EDO shares closed on Wednesday at $58. Hornbeck profit climbs 21% (6:27 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Hornbeck Offshore Services Inc. HOS, -7.22% said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit rose 21% to $28.9 million, or $1.09 a share, from $23.9 million, or 86 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter rose 22% to $94.7 million. The company, which provides offshore supply vessels, said revenue was boosted by the contribution of recently acquired and newly constructed vessels. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of 83 cents a share on revenue of $89 million. Hornbeck said it now expects earnings for the year in the range of $3.28 to $3.52 a share. Genesee & Wyoming returns to profit in third quarter (6:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Genesee & Wyoming GWR, -3.25% said it posted a third-quarter profit of $16.2 million, or 42 cents a share, with revenue up 8% to $131 million. The company lost $12.1 million, or 29 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. The owner and operator of short line and regional freight railroads earned 43 cents a share from continuing operations when excluding asset sales and tax benefits. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of 40 cents a share. "In light of the difficult freight environment, we are generally pleased with our third quarter financial results," said GWI Chief Executive Officer John C. Hellmann. PharmaNet swings to profit (6:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- PharmaNet Development Group Inc. PDGI said Thursday that it swung to a third-quarter net profit of $6.8 million, or 36 cents a share, from a loss of $0.3 million, or a penny a share, a year earlier. Total revenue for the quarter rose 20.5% to $124.4 million. Earnings from continuing operations were 37 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 30 cents a share. The company, which provides drug development services to the pharmaceutical sector, also said its backlog rose to $472.5 million at the end of the quarter from $444 million at the end of the second quarter. The group cuts its earnings guidance for the year to a range of 53 cents to 59 cents from a range of 58 cents to 64 cents. But it also raised its guidance for adjusted earnings to a range of $1.22 to $1.29 a share from a range of $1.12 to $1.24 a share. Randgold 3rd-quarter net off 9.5% on 12% higher gold sales (6:13 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Randgold Resources Ltd., GOLD, +2.41% (UK:RRS)the London gold miner, reported third-quarter net income fell 9.5% on 12% higher gold sales. Earnings were $11.5 million against $12.7 million in the year-earlier period. Pretax profit was flat at $18.3 million. Gold sales reached $70.7 million from $63.2 million. The company produced 110,247 ounces of gold in the period, up 3% from 107,002 ounces a year earlier. The total cash cost per ounce produced was $346, up 14% from $304 a year earlier. Portland General Electric profit doubles on tax change (5:43 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Portland General Electric Co.'s POR, -1.70% third-quarter earnings doubled to $20 million, or 32 cents a share, from $10 million, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier. The Oregon utility company cited an $18 million benefit from a state utility income-tax law. The company's quarterly revenue rose 17% to $435 million from $372 million. Looking ahead, the company reaffirmed its 2007 earnings guidance of $2.25 to $2.35 a share, including one-time items totaling 41 cents a share from a deferral of excess power costs. For 2008, the company expects earnings of $1.75 to $1.85 a share. On average, analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expect earnings of $2.10 for 2007 and $1.97 for 2008. Profit at medical equipment maker Beckton Dickinson up 44% (5:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Becton Dickinson and Co. BDX, -2.48% the New Jersey medical-equipment maker, said fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose 44% to $251 million, or 99 cents a share, with revenue up 13% to $1.65 billion. From continuing operations, profit rose 15% to 98 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 97 cents a share on revenue of $1.63 billion. For fiscal 2008, the company expects earnings up 10% to 12% from the $3.84 per share it earned in fiscal 2007. Lenovo Group net up nearly three fold to $103M in quarter (5:04 AM ET) Lenovo Group Ltd.(HK:992), makers of the ThinkPad line of laptop computers, said Thursday that net profit for its fiscal second quarter ending Sept 30. surged almost three-fold on strong PC shipments in China and overseas. Lenovo, which ranks as China's top computer maker, reported quarterly net profit of $105.26 million, up from $37.89 million a year ago. Revenue for the three-month period reached $4.43 billion, rising from $3.7 billion a year ago. In the first half, worldwide PC shipments rose 23%, with shipments to North America up 14%, shipments to China up 30% and shipments to the rest of Asia up 18%. Lenovo said its total global PC market share gained 0.6 percentage point to 8.2%. Lenovo shares fell 2.1% in Thursday trade after rising 151.6% so far this year. Bally Technologies swings to 4th-quarter net; revenue up 31% (4:57 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Bally Technologies Inc., BYI, +0.62% the Las Vegas producer of gambling equipment, swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter profit from a year-earlier loss on 31% higher revenue. Bally also affirmed its outlook for the coming fiscal year. And it said that on Nov. 2 it expected to file its reports for the quarter ended March 31 and the year ended June 30 with the Securities and Exchange Commission. For the fourth quarter ended June 30, profit was $18.5 million, or 33 cents a share, against a loss of $12 million, or 23 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted for stock-based compensation, results were profit of 37 cents against a loss of 19 cents. Shares outstanding rose 8.2% to 56.4 million. Revenue rose to $202.4 million from $154.9 million. British American Tobacco profit up 35% (3:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British American Tobacco(UK:BATS)said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit rose 35% to 600 million pounds ($1.24 billion) as revenue grew 5.8% to 2.59 billion pounds. Cigarette volumes rose slightly in the quarter, but were still down 1% for the first nine months, hurt by supply chain disruptions in the Middle East as well as heavy trade buying at the end of 2006. Profit benefited from lower raw materials and employee costs. The group said it still expects profit growth to slow in the fourth quarter due to increased spending on marketing and the timing of price increases in Brazil. Drew Industries 3rd-quarter net up 60%, sales off 4.1% (3:39 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Drew Industries Inc., DW, +4.17% the White Plains, N.Y., producer of parts for recreational vehicles and manufactured homes, reported third-quarter net income rose 60% on 4.1% lower sales. Earnings reached $11.1 million, or 50 cents a share, from $6.9 million, or 32 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales fell to $173.4 million from $180.7 million. Cost-cutting was "a significant factor" in the higher profit, President and Chief Executive Leigh Abrams said in a statement. New products, greater market share and acquisitions helped offset "continued weakness in both the RV and manufactured-housing industries," he said. Sales in October were level with those of the year-earlier month. That's the first month in 2007 that sales didn't decline from the year earlier, Drew said. ICI pretax climbs 18%, to top 2007 forecast (3:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Imperial Chemical Industries(UK:ICI), which has agreed to be bought by Akzo Nobel AKZOY, -1.81% said third-quarter adjusted pretax profit rose 18% to 177 million pounds on a 5% rise in comparable sales from continuing operations. "The third quarter was particularly strong with good underlying sales performances from Specialty Starches, Specialty Polymers and Decorative Paints in Asia & Latin America," the company said, adding that cost controls and selective price rises helped trading margins rise by nearly a percentage point to 13.3%. ICI said it expects its fourth-quarter and 2007 results to top previous expectations. ICI expects the Akzo Nobel acquisition to close on Jan. 2. Unilever profit up 37%, sales climb strongly in Africa, Asia (3:34 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Household products and food group Unilever(UK:ULVR) UL, -1.40% said Thursday that its third-quarter net profit rose 37% to 1.01 billion euros from 737 million euros as revenue for the period rose 1% to 10.24 billion euros. Underlying sales were up 4.5%. Revenue fell 0.6% in Europe and 2.3% in the Americas, but this was more than offset by strong growth in Asia and Africa, with India and China showing particularly strong growth. Commodity prices pressures have increased sharply, but have been offset through increased prices which helped raise the group's margin by 0.2 percentage points. Earnings were also boosted by increased an increased contribution from joint ventures and lower financing costs. Unilever said it remains confident it will meet its targets for 2007. Dentsply 3rd-quarter net up 33%; year outlook increases (3:20 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Dentsply International Inc., XRAY, -3.30% the York, Pa., provider of dental-care products, reported third-quarter net income rose 33% on 12% higher sales. Earnings reached $65.7 million, or 42 cents a share, from $49.4 million, or 31 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose to $488.1 million from $435.7 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 38 cents of profit on $477 million of sales. Dentsply increased its estimate of full-year earnings to $1.62 to $1.66 a share from $1.60 to $1.64. Thomson's survey is looking for $1.64. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Owens Corning OC, -2.61% on Thursday reported third-quarter net income of $112 million, or 86 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, it earned 40 cents a share. Net sales fell to $1.27 billion from $1.39 billion. The Toledo, Ohio-based company, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, said third-quarter results reflected continued weakness of the U.S. new residential construction market, partially offset by stronger global markets in its composites business. As part of Owens Corning's annual operations planning, the company said it is evaluating various cost-reduction projects to deliver significant savings in operating and corporate costs. These projects include capacity and job cuts, elimination of operational costs, and reduced general corporate expenses. Some of these cost-reduction projects have begun, Owens Corning said. The majority of the projects are expected to be completed by the end of the fourth quarter, resulting in a leaner cost structure that better positions the company to compete in a weaker housing market in 2008. This cost-reduction initiative is intended to reduce company-wide operating costs by about $100 million. The company no longer believes that it will surpass its earlier EBIT guidance from continuing operations of $365 million. Based on the deeper and prolonged weakness in demand for building materials in the U.S., the company now believes $335 million is a more appropriate estimate for 2007 adjusted EBIT from continuing operations.
title: Owens Corning posts profit, sees weak U.S. housing market

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -2.60% late Friday said it has agreed to sell its continuous filament mat business in Huntingdon, Pa., as well as related marble production assets in Anderson, S.C., to AGY, a producer of fiberglass yarns and high-strength fiberglass reinforcements. Financial terms weren't disclosed. The divestitures are intended to address regulatory concerns associated with Owens Corning's proposed acquisition of Saint-Gobain's reinforcement and composites business, the company said. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter.
title: Owens Corning agrees to sell CFM business to AGY

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Leo Leydon of Financial Focus Advisory Services in Pembroke, Mass., believes the stock market may be reaching the point of "capitulation," when investors -- particularly individuals -- throw in the towel and head for the hills. In a radio interview with Chuck Jaffe, MarketWatch senior columnist, Leydon noted that the capitulation point is only known for sure in hindsight, but said that it's a place where brave investors dive in. And he noted that the current turmoil hasn't eliminated buying opportunities in stocks. Leydon recommended buying Hewlett-Packard HPQ, -3.97% Lawson Software LWSN Vector Group VGR, -1.57% and Cemex CX, -2.19% He said Mobile Telesystems MBT, +0.70% and Vimpel Communications VIP, -1.79% are both worth buying, but only after a small price decline. And he said that concerns over the housing market make Owens-Corning OC, -2.55% a stock to sell, and to consider selling short. Listen to the highlights of Your Money with Chuck Jaffe. Jaffe's radio program regularly features reviews of stocks and mutual funds suggested by MarketWatch readers; to request a stock or mutual fund for review, send your name, hometown and the ticker symbols that interest you to Chuck Jaffe. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid
title: Market turmoil hasn't eliminated buying opportunities

content: Sunoco reports quarterly profit gain as sales increase (7:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sunoco Inc. SUN, -2.04% reported late Wednesday second-quarter net earnings rose to $509 million, or $4.20 a share, from $426 million, or $3.22 a share, a year ago. Revenue at the Philadelphia-based oil refiner rose 2% to $10.76 billion from $10.59 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast a profit of $3.85 a share. Sunoco shares closed ahead of the report at $65.27, a 2.2% loss for the day. Tetra Tech quarterly profit jumps; updates outlook (5:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Tetra Tech Inc. TTEK, -1.53% late Wednesday reported third-quarter net earnings of #12.4 million, or 21 cents a share, up from $7.85 million, or 14 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Pasadena, Calif.-based provider of engineering and technical services said revenue rose to $404 million from $359.1 million. Revenue, net of subcontractor costs, was $256.3 million vs. $240.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 20 cents on revenue of $257 million. Tetra Tech said it expects fourth-quarter per-share earnings of 21 cents to 22 cents on revenue, net of subcontractor costs, of $255 million to $270 million. For fiscal 2007, the company said it sees per-share earnings of 76 cents to 77 cents on net revenue of $992 million to $1.01 billion. Willis quarterly net rises 8%; organic revenue grows 4% (5:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Willis Group WSH said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income came in at $78 million, or 54 cents a share, up 8% from a year earlier when the insurance broker made $72 million, or 45 cents a share. Currency fluctuations trimmed net earnings by three cents a share, the company noted. Willis was expected to earn 56 cents a share, according to 16 analysts in a Thomson Financial poll. Organic revenue, which excludes the impact of recent acquisitions and divestitures and currency movements, grew 4% in the second quarter, Willis said. Prudential quarterly net almost doubles (4:43 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Prudential Financial PRU, -3.79% said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income came in at $835 million, or $1.80 a share, almost double the same period a year earlier when the insurer made $424 million, or 89 cents a share. After-tax adjusted operating income was $872 million, or $1.87 a share. Prudential was expected to make $1.72 a share, according to a Thomson Financial analyst survey. Prudential also forecast full year 2007 after-tax adjusted operating income of $7.20 to $7.40 a share. Napster narrows first-quarter loss, as sales grow 15% (4:37 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Online music provider Napster Inc. on Wednesday posted a narrowed loss for its first-quarter ended June 30. Los Angeles-based Napster NAPS, +0.00% said its net loss for the quarter was $4.24 million, or 10 cents a share, compared to $9.82 million, or 23 cents a share in the period a year earlier. Revenue meanwhile rose 15% to $32.25 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected Napster to post a loss of 15 cents a share, on revenue of $32 million. Napster said it saw a net 2.5% decrease in subscribers in the quarter, citing "normal summer seasonality." The company said it expects to post roughly $30 million in revenue for its fiscal second-quarter, which it said would reflect a 20% increase over the same period a year earlier. CORRECT: CA reports $129M quarterly profit (4:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Business software maker CA Inc. CA, -3.69% late Wednesday reported net income of $129 million, or 24 cents a share, up from $35 million, or 6 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose 8% to $1 billion. Looking ahead, CA lifted the high end of its fiscal 2008 per-share forecast to a range of 75 cents to 81 cents, up from a previous target of of 75 cents to 79 cents. Overall, the company said it expects total bookings growth for the full fiscal year. (Corrects fiscal 2008 per-share forecast) Molex profits tumble on charges; ups dividend 50% (4:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Electronic parts maker Molex Inc. MOLX said late Wednesday net income for its June quarter fell to $32.7 million, or 18 cents a share, from $70.5 million, or 38 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales rose 1% to $791.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 32 cents on sales of $796.6 million. Earnings in the most recent quarter, its fiscal fourth quarter, included $36.9 million in charges, or 16 cents a share, from a restructuring program. It said demand increased in several markets but sales fell 30% in the mobile phone sector as manufacturers rolled out simpler models for sale to developing economies. Molex raised its quarterly cash dividend 50% to 11.25 cents. Shares fell 1.2% to $28 in normal New York trading. Callaway Golf quarterly profit surges; boosts outlook (4:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Callaway Golf Co. ELY, -0.92% late Wednesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $36.6 million, or 53 cents a share, up 63% from $22.5 million, or 33 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Carlsbad, Calif.-based company said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $380 million from $341.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 54 cents on revenue of $380 million. Additionally, Callaway said it now expects full-year 2007 pro forma per-share earnings of 78 cents to 84 cents, up from its previous estimate of 72 cents to 82 cents. The company also said it now sees revenue for the year of $1.07 billion to $1.08 billion, up from its prior outlook of $1.035 billion to $1.055 billion. Unum quarterly net rises 23%; insurer lifts 2007 forecast (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Unum Group UNM, -3.28% said on Wednesday that second-quarter net income came in at $153.5 million, or 43 cents a share, up 23% from a year earlier when the disability insurer made $125.2 million, or 38 cents a share. Excluding a $53 million provision for reassessing past claims and other one-time items, Unum said income from continuing operations on an after-tax basis was $181.5 million, or 51 cents a share. The company was expected to make 47 cents a share, according to a Thomson Financial analyst poll. Unum also lifted its forecast for full year 2007 operating earnings to a range of $2.01 to $2.04 a share, up from a previous estimate of $1.91 to $1.95 a share. EA sees losses grow as revenue slips (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Electronic Arts Inc. reported a net loss for the June quarter amid a small decline in revenue. After Wednesday's closing bell, the video game publisher ERTS reported a net loss of $132 million, or 42 cents per share, compared to a loss of $81 million, or 26 cents a share, for the same period last year. Excluding the impact of stock options, the company said the net loss for the period would have been 22 cents a share. Revenue dropped 4% to $395 million. Analysts were looking for revenue of $389.4 million with a loss of 35 cents a share, according to consensus estimates from Thomson Financial. Starbucks profit rises, backs year view (4:16 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -3.87% on Wednesday said net income rose to $158.3 million, or 21 cents a share, from $145.5 million, or 18 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $2.36 billion from $1.96 billion. Analysts, on average, were expecting it to earn 21 cents a share on revenue of $2.39 billion, according to Thomson Financial. Same-store sales rose 4% in the quarter. The Seattle-based company backed its fiscal 2007 profit forecast in the range of 87 cents to 89 cents a share and net revenue growth of about 20%. It also still sees fiscal 2007 new store openings of at least 2,400, and same-store sales growth in the range of 3% to 7%. For fiscal 2008, it also said it expects revenue growth of about 18% and earnings per share growth of about 20% to 22%. It is also targeting new store openings of about 2,600, accelerating international openings by 200 stores, and same-store sales growth in the range of 3% to 7%. Disney reports higher earnings, sales (4:13 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) - Walt Disney Co. DIS, -2.47% said Wednesday that third-quarter income was $1.18 billion, or 57 cents a share, compared with $1.13 billion, or 53 cents a share for the same period a year ago. Sales for the Burbank, Calif.-based media conglomerate were $9.05 billion vs. last year's $8.47 billion. The company was expected to earn 55 cents a share on sales of $9.02 billion, according to analysts polled by Thomson Financial. Disney shares ended the day up 83 cents, or 2.5%, to $33.83. EDS posts double-digit profit gain in second quarter (4:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Electronic Data Systems Corp. said Wednesday its second-quarter profit and sales rose compared to the period a year earlier. Plano, Texas-based EDS said net income for the period ended June 30 rose 33% to $138 million, or 26 cents a share, from $104 million, or 20 cents a share in the period a year earlier. Meanwhile revenue rose 5% to $5.45 billion. EDS, a maker of software used by businesses for functions such as data management, said that excluding certain items, earnings for the quarter were 27 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected EDS to post earnings of 26 cents a share, on revenue of $5.41 billion. EDS' results are the first posted since the company named president Ronald Rittenmeyer as its new CEO in July. Rittenmeyer is due to assume the new role in September. EDS EDS shares fell more than 2% by the close of trading Wednesday. Porsche U.S. sales rise 1% in July (12:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Porsche AG's(DE:693773)Porsche Cars North America Inc. said Wednesday that U.S. sales rose 1% in July to 3,230 vehicles from 3,202, in the same month last year. BMO Capital reiterates market perform rating on Devon (10:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- BMO Capital Markets on Wednesday said Devon Energy DVN, -5.68% turned in a "great quarter" with earnings of $1.89 a share, ahead of their estimate of $1.46 a share. Excluding Egyptian assets held for sale, earnings were $1.71 a share. Volumes were 56.2 million barrels of oil equivalent a day, ahead of BMO's estimate of 52.6 million. BMO reiterated its market perform rating on the stock Comtech Group buying design-engineering firm for $20 mln (9:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Comtech Group COGO said Wednesday it's buying design-engineering firm Keen Awards (KA) for $20 million. The company said the move will enhance its share of the digital media industry in China. CB&I net income falls (9:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CB&I CBI, -6.87% said Wednesday second-quarter net income fell to $26.1 million, or 27 cents a share, from $32.6 million, or 33 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 36% to $1 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 38 cents a share and revenue of $955 million, on average. The Woodland, Texas engineering firm expects 2007 earnings of $1.50 to $1.65 a share, compared to the Wall Street target of $1.63 a share. Allergan reports higher second-quarter earnings (9:20 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Eye care products group Allergan Inc. AGN, -3.91% early Wednesday reported second-quarter net income rose to $137.8 million, or 45 a share, from $74.2 million, or 24 cents a share, for the same period in 2006. Excluding various charges, Allergan would have reported adjusted earnings of 54 cents a share, versus 43 cents last year. Sales jumped 24% to $972.8 million. A poll of analysts by Thomson Financial pegged the company at reporting earnigns of 51 cents a share, on revenue of $923 million. On June 22, Allergan completed a two-for-one stock split that was paid to shareholders of record as of June 11. For 2007, Allergan sees sales coming in between $3.66 billion and $3.76 billion, with adjusted earnings per share of between $2.16 and $2.18. Third-quarter sales are seen coming in between $940 million and $960 million, with adjusted earnings per share of 56 cents to 57 cents. The company also announced a dividend of 5 cents a share, payable on Sept. 7 to shareholders of record as of Aug. 17. THQ Inc. posts narrower loss (9:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- THQ Inc. THQI on Wednesday said first-quarter net loss narrowed to $9.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from a loss of $12.1 million, or 19 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Agoura Hills, Calif. video game maker said items in the latest quarter included a charge of 5 cents a share for compensation expenses and a boost of 10 cents a share for a tax benefit. Revenue fell to $104.5 million from $139 million. Analysts survyed by Thomson Financial forecast a loss of 25 cents a share and revenue of $112.8 million, on average. For its second quarter, THQ expects net income of 10 cents a share, excluding forecasted stock-based compensation expense of 7 cents a share, compared to the Thomson Financial forecast of 21 cents a share. Helmerich & Payne net income climbs (8:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Helmerich & Payne Inc. HP, -3.85% said Wednesday second-quarter net income rose to $115.2 million, or $1.09 a share, from $80 million, or 75 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue grew to $421.3 million from $320 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 82 cents a share and revenue of $400.3 million, on average, for the oil drilling company. PSEG swings to a Q2 gain (8:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Public Service Enterprise Group (PSEG) PEG, -1.11% said Wednesday second-quarter income from continuing operations rose to $293 million or $1.15 a share, from a loss of $8 million or 3 cents a share in the year-ago period. Losses from discontinued operations of 7 cents a share reduced net income in the latest period to $1.08 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 97 cents a share, on average. Health Net Q2 net $92.0 million vs $77.0 million (8:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Health Net, Inc. HNT, +0.00% said Wednesday its second-quarter profit totaled $92.0 million, or 80 cents per share, from $77.0 million, or 65 cents per share, in the same quarter a year before. The Los Angeles-based insurer said its total revenues increased to $3.5 billion from $3.3 billion in the year-ago period. It said it had repurchased 360,300 of its shares during the quarter at an average price of $53.07, and forecast earnings at 99 cents in the third quarter and $3.66 for the full year of 2007. DuPont agrees to settle patent lawsuit for undisclosed sum (8:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- DuPont DD, +0.94% said Wednesday it settled a patent infringement lawsuit filed this year against Trustchem Co., Ltd., also known as Jiangsu Trustchem Chemicals Co. Ltd. Under the terms of the settlement, Trustchem will pay monetary compensation and make a public apology to DuPont for losses resulting from Trustchem actions. Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Citizens Communications net falls, as revenue increases 14% (8:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Citizens Communications CZN, -3.85% said Wednesday second-quarter earnings fell 60% to $40.6 million, or 12 cents a share, from $101.7 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier, when results were boosted by a $64.6 million in cash from the liquidation of the Rural Telephone Bank. However, the Stamford, Conn., telecommunication company's revenue rose 14% to $578.8 million from $506.9 million a year ago, helped in part by higher data and Internet services revenue. Wyndham Worldwide profits rise on vacation-ownership busines (8:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Wyndham Worldwide Corp. WYN, -4.94% said Wednesday its net income rose 28% to $96 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $75 million, or 37 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding items such as costs associated with Wyndham Worldwide's spin-off from Cendant Corp. (now Avis Budget Corp.), income was $89 million, or 49 cents a share, compared with $62 million, or 31 cents a share, on an adjusted basis, in the year-ago period. Revenue, meanwhile, was up 15% to $1.1 billion, compared with $955 million a year ago. The Parsippany, N.J-based hospitality company said strong results were led by its vacation-ownership business. MasterCard swings to a gain, beats Wall St. target (8:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- MasterCard MA, -3.03% said Wednesday net income for the three months ended June 30 rose to $252.29 million, or $1.85 a share, from a loss of $310.5 million, or $2.30 a share in the year-ago period. Excluding items, net income was $195 million, or $1.43 a share, up 93%. Revenue increased 17.8% to $997 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of $1.33 a share and reveneu of $975 million, on average. The credit card firm said its higher revenue was fueled by growth in its gross dollar volume, which increased 13.3%, on a local currency basis, to $555 billion and a 15.2% increase in the number of transactions processed to 4.6 billion. Jones Apparel favors Fast Retailing's bid for Barneys (8:16 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Jones Apparel Group Inc. JNY said its board is favoring a revised offer from Fast Retailing Co. to buy its luxury-retail chain Barneys of New York for $900 million in cash. The company said it has notified Istithmar it intends to accept the offer from Fast Retailing. If the apparel company accepts the Fast Retailing bid, Jones Apparel would be required to pay an Istithmar affiliate a termination fee of $22.7 million, according to a statement. Martha Stewart Living posts wider net loss (8:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc. MSO, +0.00% on Wednesday posted a wider second-quarter loss of $6.7 million, or 13 cents a share, from a loss of $1.2 million, or 2 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding non-recurring items, the loss was 9 cents a share compared to a 7 cents loss in the prior year period. Revenue rose to $73.4 million from $68.2 million. For the third quarter, the company forecast revenue in the range of $68 million to $70.5 million, operating loss in the range of $7.5 million to $8.5 million and adjusted EBITDA loss in the range of $2.5 million to $3.5 million, including an investment of $2 million in Blueprint magazine. It maintained its forecast for the year for revenue in the range of $330 million to $340 million, operating income in the range of $9.5 million to $12.5 million and adjusted EBITDA guidance in the range of $34 million to $37 million. Analysts, on average, expected it to lose 9 cents a share in the second quarter on revenue of $71 million, and are targeting revenue of $69 million for the third quarter and $335 million for the year, according to Thomson Financial. Parker Hannifin Q4 net income rises (7:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Parker Hannifin Corp. PH, -3.99% said Wednesdsay fourth-quarter net income for the three months ended June 30 rose to $217.2 million, or $1.84 a share, from $194 million, or $1.59 a share in the year-ago period. Operating earnings rose to $1.84 a share from $1.55 a share. Revenue climbed to $2.87 billion from $2.6 billion in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of $1.78 a share and revenue of $2.8 billion, on average. For fiscal year 2008, the company said it expects earnings from continuing operations in the range of $7.20 to $7.60 a share, compared to the Wall Street target of $7.41 a share. Noble Energy's revenue, energy production rise (7:58 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Noble Energy Inc. NBL, -5.41% Wednesday said it posted a second-quarter profit of $209.1 million, or $1.21 a share, compared with a loss of $30.7 million, or 17 cents a share in the year-earlier quarter. Total revenue rose 3% to $794.2 million, while total costs and expenses dropped to $501.1 million from $817.4 million, the company said. Wall Street analysts, on average, had forecast per-share net income of $1.19 a share, on revenue of $736.8 million. The international energy company said production volume rose 12% from a year earlier not including assets sold last summer. Shares of Noble Energy lost 75 cents at $61.14 on Tuesday. Owens Corning profits fall due to weak housing market (7:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -2.74% said Wednesday its second-quarter net income fell 88% to $29 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with $251 million, or $4.19 a share, a year ago. Excluding items such as the $30 million cost of its Chapter 11 proceedings and restructuring fees, the company earned $49 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with $245 million, or $4.09 a share, on an adjusted basis. Sales, meanwhile, fell 11% to $1.53 billion compared with $1.72 billion a year ago. "The ongoing decline of the residential construction market in the United States continued to weaken demand for building materials during the second quarter," said President and Chief Executive Dave Brown in a statement. Analysts by Thomson Financial expected the company to earn 26 cents a share, on average. Dominion Resources swings to a loss (7:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dominion Resources D, -0.85% said Wednesday it swung to a second-quarter loss of $530 million, or $1.52 a share, compared to net income of $161 million, or 46 cents a share in the year-ago period. Operating income rose to $310 million, or 89 cents a share from $279 million, or 80 cents a share in the year-ago period. Operating revenue rose to $3.7 billion from $3.5 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 89 cents a share and revenue of $3.5 billion, on average. The company reiterated its 2008 operating earnings forecast of at least $6 a share. MeadWestvaco returns to profitability, meets forecasts (7:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Packaging provider MeadWestvaco MWV said it swung to a second-quarter net income of $32 million, or 17 cents a share, with sales up 9% to $1.71 billion. It lost $7 million in the year-ago quarter. MeadWestvaco took a total of 6 cents a share in charges. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 23 cents a share on revenue of $1.72 billion. OfficeMax profits stay flat (7:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- OfficeMax Inc. OMXS30, +1.54% said Wednesday its second-quarter net income stayed flat at $27.4 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with a year ago. In the year ago period, the company said it earned $23 million, or 29 cents a share, excluding special items. The Naperville, Ill.-based company said sales increased 4.5% to $2.13 billion, compared with $2.04 billion a year ago. Lower-margin sales in the company's contract division caused shrinking operating margins, said Chief Executive Sam Duncan. Analysts at Thomson Financial expected the company to earn 32 cents a share, on average, on revenue of $2.12 billion. Human Genome Sciences quarterly loss narrows (7:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Drug company Human Genome Sciences Inc. HGSI said Wednesday that its second-quarter net loss narrowed to $51.3 million, or 38 cents a share, from $61.3 million, or 47 cents a share, as revenue jumped to $9 million from $2.2 million. The group said it's made good progress with its four Phase 3 trials and said 2007 net cash burn is on track to be $145 million to $165 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting the firm to report a loss of 41 cents a share. TRW Automotive Q2 earnings 94c per share vs 88c (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- TRW Automotive Holdings Corp. TRW, -3.33% said XXXXday its second-quarter profit totaled $97 million, or 94 cents per share, from $91 million, or 88 cents per share, in the same quarter a year before. A Thomson Financial poll of analysts had predicted 78 cents per share. The Livonia, Mich.-based company said sales totaled $3.8 billion, an increase of 8.5% on year. It said that during the second quarter, it had completed the final step of its 2007 debt recapitalization plan with the successful refinancing of its $2.5 billion credit facilities in May. It said it expects full year sales in the range of $14.1 billion to $14.5 billion, including third quarter sales of approximately $3.4 billion, and net earnings per share in the range of 55 cents to 85 cents. Lazard net income edges down (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Lazard LAZ, -2.07% on Wednesday said second-quarter net income for the three months ended June 30 fell slightly to $61.5 million, or 53 cents a share, from $62.9 million, or 60 cents a share in the year-ago period. The banking firm headed by Bruce Wasserstein reports net income assuming full exchange of exchangeable interests. Operating revenue for the second quarter increased 7% to $439.5 million amid growth in its asset management business. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial forecast earnings of 45 cents a share and revenue of $379 million, on average. Jones Apparel swings to net loss (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Jones Apparel Group Inc. JNY on Wednesday posted a second-quarter net loss of $47.1 million, or 44 cents a share. In the year-ago period it earned $36.6 million, or 32 cents a share. Excluding discontinued operations, the impact of severance and expenses related to restructuring activities and other items, the apparel wholesaler earned 17 cents a share. Net sales fell to $894.5 million from $909.6 million. Jones forecast full year adjusted earnings per share to in a range of $1.28 to $1.34, compared to $2.18 a year earlier. On a continuing operations basis it forecast profit in an adjusted range of $1.20 to $1.25 a share. Moody's Q2 EPS 95c vs 59c (7:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Moody's Corp. MCO, -2.93% said Wednesday its second-quarter profit totaled $261.9 million, or 95 cents per share, from $172.1 million, or 59 cents per share, in the same quarter a year before. A Thomson Financial poll of analysts had predicted earnings of 69 cents. The New York-based financial company said revenue for the quarter totaled $646.1 million, compared with $511.4 million for the same quarter of 2006. It also said it had repurchased 7.7 million of its shares for $500 million and had approved a new $2 billion repurchase plan to begin "immediately following completion of the existing program." The company said revenue growth for the full year 2007 would be in the "low teens," meeting the lower end of its previous guidance Devon Energy profit up 5% on production rises (6:54 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Devon Energy DVN, -5.68% said second-quarter net income rose 5% to $904 million, or $2 a share, with revenue up 25% to $2.93 billion. Adjusted for 13 cents a share in benefits, it would've earned $1.87 a share, compared to Thomson Financial-compiled earnings estimates of $1.46 a share. Production rose 16% to 56.2 million barrels of oil equivalent. MWI Veterinary Supply profit increases 13%, cut revenue view (6:50 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- MWI Veterinary Supply MWIV said fiscal third-quarter net income rose 13% to $4.3 million, or 35 cents a share, with revenue up 12% to $184 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 36 cents a share. It trimmed its revenue outlook, now seeing about $715 million in revenue from earlier guidance of $720 million, while earnings are still seen at $1.39 a share. Oshkosh Truck profit up 70%, helped by defense unit (6:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Specialty vehicle maker Oshkosh Truck OSK, -3.94% said third-quarter net income rose 70% to $90.6 million, or $1.21 a share, with sales more than doubling to $1.85 billion from $888 million. Sales grew on the acquisition of JLG Industries, and its profit improvements on the back of its defense segment. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of $1.02 a share. Oshkosh increased its estimate for fiscal 2007 EPS to a range of $3.35 to $3.40, and sees fiscal 2008 earnings per share between $4.15 and $4.35 on revenue between $7 billion and $7.2 billion. Analysts, on average, were looking for this fiscal year's EPS to be $3.35, rising to $4.74 in fiscal 2008. Tekelec swings to loss after SSG disposal (6:38 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Network applications developer Tekelec TKLC said Wednesday that it swung to a second-quarter net loss of $7.8 million, or 11 cents a share, from a profit of $14.6 million, or 20 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter slipped 7.7% to $110 million. The company said its result was mainly due to a loss from discontinued operations related to the sale of its SSG business. Profit from continuing operations was 5 cents a share, or 12 cents a share on an adjusted basis. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 11 cents a share on revenue of $103 million. R.R. Donnelley posts loss on write-off (6:37 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Printing services firm R.R. Donnelley & Sons RRD, -7.56% said it lost $69.4 million, or 32 cents a share, in the second quarter, mostly on $316.7 million in impairments on writing off the Moore Wallace, OfficeTiger and other trade names. On an adjusted basis, it would've earned 67 cents a share, with revenue growing to $2.8 billion from $2.27 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 65 cents a share on revenue of $2.81 billion. It sees 2007 adjusted earnings at the high end of its $2.70 to $2.75 a share range. Genesee & Wyoming net down 91% on year-ago asset sale (6:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Genesee & Wyoming GWR, -3.49% said second-quarter net income fell 91% to $10.7 million, or 27 cents a share, while revenue rose 16% to $132 million. This year's quarter included an 11 cents-a-share hit from hurricane-damaged Mexican operations while last year's quarter included a $2.41 a share gain on the sale of its Western Australian railroad operations. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 36 cents a share. Its board has authorized the buyback of up to 4 million shares. Cigna revises 2007 adjusted profit outlook higher (6:28 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Cigna Corp. CI, -2.02% said it anticipates generating adjusted income from operations in a range of $3.55 to $3.75 a share for 2007 on a consolidated basis. This is higher than the company's previous estimate, reflecting the impact of stock buybacks and higher-than-expected earnings from operations. Analysts' average profit estimate, as derived by Thomson Financial, stands at $3.61 a share. In addition, full-year growth in medical membership is pegged at 5% to 6.5%, the insurer said. Iron Mountain profit up 3%, tops forecast (6:24 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Iron Mountain IRM, -1.49% which provides records and data protection services, said second-quarter net income rose 3% to $39 million, or 19 cents a share, with revenue up 15% to $669 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 17 cents a share. It upped its 2007 revenue outlook, citing its first-half performance, seeing revenue growth of $2.66 billion to $2.695 billion compared to an earlier view between $2.6 billion and $2.66 billion; the top end of its operating income view was trimmed to $453 million from $457 million. Kendle profit edges up, matches expectations (6:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Clinical research group Kendle International Inc. KNDL said Wednesday that its second-quarter net profit rose 1% to $4.33 million, or 29 cents a share, from $4.29 million, as net service revenue for the quarter grew 58% to $97.8 million. Excluding an amortization charge, earnings would have been 34 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 34 cents a share on revenue of $101 million. New business awards rose 96% to $165 million, while contract cancellations were $13 million. Kendle cut its earnings guidance for 2007 by 18 cents a share to a range of $1.32 to $1.52, reflecting the non-cash charge of the write-off of term debt financing fees. The write-off of financing fees resulted from the debt payments made in July with proceeds from a convertible note offering. Cigna posts lower net profit on run-off reinsurance charge (6:17 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Cigna Corp. CI, -2.02% reported second-quarter net income of $198 million, or 68 cents a share, down from $273 million, or 78 cents, earned in same period last year. Net income for the latest quarter included a special charge of 19 cents a share, related to Cigna's run-off reinsurance business. On an adjusted basis, the Philadelphia-based insurer had income from operations of 96 cents a share for the latest quarter, up from the prior year's 77 cents. Cigna also said revenue reached $4.4 billion, up from $4.1 billion. Analysts, on average, had been looking for Cigna to post earnings of 88 cents a share on revenue of $4.41 billion, based on estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. The results reflected what the company called "strong" performance from its health-care, disability and life, and international businesses. Shares of Cigna lost 61 cents, or 1.2%, to end Tuesday's trading at $51.64.
