Beckman Coulter net rises 56% on diagnostic product demand (6:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Beckman Coulter BEC, +1.49% said second-quarter net income rose 56% to $69.4 million, or $1.09 a share, with revenue up 12% to $690 million, helped by demand for clinical diagnostics products. On an adjusted basis, it would've earned 75 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 76 cents a share on revenue of $668 million. It sees annual adjusted earnings between $3.10 and $3.25 a share on revenue growth between 7% and 9%. Cadbury pretax drops 11%, doesn't see margin rise (3:04 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. confectionery group Cadbury Schweppes PLC CSG, -8.88% (UK:CSBRY)Wednesday posted an 11% drop in first-half profit despite strong sales growth and said it is unlikely to see any margin growth this year. Cadbury - which makes brands such as Cadbury Dairy Milk chocolate, Trident gum and Halls throat lozenges - said that pretax profit before exceptional items in the six months to June 30 dropped 11% to 110 million pounds. The company's American Beverages business is being treated as a discontinued business ahead of its divestment. Revenue for the period grew 1% to 2.33 billion pounds, while net profit dropped to 182 million pounds from 819 million pounds last year. Net profit last year included the European beverage operation which has since been sold. Sanofi-Aventis profit down 6%, plans $4.1 billion buyback (2:45 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French drugmaker Sanofi-Aventis SNY, -1.35% (FR:012057)said second-quarter profit fell 6% to 1.68 billion euros ($2.3 billion), with sales down 2% to 6.94 billion euros. The company said sales would've rose 7% when excluding the impact of generics of Ambien IR in the U.S. and Eloxatin in Europe as well as currency moves. It's going to buy back up to 3 billion euros of its shares by May 2008. Adjusted earnings per share excluding certain items should rise 9% based on an euro worth $1.25; based on the $1.329 value of the euro during the first, EPS will rise 4%, it said. ArcelorMittal profit up 50% on shipments, rising prices (2:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- ArcelorMittal(FR:MTP) MT, -1.57% the world's biggest steel maker, said second-quarter profit, on a proforma basis, rose 50% to $2.72 billion, with sales up 11% to 27.22 billion. Shipments rose to 28.7 million metric tons from 27 million. Higher selling prices also boosted profit, offset in part by higher costs. Hanson profit dips, U.S. demand slows further (2:38 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Construction materials group Hanson(UK:HNS)said Wednesday that its first-half net profit fell 3.5% to 161.1 million pounds, while revenue grew 2.3% to 2.04 billion pounds. Revenue growth was largely due to acquisitions made in 2007, while exchange rates and lower property profits weighed on earnings, the company said. Hanson also noted that residential demand in North America continued to decline in the first half of the year, resulting in reduced volumes for most of its products. The firm, which has agreed to be bough by HeidelbergCement, said it expects the deal to complete at the end of August. BNP Paribas profit up 20%, says no direct link to subprime (2:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French bank BNP Paribas(FR:013110)said second-quarter net income rose 20% to 2.28 billion euros ($3.1 billion), with revenue up 13% to 8.21 billion euros. Provisions rose to 258 million euros from 121 million euros, but BNP said the good quality of its customer base and prudent risk policy means it's not directly impacted by the current U.S. subprime mortgage criss and tensions in the LBO market. It says its corporate and investment bank has an indirect, "moderate" risk via its activity with hedge funds, though direct investments in hedge funds are neglible and exposure to counterparty risk is collateralized. Its portfolio of final takes is largely diversified, 69% European and virtually exclusively with senior tranches. Prudential profit rises after strong Asia growth (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. insurer Prudential Plc(UK:PRU)said Wednesday that its first-half net profit rose 59% to 715 million pounds ($1.45 billion). On a European Embedded Value basis, net profit for the period rose 69% to 1.78 billion pounds. Sales rose 12% to 1.33 billion pounds on an annual premium equivalent basis. The company said growth was driven by its Asia unit, where new business rose 48%. U.K. sales rose 10%, with the internal rate of return at 15%, topping its 14% target. Metro pretax drops 9%, reiterates 2007 target (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Metro(DE:725750), the German retailing giant, said second-quarter profit before tax dropped an in-line 9% to 184 million euros, weighed down by the integration of Real's acdquisitions from last year, while revenue rose 10% to 15.39 billion euros. Operating profit dropped 8% to 296 million euros. For the year it still sees sales growth of 8% to 9% and an EBIT rise of 6% to 8%. It also expects a tax hit of between 160 million and 180 million euros in the third quarter to account for a revaluation of deferred tax assets and liabilities in light of German corporate tax reform. Atos Origin profit climbs, holds targets (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French IT services group Atos Origin(FR:005173)said first-half net income rose to 57 million euros from 10 million euros, with revenue rising 7% to 2.89 billion euros. It still sees revenue growth of above 8.5% and sees an adjusted operating margin above last year's 4.6%, saying it's confirming its targets despite the British Department of Health terminating a diagnostic services contract. Teva 2nd-quarter net rose 5.3% on 9.9% higher sales (1:35 AM ET) TEL AVIV (MarketWatch) -- Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd., TEVA, -3.19% Jerusalem, reported second-quarter net income rose 5.3% on 9.9% higher sales, driven by strong sales of the multiple-sclerosis treatment Copaxone and the generic version of the high-blood-pressure treatment Lotrel. Earnings reached $515 million, or 63 cents a share, from $495 million, or 59 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings were 63 cents versus 66 cents. Sales rose to $2.39 billion from $2.17 billion. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced consensus estimates of 56 cents of earnings on $2.28 billion of sales. North American pharmaceutical sales rose 6.4% to $1.34 billion while European sales rose 13% to $556 million. Sales of two Teva-originated drugs rose: Copaxone by 23% to $436 million and Azilect, a treatment for Parkinson's, to $28 million from $6 million. A statement didn't specify sales of the generic version of Novartis's NVS, -1.62% Lotrel. Teva had said on June 11 that it planned to resume shipments of generic Lotrel after winning a round in a patent dispute with Novartis over the drug. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Aon Corp. AOC, -3.71% said Wednesday second-quarter net income came in at $240 million, or 75 cents a share, up 24% from a year earlier when the insurance broker made $193 million, or 57 cents a share. Profit from continuing operations jumped 36% to $238 million, or 74 cents a share. Aon also said it's considering strategic options for its Combined Insurance Co. of America business, including a sale or spin-off to shareholders. Apple Inc. AAPL, -1.65% was upgraded to buy from hold at Citigroup, which cited Tuesday's 7% pullback in the shares. The broker left its price target unchanged at $160. It said that iPhone and iPod production cuts rumored in Asia should not come as a surprise to investors and that such cuts would reflect normal channel inventory clearance ahead of new product introductions in August and September. ArcelorMittal MT, -1.52% the world's biggest steelmaker, said second-quarter profit, on a proforma basis, rose 50% to $2.72 billion, with sales up 11% to $27.22 billion. Shipments rose to 28.7 million metric tons from the prior year's 27 million. Higher selling prices also boosted profit, offset in part by higher costs. Eye-care products supplier Allergan Inc. AGN, -3.92% reported second-quarter net income rose to $137.8 million, or 45 cents a share, from $74.2 million, or 24 cents, earned in the same period in 2006. Excluding various charges, Allergan would have reported adjusted earnings of 54 cents a share, up from 43 cents last year. Sales jumped 24% to $972.8 million. AvalonBay Communities Inc.'s second-quarter net income fell 24% to $51.1 million, or 61 cents a share, from $67 million, or 86 cents a share, a year earlier. Year-ago earnings include gains from sales of land and communities, the Alexandria, Va., real- estate investment trust AVB, -1.40% said. Funds from operations increased 26% to $94 million, or $1.17 a share, from $74.9 million, or 99 cents a share, a year ago. Total revenue increased 12% to $400.2 million from $357.6 million a year ago, the company said. Canada's WestJet agreed to buy 20 Boeing Co.-made 737 jets. The Chicago aerospace giant BA, -2.92% is to deliver 14 of the aircraft in 2012 and six more in 2013, WestJet (WJA) said. Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc.'s second-quarter net income jumped 85% to $20 million, or 60 cents a share, from $10.8 million, or 33 cents, earned a year earlier, due to more new stores and higher menu prices. The restaurant chain CMG, -4.40% said revenue increased 34% to $274.3 million from $204.9 million as comparable-restaurant sales grew 11.6%. Devon Energy DVN, -5.50% said second-quarter net income rose 5% to $904 million, or $2 a share, with revenue up 25% to $2.93 billion. On an adjusted basis, the company would have earned $1.87 a share in the latest quarter, outpacing the Thomson Financial-compiled earnings estimates of $1.46 a share. See full story. The board of Dow Jones & Co. DJ definitively agreed for the media company to be acquired by News Corp. NWS, -3.42% NWS for $60 a share, or $5.6 billion. See full story. DreamWorks Animation SKG Inc. DWA helped by box-office revenue from the movie hit "Shrek The Third," quadrupled second-quarter net income to $61.8 million, or 60 cents a share, compared with $13.7 million, or 13 cents, earned for the same period a year ago. Sales generated by the Glendale, Calif., animation studio were $222.5 million vs. last year's $74.9 million. Endurance Specialty Holdings Ltd. ENH said second-quarter net income came in at $135 million, more than double a year ago when the reinsurer made $64 million. Net income available to common shareholders was $131.5 million, or $1.85 a share. Operating income, which excludes after-tax realized investment gains and losses and foreign-exchange gains and losses, was $141.2 million, or $1.94 a share, Endurance also reported. Energen Corp. EGN, -3.69% said its oil and gas exploration and production subsidiary, Energen Resources Corp., has increased its 2008 hedge position to 62% of its total estimated production of 98 billion cubic feet equivalent. The company also said that Energen Resources has begun hedging its 2009 natural gas and oil production. Genesee & Wyoming GWR, -3.43% said second-quarter net income fell 91% to $10.7 million, or 27 cents a share, while revenue rose 16% to $132 million. The latest quarter's earnings per shares included an 11-cent hit from hurricane-damaged Mexican operations, while last year's quarter included a $2.41 a share gain on the sale of Australian railroad operations. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 36 cents a share, on average. In addition, Genesee & Wyoming's board has authorized the buyback of up to 4 million shares. Healthspring Inc. HS said second-quarter earnings fell 23% to $16.2 million, or 28 cents a share, from $21.1 million, or 37 cents a share, a year earlier. The latest quarter includes a charge of 5 cents a share for the impairment of intangible assets. The Nashville managed-care company said total revenue increased 14%, climbing to $368.2 million from $322.8 million. Helmerich & Payne Inc. HP, -3.77% said second-quarter net income rose to $115.2 million, or $1.09 a share, from $80 million, or 75 cents, earned in the year-ago period. Revenue grew to $421.3 million from $320 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 82 cents a share and revenue of $400.3 million, on average, for the oil drilling company. Hutchinson Technology Inc. HTCH swung to a third-quarter loss of $13.5 million, or 52 cents a share, from a year-earlier net profit of $6.2 million, or 23 cents a share, as revenue fell nearly 8%. The loss includes $8.7 million in pretax severance charges. The Hutchinson, Minn., disk-drive suspension assembly maker's revenue dropped to $156.7 million from $170 million in the year-ago period. Kraft Foods Inc.'s second-quarter earnings rose to $707 million, or 44 cents a share, from $682 million, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding items, earnings were 50 cents a share for the latest quarter. A Thomson Financial survey of analysts, on average, had predicted earnings of 47 cents a share. Quarterly revenue generated by the Northfield, Ill., food and beverage maker KFI, +0.00% rose to $9.21 billion from $8.62 billion a year ago. See full story. Navteq Corp.'s second-quarter net income rose 72% to $40.9 million, or 41 cents a share, from $23.8 million, or 25 cents a share, a year earlier. The Chicago-based provider of digital map information for automotive navigation systems NVT, -10.00% said revenue rose 49% to $202.3 million from $135.9 million. Israel-based Nice Systems Ltd. NICE, -1.74% a producer of digital recording and archiving systems, reported higher second-quarter net income and revenue, and it raised its earnings estimate for the year. Noble Energy Inc. NBL, -5.35% reported a second-quarter profit of $209.1 million, or $1.21 a share, reversing a loss of $30.7 million, or 17 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Total revenue rose 3% to $794.2 million, while total costs and expenses dropped to $501.1 million, the company said. OfficeMax Inc. OMXS30, +1.54% said second-quarter net income was $27.4 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with a year-earlier profit of $23 million, or 29 cents, excluding special items. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had, on average, expected the company to earn 32 cents a share on revenue of $2.12 billion. See full story. Oshkosh Truck OSK, -4.00% said third-quarter net income rose 70% to $90.6 million, or $1.21 a share, with sales more than doubling to $1.85 billion from $888 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been looking for earnings of $1.02 a share. Oshkosh also increased its full-year profit forecast to a range of $3.35 to $3.40, and the company sees earnings in a range between $4.15 and $4.35 a share on revenue between $7 billion and $7.2 billion for fiscal 2008. Analysts' average estimates stand at $3.35 a share for fiscal 2007, rising to $4.74 a share in fiscal 2008. RealNetworks Inc. RNWK, -0.65% saw revenue surge more than 50% for the second quarter while earnings slid from the year-ago period, which was skewed by a large settlement with Microsoft. See full story. RenaissanceRe Holdings Ltd. RNR, -0.97% said that second-quarter net income came in at $193.7 million, up 39% from a year earlier when the catastrophe reinsurance specialist made $139.1 million. Operating earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses, were $194.7 million, or $2.69 per common share, the company reported. Sun-Times Media Group Inc. SVN, +0.00% settled securities class-action lawsuits over the insurance coverage for its directors and officers. The agreements are subject to court approval in the U.S. and Canada, the company said. Tupperware Brands TUP, -3.67% said second-quarter net income for the consumer-goods company was $35.5 million, or 56 cents a share, compared with $25.2 million, or 41 cents, for the same period a year ago. Sales were $492.9 million, up from last year's $438.6 million. The company said adjusted net income, also excluding a one-time gain, was 54 cents a share. WebMD Health Corp. WBMD said it swung to a second-quarter profit of $5.39 million, or 9 cents a share, from a net loss of $853,000, or 2 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The provider of health-information services said revenue for the latest quarter rose to $78.5 million from $56.6 million last year. Whole Foods Market Inc. WFMI said third-quarter profit fell 9%, hurt by expenses related to store openings, but the results beat Wall Street estimates. See full story. Wright Medical Group Inc. WMGI, -0.35% swung to a second-quarter loss of $2.1 million, or 6 cents a share, from a profit of $2.8 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier. The prior year's net income included the after-tax effect of about $3.1 million in non-cash stock-based compensation expenses. The Arlington, Tenn., joint-implant maker's net sales rose 12% to $98 million from $87.5 million in the year-ago period. Decliners Shares of Beazer Homes USA Inc. BZH, -6.39% were down sharply as fresh worries broke out over the housing and mortgage markets. Some analysts have expressed concern over Beazer's future as it faces a federal investigation of its mortgage-origination business. In June, Beazer said it had fired its chief accounting officer over attempts to destroy documents. See full story. Cadbury Schweppes Plc CSG, -8.88% (CBRY) reported an 11% drop in first-half profit despite strong sales growth and said it is unlikely to see any margin growth this year. CB&I CBI, -6.87% said second-quarter net income fell to $26.1 million, or 27 cents a share, from $32.6 million, or 33 cents, earned in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 36% to $1 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 38 cents a share and revenue of $955 million, on average. The engineering firm also said it expects 2007 earnings of $1.50 to $1.65 a share, compared to analysts' average of $1.63 a share. Cephalon Inc. CEPH reported a second-quarter loss of $4.3 million, or 6 cents a share, vs. a profit of $50.4 million, or 76 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Revenue was $447.2 million vs. last year's $440.1 million. Creation of a settlement reserve of $56 million for pending litigation, plus new accounting rules, cut into income. Without them, the company said it would have reported earnings of 93 cents a share. Cigna Corp. CI, -2.04% reported second-quarter net income of $198 million, or 68 cents a share, down from $273 million, or 78 cents, in the same period last year. On an adjusted basis, the Philadelphia-based insurer had a profit from operations of 96 cents a share for the latest quarter, up from the prior year's 77 cents. Cigna also said revenue reached $4.4 billion, up from $4.1 billion. Analysts, on average, had been looking for Cigna to post earnings of 88 cents a share on revenue of $4.41 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. Citizens Communications CZN, -3.85% said second-quarter earnings fell 60% to $40.6 million, or 12 cents a share, from $101.7 million, or 32 cents, earned a year earlier, when results were boosted by a $64.6 million in cash from the liquidation of the Rural Telephone Bank. Revenue rose 14% to $578.8 million from $506.9 million a year ago, helped in part by higher data and Internet services revenue. Crown Castle International Corp.'s second-quarter net loss widened to $32.7 million, or 13 cents a share, from a year-earlier loss of $13.3 million, or 9 cents a share. The Houston wireless and broadcast transmission service company's revenue grew 77% to $342.9 million, from $193.8 million a year earlier, partly because of the January merger of Global Signal Inc. with Crown Castle CCI, -1.09% DaimlerChrysler DCX posted a 9.1% decline in July U.S. sales to 156,314 vehicles despite a strong showing in Chrysler cars. Chrysler, which is in the process of being taken over by Cerberus Capital Management, posted an 8% slide to 137,728 vehicles, even as car sales surged 32% on the back of the Sebring sedan. The luxury Mercedes side reported a 14% slip to 18,586 cars and trucks. There was one less selling day in July 2007 than in the same month a year ago. See full story. Dominion Resources D, -0.83% swung to a second-quarter loss of $530 million, or $1.52 a share, compared to net income of $161 million, or 46 cents a share in the year-ago period. Operating earnings rose to $310 million, or 89 cents a share, from $279 million, or 80 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $3.7 billion from $3.5 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 89 cents a share and revenue of $3.5 billion, on average. The company also reiterated its forecast for 2008 operating earnings of at least $6 a share. See full story. Ford Motor Co. F, -3.24% on Wednesday posted a 19.1% plunge in July U.S. auto sales to 195,245 cars and trucks, with the automaker slashing its rental car sales in half as part of its planned reduction in the less-profitable fleet business. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were looking for a decline of about 10%. All six of Ford brands posted declines, with Jaguar taking the biggest hit, down 43% to a mere 1,136 vehicles. Car sales fell 32.8% while trucks shed 11%. The flagship F-Series pickup endured another rough month, down 18.1% as the home-building crunch again weighed on the competitive big truck segment. General Growth Properties Inc. GGP, -1.00% swung to a second-quarter profit of $8.39 million, or 3 cents a share, from a net loss of $25.8 million, or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Funds from operations came in at $210.3 million, or 71 cents a share, compared with $182 million, or 62 cents a share, last year. The Chicago real-estate investment trust said revenue in three months ended June 30 rose to $740.1 million from $709.8 million in the comparable period a year ago. Jones Apparel Group Inc. JNY reported a second-quarter net loss of $47.1 million, or 44 cents a share. In the year-ago period, the company earned $36.6 million, or 32 cents a share. Excluding discontinued operations, the impact of severance and expenses related to restructuring activities and other items, the apparel wholesaler earned 17 cents a share. Net sales fell to $894.5 million from $909.6 million. Jones Apparel also forecast full-year adjusted earnings per share to in a range of $1.28 to $1.34 a share, compared to $2.18 a year earlier. On a continuing operations basis, it forecast profit in an adjusted range of $1.20 to $1.25 a share. See full story. Lincoln National Corp. LNC, -4.01% said second-quarter net income came in at $376 million, or $1.37 a share, up 8% from $349 million, or $1.23 a share, earned by the annuity specialist in the same period last year. Income from operations for the second quarter was $386.7 million, or $1.41 a share. MasterCard Inc. MA, -2.93% swung to a second-quarter profit, although some Wall Street analysts pointed to slowing growth in transactions and volume for the credit-card issuer. See full story. Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc. MSO, +0.00% reported a wider second-quarter net loss of $6.7 million, or 13 cents a share. Excluding non-recurring items, the loss was 9 cents a share, compared to loss of 7 cents a share in the prior year's quarter. Revenue rose to $73.4 million from $68.2 million. See full story. MeadWestvaco MWV, +0.00% swung to a second-quarter net profit of $32 million, or 17 cents a share, with sales up 9% to $1.71 billion. The company, which lost $7 million in the year-ago quarter, took a total of 6 cents a share in charges during the most recent three months. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of 23 cents a share on revenue of $1.72 billion. MetLife Inc. MET, -2.94% said second-quarter net income came in at $1.16 billion, up 79% from a year earlier when the life insurance and annuity giant made $650 million. Net income available to common shareholders was $1.13 billion, or $1.48 a share. Operating earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses, were $1.31 billion, or $1.72 a share, the company reported. Millipore Corp.'s second-quarter net income fell to $28.4 million, or 52 cents a share, from $29.1 million, or 54 cents, earned a year earlier. Net income for the latest quarter included stock-based compensation expenses of $4.3 million. Revenue generated by the Billerica, Mass., bioprocess and biosciences products company MIL, -3.92% jumped 40% to $383.2 million from $273.8 million, boosted by strong results in its bioprocess unit. MWI Veterinary Supply MWIV said third-quarter net income rose 13% to $4.3 million, or 35 cents a share, with revenue up 12% to $184 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 36 cents a share, on average. The company also trimmed its full-year revenue outlook, now seeing about $715 million as opposed to $720 million previously, while earnings are still seen as coming in at $1.39 a share. Owens Corning OC, -2.77% said second-quarter net income fell 88% to $29 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with $251 million, or $4.19 a share, a year ago. Excluding items such as the $30 million cost of its Chapter 11 proceedings and restructuring fees, the company would have earned $49 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with $245 million, or $4.09 a share, on an adjusted basis. Sales, meanwhile, fell 11% to $1.53 billion compared with $1.72 billion a year ago. Qwest Communications International Inc.'s second-quarter earnings more than doubled, boosted by lower cost of sales and lower depreciation and amortization expenses for the telecom carrier Q, +2.95% See full story. R.R. Donnelley & Sons RRD, -7.33% reported a loss of $69.4 million, or 32 cents a share, for the second quarter, mostly on $316.7 million in impairments on writing off Moore Wallace, OfficeTiger and other trade names. On an adjusted basis, it would've earned 67 cents a share, with revenue growing to $2.8 billion from $2.27 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 65 cents a share on revenue of $2.81 billion, on average. The company also said it sees 2007 adjusted earnings at the high end of its $2.70 to $2.75 a share range. See full story. Ruth's Chris Steak House Inc.'s second-quarter net income rose 12% to $5.44 million, or 23 cents a share, from $4.9 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier on growth from newly opened restaurants. The restaurant chain RUTH, -1.23% saw its quarterly revenue increase 30% to $78.4 million from $60.5 million a year ago, while same-restaurant sales increased 1% on a calendar basis. SiRF Technology Holdings Inc. SIRF reported a second-quarter profit of $2.1 million, or 4 cents a share, on revenue of $70.6 million. During the same period a year ago, the maker of GPS chip technology earned $1.7 million, or 3 cents a share, on $57.2 million in sales. SPX Corp. SPX, -3.07% said second-quarter net income declined to $63.9 million, or $1.12 a share, from $110.3 million, or $1.83 a share. Stripping out discontinued operations, earnings rose to $1.26 a share, from $1.06 a year ago. Analysts had been expecting earnings of $1.17 a share. Sales rose to $1.28 billion, up from $1.04 billion last year. The company also said that it expects to achieve its updated full-year earnings range of $4.50 to $4.70 a share. Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. TEVA, -3.13% reported higher second-quarter net income and sales, driven by multiple-sclerosis treatment Copaxone and the generic version of high-blood-pressure treatment Lotrel. See full story. THQ Inc. THQI said first-quarter net loss narrowed to $9.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from a loss of $12.1 million, or 19 cents, in the year-ago period. The Agoura Hills, Calif., video-game maker said items in the latest quarter included a charge of 5 cents a share for compensation expenses as well as 10 cents a share for a tax benefit. Revenue fell to $104.5 million from $139 million. Time Warner Inc.'s second-quarter net income rose 5.2% to $1.07 billion, or 28 cents a share, from $1.01 billion, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding discontinued operations and other items, earnings would have been 25 cents a share, up from 20 cents a year earlier. The media and entertainment company TWX, -0.14% said revenue rose 6% to $10.98 billion from $10.36 billion a year ago. On average, analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 21 cents a share and revenue of $11.13 billion. See full story. Transocean RIG, -4.04% said second-quarter net income rose to $549 million, or $1.84 a share, compared to $249 million, or 75 cents, earned in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $1.4 billion from $854 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of $1.72 a share and revenue of $1.37 billion, on average. The company's average day rate reached a record high $202,400 in the latest quarter, up 2% compared to $198,000 during the first three months of 2007. Visteon Corp. VC, -3.55% reported a second-quarter loss with sales to Ford Motor Co., its top customer and former parent, suffering a double-digit decline amid hefty production cuts in North America. See full story. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Wednesday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: Sunoco boosts profit on refining margins, stock issue (6:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sunoco Inc. SUN, -2.23% reported late Wednesday first-quarter net income of $175 million, or $1.44 a share, up from $79 million, or 59 cents a share, a year ago. Profits include $90 million from the sale of stock in its Sunoco Logistics limited partnership, in which Sunoco holds a 43% stake. Excluding special items, earnings were $85 million, or 70 cents a share. There were no special items in the year-ago quarter. Revenue at the Philadelphia-based oil refiner rose 8% to $9.31 billion from $8.59 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast a profit of $1.44 a share on $9.87 billion of revenue. Sunoco shares closed ahead of the report at $77.70, a 2.6% gain for the day. Sunstone Hotel's quarterly profit falls; FFO rises (5:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sunstone Hotel Investors Inc. SHO, -2.04% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $4.83 million, down from $17.8 million last year. The company posted a loss available to common stockholders of $359,000, or a penny a share, compared with a profit of $13.7 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted funds from operations available to common stockholders were $29.9 million, or 48 cents a share, versus $29.2 million or 49 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue in the three months ended March 31 rose to $239.8 million from $197.6 million in the first quarter of 2006. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, FFO of 46 cents a share on revenue of $222.8 million. San Clemente, Calif.-based Sunstone forecast income available to common shareholders of 23 cents to 27 cents a share for the second-quarter, and 71 cents to 82 cents a share for 2007. The lodging real estate investment trust also forecast adjusted FFO available to common shareholders of 74 cents to 78 cents a share for the second quarter, and $2.69 to $2.80 a share for 2007. Analysts are looking for second-quarter FFO of 78 cents a share, and 2007 FFO of $2.76 a share. Regency Centers profit falls; FFO rises (5:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Regency Centers Corp. REG, -1.98% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings available to common shareholders of $52.1 million, or 75 cents a share, down 21% from $65.9 million, or 97 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Funds from operations for the first quarter came in at $79.1 million, or $1.13 a share, up 35% from $58.8 million, or 85 cents a share, last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a profit of $1.07 a share. Jacksonville, Fla.-based Regency is a shopping center operator. Assurant's quarterly profit rises 10% (5:19 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Assurant Inc. AIZ, -4.07% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings rose 10% to $179.5 million, or $1.45 a share, from $162.5 million, or $1.23 a share, in the year-ago period. Operating income increased 7% to $175.8 million, or $1.42 a share, from $163.8 million, or $1.24 a share, last year. The New York-based insurance company said revenue in the three months ended March 31 rose to $2.06 billion from $1.93 billion in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of $1.21 on revenue of $2.07 billion. Aspen Insurance's first-quarter profit jumps 97% (5:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Aspen Insurance Holdings Ltd. AHL, +0.95% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $121.9 million, or $1.27 a share, up 97% from $61.8 million, or 59 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Bermuda-based insurer said net written premiums in the three months ended March 31 rose to $555.1 million from $451.9 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 86 cents. The combined ratio for the first quarter of was 79.4% versus 90.4% for the same quarter in 2006. DTE Energy quarterly profit falls slightly; backs 2007 view (5:08 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - DTE Energy Co. DTE, -0.48% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $134 million, or 76 cents a share, down slightly from $136 million, or 76 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Operating revenue at the Detroit-based utility company rose to $2.73 billion from $2.64 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast first-quarter earnings of 77 cents a share. Additionally, DTE Energy said it still expects 2007 operating earnings of $2.60 to $2.80 a share, excluding synthetic fuel. Synthetic fuel is expected to add operating earnings of 60 cents to $1.25 a share in 2007, the company noted. Luminex quarterly profit falls 74%; revenue rises (5:04 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Luminex Corp. LMNX, -2.04% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $136,000, or breakeven a share, down 74% from $526,000, or 2 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue in the first quarter rose to $16.6 million from $13 million in the first quarter of 2006. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, breakeven results on a per-share basis and revenue $15 million. Austin, Texas-based Luminex is a developer of biological testing technologies. Concur Technologies' quarterly profit up 44% (4:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Concur Technologies Inc. CNQR late Wednesday reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $1.35 million, up 44% from $933,000 in the same quarter last year. The company said net income available to common stockholders rose to 3 cents a share from 2 cents a share a year ago. Excluding items, the company posted a profit of $5.1 million, or 12 cents a share, up from $2.8 million, or 7 cents a share, last year. Revenue in the three months ended March 31 rose 31% to $30.9 million from $23.5 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 7 cents on revenue of $29.9 million. The Redmond, Wash.-based provider of software and business services forecast fiscal third-quarter earnings of 2 cents a share, or 11 cents a share excluding items, on revenue of $31.6 million. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 8 cents on revenue of $32 million. For fiscal 2007, Concur forecast earnings of 11 cents a share, or 48 cents a share excluding items, on revenue of $123 million to $125 million. Analysts are expecting a per-share profit of 30 cents on revenue of $124.9 million. Endurance Specialty's quarterly profit falls (4:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Endurance Specialty Holdings ENH late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $101.8 million, down from $107 million last year. The company reported earnings available to common shareholders of $98 million, or $1.36 a share, down from $103.2 million, or $1.45 a share, in the year-ago period. First quarter operating income available to common shareholders was $101.3 million, or $1.41 a share, down from $104 million, or $1.46 a share, last year. The Bermuda-based insurer said revenue in the three months ended March 31 fell to $443.8 million from $481.9 million last year, while net premiums written fell to $533.7 million from $543 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of $1.25 on revenue of $589 million. Avis Budget Group quarterly profit falls; updates outlook (4:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Avis Budget Group Inc. CAR, -0.51% late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $13 million, or 12 cents a share, down from $70 million, or 70 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization were $68 million, and income from continuing operations was $12 million, Avis said. Excluding the impact of separation-related items, EBITDA was $62 million. Revenue at the Parsippany, N.J.-based provider of vehicle rental services rose to $1.37 billion from $1.34 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast first-quarter results of breakeven on a per-share basis on revenue of $1.4 billion. Additionally, Avis said it expects its revenue, pro forma EBITDA, and pretax income will increase in 2007 compared with 2006. The company said it estimates that year-over-year comparisons will be stronger in the second half of 2007 than in the first half, driven by an expectation of increased pricing and an easing in fleet costs for the 2008 model year. ValueClick profit rises 90%; sales up 34% (4:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Internet marketing specialist ValueClick Inc. VCLK said late Wednesday that its first-quarter profit nearly doubled on a 34% surge in sales. For the quarter ended March 31, the Westlake Village, Calif.-based company reported net income rose 90% to $18.6 million, or 18 cents a share, compared to $9.8 million or 9 cents a share a year ago. The profit exceeded the company's own guidance of 18 cents a share, and the 17 cents a share expected by Thomson Financial analysts. Sales rose 34% to $156.9 million, from $117 million a year ago, and exceeded both the company's expectations and those of Thomson Financial analysts. Also late Wednesday, the company narrowed the range of its 2007 sales guidance to a range of $655 million to $665 million, from $645 million to $665 million. Annual profit is now seen at between $177 million to $182 million, compared to the $175 million to $180 million the company previously said it expected. Prudential Financial quarterly net rises 52% (4:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Prudential Financial PRU, -3.58% said late Wednesday that first-quarter net income came in at $1.025 billion, or $2.18 per common share, up 52% from a year earlier when the life insurance and annuity company made $675 million, or $1.38 per common share. After-tax adjusted operating income was $868 million, or $1.85 a share. Prudential was expected to make $1.65 per common share, according to the average estimate of 16 analysts in a Thomson Financial survey. The insurer stuck with its full-year forecast for after-tax adjusted operating income of $6.80 to $7 a share. CORRECT: Symantec surprises with fourth quarter results (4:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Symantec Corp. said late Wednesday that while its fiscal fourth quarter profit fell nearly 50% from the period a year earlier, it still managed to beat analysts' expecations. Security and storage software maker Symantec SYMC, -3.29% said net income fell to $60.9 million, or 7 cents a share, from $118.8 million, or 11 cents a share in the period a year earlier. Meanwhile revenue rose to $1.36 billion, from $1.24 billion. Excluding certain items, Symantec said it earned 24 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had expected Symantec to report earnings of 20 cents a share, on revenue of $1.27 billion. Cupertino, Calif.-based Symantec said that for fiscal 2008, it expects revenue between $5.59 billion and $5.69 billion. Analylsts on average expect revenue of $5.37 billion for 2008. Shares of Symantec, which rose 2% before the end of trading Wednesday to $18.20, rose more than 7% in after hours trading to $19.17. (Corrects headline to read fourth quarter instead of third). Airgas quarterly profit rises 31%; updates outlook (4:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Airgas Inc. ARG, +0.00% late Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $43.7 million, or 54 cents a share, up 31% from $33.5 million, or 42 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations were $43.7 million, or 54 cents a share, compared with $36 million, or 45 cents a share, last year. Revenue at the Radnor, Pa.-based distributor of industrial gasses company rose to $853.9 million from $746.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 53 cents a share on revenue of $835 million. Additionally, Airgas said it expects fiscal 2008 per-share earnings of $2.33 to $2.41, including the impact of the Linde bulk business. For the first quarter, the company said it sees earnings of 52 cents to 54 cents a share. Applebee's turns in sharply lower profit (4:21 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Applebee's International, facing a difficult environment for casual-dining restaurants, delivered a first-quarter profit late Wednesday that was sharply lower than last year's amid hefty charges to cover impairment costs tied to store closings and other like costs. Overland Park, Kan.-based Applebee's said it made $9.5 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with last year's income of $27.2 million, or 36 cents a share. Excluding $17.6 million, or 23 cents a share, in after-tax costs, Applebee's said it would have made $27.1 million, or 36 cents a share. Total revenue also was lower than last year's at $337.6 million. At Thomson Financial, analysts were looking for an average per-share profit of 33 cents on sales of $351.6 million. Applebee APPB, +0.00% shares ended the session at $27.45, up 3 cents, ahead of the results. JDS Uniphase swings to loss; forecast soft (4:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- JDS Uniphase Corp. JDSU a maker of technology networking equipment, late Wednesday said it swung to a fiscal third-quarter net loss of $14.2 million, or 7 cents a share, compared with a net profit of $3.7 million, or 2 cents a share. For the three months ended March 31, sales rose to $361.7 million, up from $314.9 million a year ago, and better than Wall Street's expectations. JDS said fiscal fourth-quarter revenue will be in the range of $325 million to $345 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial anticipated $354 million. Las Vegas Sands profit falls 25% on pre-opening costs (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Las Vegas Sands Corp. LVS, -2.24% late Wednesday said its first-quarter profit fell 25%, largely due to costs associated with the pending opening of new locations. The gaming company said it made $90.9 million, or 26 cents a share, in the quarter ended March 31, compared to $121.8 million, or 34 cents a share, the year before. Excluding onetime items, the per-share profit stood at 32 cents. Revenue rose to $628.2 million from $530.4 million. Analysts had been looking for earnings of 32 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial. Unum quarterly net more than doubles to $178.3 million (4:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Unum Group UNM, -3.17% said late Wednesday that first-quarter net income came in at $178.3 million, or 51 cents a share, more than double a year earlier when the disability insurer made $73.4 million, or 23 cents a share. Income from continuing operations was $174.6 million, or 50 cents a share, the company added. Unum was expected to make 45 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 13 analysts in a Thomson Financial survey. Unum lifted its forecast for 2007 operating earnings to a range of $1.91 to $1.95 a share from a previous target of $1.83 to $1.87 a share. RealNetworks earnings surge 60% in first quarter (4:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- RealNetworks Inc. reported a 60% gain in first-quarter earnings Wednesday afternoon. The Seattle-based provider of digital music and gaming services RNWK, -0.65% reported earnings of $40 million, or 22 cents per share, compared to earnings of $24.9 million, or 14 cents per share, for the same period last year. Revenue grew 50% to $129.5 million. Analysts were expecting earnings of 17 cents a share on revenue of $125.3 million, according to Thomson Financial. The company also announced that its board of directors has approved another $100 million stock buyback program. Thor Industries preliminary third-quarter sales down 8% (1:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Thor Industries Inc. THO, -4.87% said Wednesday that preliminary sales for the third quarter totaled $788 million, down 8% from $858 million last year. RV sales were $682 million, down 12% from $777 million last year, the Jackson Center, Ohio-based company said. Bus sales came in at $106 million for the period, up 31% from $81 million a year ago, the company said. Backlog as of April 30 was $593 million, down 15% from $698 million last year, the manufacturer of recreation vehicles and commercial buses said. TTM Tech shares surge on first-quarter results, outlook (11:21 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- TTM Technologies Inc. TTMI, -2.88% shares surged 19% to $10.92 in Wednesday morning trade after the Santa Ana, Calif.-based printed circuit board maker reported a first-quarter net profit of $8.5 million, or 20 cents a share, down from $8.8 million, or 21 cents a share, for the same period of 2006. Revenue more than doubled in the quarter, rising to $176.9 million from $72.7 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 15 cents on revenue of $168.4 million. For the second quarter of 2007, TTM forecast revenue of $158 million to $167 million and earnings of 13 cents to 19 cents a share. Voxware shares soar on third-quarter results (11:13 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Voxware Inc. VOXW shares soared Wednesday morning, adding $4.95 to $7.25. Late Tuesday, the Lawrenceville, N.J.-based software company reported a fiscal third-quarter net profit of $685,000, or 10 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $2.13 million or 34 cents a share, in a year-ago. Revenue rose to $4.79 million from $2.68 million last year. CEC Entertainment shares fall on first-quarter results (11:04 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CEC Entertainment Inc. CEC, +0.24% shares fell 9% to $37.95 in Wednesday morning trade. Late Tuesday, the Irving, Texas-based company, which operates Chuck E. Cheese restaurants, reported first-quarter net income of $32 million, or 95 cents a share, versus earnings of $28.9 million, or 84 cents a share, in the same period of 2006. Revenue increased to $232.9 million from $227 million in the first quarter of 2006. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 98 cents on revenue of $238.8 million. CEC forecast 2007 earnings of $2.25 to $2.30 a share and for same-restaurant sales to rise 2% to 2.5%. Molina Healthcare's quarterly profit rises; shares up (10:52 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Molina Healthcare Inc. MOH, -3.71% shares rose 11% to $33.10 in Wednesday morning trade. Late Tuesday, the Long Beach, Calif.-based managed care company reported first-quarter net earnings of $9.59 million, or 34 cents a share, up from $8.59 million, or 31 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $562.9 million from $453.4 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 31 cents on revenue of $604.1 million. The company still expects fiscal 2007 earnings of $1.75 to $1.90 a share. Eagle Materials' shares rally on fourth-quarter results (10:29 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eagle Materials Inc. EXP, -4.18% shares gained 11% to $48.80 in Wednesday morning trade. Late Tuesday, the Dallas-based company reported fiscal fourth-quarter net earnings of $36.6 million, or 75 cents a share, down 16% from $43.8 million, or 86 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue in the quarter fell 13% to $191.8 million from $221.6 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 62 cents. Eagle Materials makes basic building materials including gypsum wallboard and cement. Jones Lang LaSalle shares rise as first-quarter profit jumps (10:23 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Jones Lang LaSalle Inc. JLL, -3.04% shares rallied in Wednesday morning trade, adding 14% to $121.97. Late Tuesday, the Chicago-based real estate services and money management firm reported first-quarter net earnings of $27.2 million, or 81 cents a share, up from $4.56 million, or 14 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $490.1 million from $337.1 million. Move shares sink on first-quarter results (10:14 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Move Inc. MOVE shares fell 13% to $4.10 in Wednesday morning trade. Late Tuesday, the Westlake Village, Calif.-based real estate information provider reported a first-quarter net profit of $1.4 million, compared with a net loss of $1.16 million last year. Net income applicable to common stockholders was $163,000, or breakeven on a per-share basis, compared with a loss of $2.33 million, or 2 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $71 million from $69 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 2 cents on revenue of $75.2 million. Separately, Move named Lorna Borenstein as president. Harris Stratex shares fall on third-quarter results, outlook (10:08 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Harris Stratex Networks Inc. HTSX shares tumbled 24% to $15.14 in Wednesday morning trade. Late Tuesday, the Research Triangle Park, N.C.-based supplier of wireless networking products reported a fiscal third-quarter net loss of $23.2 million, or 58 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $6.9 million last year. The quarter included $28.9 million in pre-tax charges associated with the merger of Harris Microwave and Stratex Networks. Excluding certain items, the company posted a profit of $3.7 million, or 6 cents a share. Revenue rose to $139 million from $73.6 million in the same quarter last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 21 cents. Harris forecast second-half earnings, excluding items, of 19 cents to 24 cents a share, and fiscal 2008 earnings, excluding items, of $1.05 to $1.22 a share. Buffalo Wild Wings' profit rises; shares jump (10:06 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Buffalo Wild Wings Inc. BWLD shares surged 12% to $72.66 in Wednesday morning trade. Late Tuesday, the Minneapolis-based restaurant chain reported first-quarter net earnings of $5.54 million, or 63 cents a share, up from $3.52 million, or 40 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 24% to $79.9 million from $64.3 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 52 cents on revenue of $78.5 million. Same-store sales in the quarter increased 8.7% at company-owned restaurants and 3.3% at franchised restaurants. Buffalo Wild Wings said it expects 2007 net income growth of more than 25% and revenue growth of more than 20%. Allergan reports higher earnings (9:30 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Eye care conglomerate Allergan Inc. AGN, -4.01% on Wednesday reported a first-quarter profit of $43.8 million, or 28 cents a share. This compares to a loss of $444.8 million, or $3.29 a share, for the same quarter last year. The 2006 quarter included hefty charges related to the acquisition of Inamed. Excluding various items, Allergan would have posted adjusted earnings of 92 cents a share, compared with 82 cents in 2006. Revenue rose to $886.5 million, which includes $165.2 million in sales from Inamed. Allergan also announced a 2-for-1 stock split for stockholders of record as of the end of June 11. The new shares will be distributed on June 22. Upon distribution, Allergan's float will increase from about 152.2 million shares to 304.4 million shares. Looking forward, Allergan sees 2007 product sales of $3.51 billion and $3.67 billion, with adjusted earnings per share of $4.28 and $4.32. Second quarter sales should be $910 million to $930 million, with adjusted earnings per share of 99 cents to $1.01. The company's forecast excludes the impact of the stock split. Clorox profit and sales rise (8:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Clorox Co. CLX, -3.58% on Wednesday said fiscal third-quarter net income rose to $129 million, or 84 cents a share, from $110 million, or 72 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Results in the most recent quarter included 4 cents a share of incremental costs from transition and restructuring associated with a previously announced information technology services agreement. Net sales rose to $1.24 billion from $1.16 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 78 cents a share on revenue of $1.2 billion, on average, according to Thomson Financial. For the fiscal fourth quarter, Clorox continues to anticipate sales growth in the range of 3% to 5% and earnings per share in a range of $1.05 to $1.11 a share. For fiscal 2007, Clorox forecast sales growth of about 5% and earnings per share from continuing operations in the range of $3.21 to $3.27. The company now anticipates the impact of the acquired bleach businesses to be neutral to earnings for the fiscal year. In addition, the fiscal 2007 outlook includes about 9 cents a share of transition and restructuring costs associated with the IT services agreement. For fiscal 2008, Clorox anticipates sales growth in the range of 3% to 5%, and expects a slightly negative net commodity cost impact. While Clorox expects resin costs to be favorable, costs are expected to increase for other commodities such as agricultural products. The company also expects further inflationary pressure in manufacturing and logistics, but said these factors are anticipated to be offset by cost savings. Brink's Co. first-quarter profit $28.7 mln (8:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Brink's Co. BCO, -1.75% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $28.7 million, or 61 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $379.2 million, or $6.92 a share. The year-ago results reflect a gain on the sale of BAX Global Inc. On a continuing operations basis, the company earned $28.4 million, or 61 cents a share, in the latest quarter, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $24.2 million, or 42 cents a share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $751.5 million from $663.6 million a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 56 cents a share in the March period. Shares of the Richmond, Va., security services provider closed Tuesday at $64.03, up 0.8%. Agco first-quarter earnings $24.5 mln vs $17.3 mln (8:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Agco Corp. AG, +2.41% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $24.5 million, or 26 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $17.3 million, or 19 cents a share. Sales rose 14% in the latest three months to $1.33 billion from $1.17 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 3 cents a share in the March period. the Duluth, Ga., maker of agricultural equipment attributed the performance in the latest quarter to improving conditions in Brazil, which led to sales growth of 34% in its South American business, and lower interest costs due to a better debt position. Looking ahead, Agco said it's targeting earnings of about $1.45 per share in 2007. Wall Street's current consensus estimate for the year is for a profit of $1.40 a share. The stock closed Tuesday at $41.79, up 6 cents. Blockbuster loss widens on declining margins (8:20 AM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch)-- Blockbuster Inc. reported a wider first-quarter loss Wednesday as margins at the video rental chain fell sharply. The company reported a net loss of $46.4 million, or 26 cents a share, vs. a loss of $1.9 million, or 3 cents in the year-ago period. Revenue, meanwhile, came in up 5.4% to $1.47 billion even as the company's gross margin for the first quarter decreased to 51.7% from 56.5%. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been for Blockbuster BBI, -5.13% to lose 16 cents a share on revenue of $1.37 billion. Separately, the company said that it has sold its Games Station Limited, a specialty games retailer in the U.K. to The Game Group PLC for about $150 million in cash, most of which will be used to pay down debt. Visteon first-quarter loss $153 mln vs earnings $3 mln (8:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Visteon Corp. VC, -3.81% Wednesday reported a first-quarter loss of $153 million, or $1.19 a share, down from a year-ago profit of $3 million, or 2 cents a share. The latest results include charges of $50 million related to non-cash asset impairments. Total sales slipped in the three-month period to $2.93 billion from $2.96 billion a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a loss of 51 cents a share in the March period. The Van Buren Township, Mich., automotive parts maker said it's completed its salaried reduction program that was first disclosed in October, eliminating roughly 900 positions. Looking ahead, the company said it now sees EBIT-R (earnings before interest and taxes but excluding restructuring expenses and non-cash asset impairments) of negative $35 million and negative $135 million for 2007 on anticipated product sales of about $10.7 billion. It anticipates production volumes for the second quarter will be "significantly lower" than a year ago for a number of its key customers. The stock closed Tuesday at $9.06, down 6 cents. Walgreen April same-store sales rise 9.2% (8:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Walgreen Co. WAG on Wednesday said April sales at stores open at least one year rose 9.2%. Total sales rose 14.1% to $3.94 billion. April pharmacy sales increased 16%, while same-pharmacy sales rose 11.2%. Total prescriptions filled at comparable stores increased 7.3%. Pharmacy sales accounted for 65.1% of total sales for the month. Front-end same-store sales rose 5.6% during April. Cooper Tire first-quarter profit $20.8 mln vs loss $5.2 mln (8:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cooper Tire & Rubber Co. CTB, -3.41% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $20.8 million, or 33 cents a share, up from a year-ago loss of $5.2 million, or 8 cents a share. On a continuing operations basis, the Findlay, Ohio-based company said it earned $20.4 million, or 33 cents a share, in the latest quarter. Sales rose in the latest three months to $689.1 million from $596.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 14 cents a share in the March period. The company said its performance in the latest quarter benefited from the cost reduction and profit improvement initiatives it began in September, an improved price and mix in North America and increased tire unit sales in Europe and Asia. The stock closed Tuesday at $19.33. Owens Corning first-quarter profit $1 mln vs $63 mln (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -2.91% Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $1 million, or a penny per share. In the same period a year earlier, the company's predecessor operations prior to its emergence from bankruptcy protection, the company earned $63 million, or $1.05 a share. The company said its adjusted earnings, excluding items, were $61 million, or 14 cents a share, for the latest quarter. Sales fell 17% in the three-month period to $1.32 billion from $1.6 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 20 cents a share in the March period. The Toledo, Ohio-based building materials company said it expects its insulating systems business to continue to be impacted by the slowdown in U.S. housing starts that's expected to extend well into 2007 by the National Association of Home Builders. It backed a projection that earnings before interest and taxes, or EBIT, should exceed $415 million in 2007, excluding the impact of its proposed joint venture with Vetrotex or other strategic organizational changes. The stock closed Tuesday at $31.78, up 3.7%. Teva swings to 1st-quarter profit on 24% higher revenue (7:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd., TEVA, -2.49% Jerusalem, swung to first-quarter net income from a year-earlier loss on 24% higher revenue. Earnings were $342 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with a loss of $1.01 billion, or $1.40, in the year-earlier period. The year-ago figures reflect an after-tax write-off of $1.3 billion for in-process R&D and inventory matters tied to the acquisition of Ivax. On an adjusted basis, earnings were 42 cents a share against 37 cents. Revenue reached $2.08 billion from $1.67 billion. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 40 cents of profit on $2.12 billion of revenue. North American pharmaceutical sales rose 22% to $1.07 billion. Global sales of Copaxone, the company's treatment for multiple sclerosis, also rose 22%, to more than $400 million. And sales of Azilect, Teva's Parkinson's disease drug, were $25 million versus $3 million a year earlier. NeurogesX IPO raises $44 mln in IPO (7:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- NeurogesX Inc. NGSX priced 4 million shares at $11 a share in a bid to raise $44 million in its initial public offering trading on Wednesday. The San Carlos, Calif. biotech firm priced below its $13-$15 range with underwriter Morgan Stanley. Sprint Nextel first-quarter loss $211 mln vs earns $419 mln (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sprint Nextel Corp. S, -0.72% Wednesday reported a first-quarter loss of $211 million, or 7 cents a share, down from net income of $419 million. or 14 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, the company lost $19 million, or breakeven on a per share basis, in the latest quarter, down from earnings of $201 million, or 7 cents a share, a year earlier. Adjusted earnings before amortization totaled $532 million, or 18 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared to $766 million, or 26 cents a share, in last year's equivalent period. Net operating revenue reached $10.1 billion in the three months ended March 31, roughly flat with its year-ago total. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for a profit of 22 cents a share in the March period on revenue of $10.31 billion. The company said it added nearly 600,000 net new subscribers in the quarter for its Wireless operations, bringing its total subscriber base to 53.6 million, up 10% from last year. Looking ahead, Sprint Nextel reiterated its outlook for consolidated operating revenue of between $41 billion and $42 billion in 2007 and capital spending of about $7.2 billion for the year. It plans to continue to buy back shares of its common stock over the course of 2007. The shares closed Tuesday at $20.01, down 2 cents. Cavium Networks IPO prices above range, adds shares (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cavium Networks CAVM, -2.54% priced 6.75 million shares at $13.50 a share in a bid to raise $91 million in its initial public offering. The maker of processors for intelligent networking increased the size of the deal from 6.25 million shares and price above its $12-13 range. Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers are lead managers on the deal. Earlier, the company increased the price range from $10-$12 a share. Jones Apparel net profit rises, to sell some brands (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Jones Apparel Group Inc. JNY on Wednesday said first-quarter net income rose to $47.8 million, or 44 cents a share, from $25.8 million, or 22 cents a share. Excluding the impact of severance and restructuring charges and other items, the company said it earned 50 cents a share, compared to 66 cents a share a year earlier. Net sales rose to $1.23 billion from $1.2 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 60 cents a share on revenue of $1.22 billion, according to Thomson Financial. The apparel company, whose brands include Gloria Vanderbilt, Judith Jack and Anne Klein, said it will exit or sell some of its moderate product lines by the end of the year. These product lines will represent net revenues in 2007 of about $300 million, with estimated combined operating margins in the low single digits. Jones said it was taking a "cautious" view for the rest of the year and forecast adjusted earnings per share of $1.95 to $2.05, compared to year-ago adjusted profit of $2.19 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expect it to earn $2.42 a share for the year, on average. ICE net income nearly triples; names IBM exec as CFO (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Intercontinental Exchange ICE, -3.19% said Wednesday first-quarter net income for the three months ended March 31 rose 183% to $55.6 million, or 80 cents a share, from $19.7 million, or 33 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue climbed to $126.6 million from $50.3 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 72 cents a share and revenue of $125 mllion, on average. The Atlanta trading firm named Scott A. Hill as chief financial officer. He'll take the job on May 14. CFO Richard V. Spencer will become vice chairman of ICE. Hill worked for 16 years in international finance for IBM IBM, -3.10% Average daily volume for ICE Futures, ICE's U.K. futures subsidiary, was 496,904 in April, an increase of 62.8% over April, 2006. Volume at the New York Board of Trade, ICE's U.S. regulated futures subsidiary, reached a record 4.9 million contracts. Devon Energy profit declines on rising expenses (6:54 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Devon Energy DVN, -6.04% said its first-quarter profit dropped to $651 million, or $1.44 a share, from $700 million, or $1.56 a share, hurt by rising expenses on increased oil transportation costs, casualty insurance premiums, increased workover activity and generally higher industry prices for oilfield services and supplies. Oil and gas production from continuing operations rose 12% to 52.9 million barrels of oil equivalent. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expected earnings of $1.26 a share. SPX 1st-quarter net up 35%; lifts profit outlook for year (6:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- SPX Corp., SPW, -4.73% the Charlotte, N.C., provider of power-plant-cooling systems, flow-process equipment, and other equipment for energy, power and other industries, reported first-quarter net income rose 35% on 13% higher revenue. Earnings reached $29.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from $21.7 million, or 35 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings from continuing operations were 55 cents against 38 cents. Shares outstanding fell 8% to 60.1 million. Revenue totaled $1.08 billion compared with $953.5 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 51 cents of profit on $1.07 billion of revenue. For the year, SPX lifted its forecast of earnings per share to a range $4.45 to $4.65 from its previous outlook, $3.85 to $3.95. The increase reflects "robust order trends in global infrastructure, particularly power and energy markets," President and Chief Executive Chris Kearney said in a statement. Ness Technologies profit dips 10% after charge (6:38 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Ness Technologies Inc. NSTC said Wednesday that its first-quarter net profit dipped 10% to $5.7 million, or 15 cents a share, from $6.3 million, or 18 cents a share, a year earlier. The IT services firm said profit was hit by around $3 million of one-off expenses, including from a change in management. Revenue for the period rose 18% to $125.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of 15 cents a share on revenue of $126 million. Ness reiterated its guidance that it expects 2007 revenue in the range of $560 million to $570 million and earnings per share in the range of $1.00 to $1.05. However, the firm said the current weakness in the dollar represents potential downside to 2007 earnings of around 6 cents a share. For the second quarter it expects earnings of 17 cents to 19 cents a share, including 6 cents a share of capital gains associated with a potential private placement. CORRECT: Allianz profit climbs on capital gains (6:38 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German insurer Allianz AZ, -1.23% (DE:840400)said its first-quarter net profit rose to 3.2 billion euros ($4.4 billion) from 1.8 billion euros, after capital gains of around 2 billion euros. Its operating profit rose by more than 7% to around 2.9 billion euros, as it's been able to offset 340 million euros of claims from the winter storm Kyrill with all other business segments. Revenue on a currency adjusted basis was flat at 29.3 billion euros. Allianz will publish the full quarterly report on May 8. (Corrects year-ago net income comparison.) Time Warner Cable profit climbs on 61% revenue rise (6:30 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Time Warner Cable TWC, -1.36% said its first-quarter net income rose to $276 million, or 28 cents a share, from $237 million, or 23 cents a share, with revenue up 61% to $1.5 billion. Subscription revenue rose 61% and advertising revenue grew 73%. It still sees 2007 percentage growth rates in revenue and operating income before depreciation and amortization will be in the mid-to-high thirties. Citizens Communications 1st-quarter net up 34% (6:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Citizens Communications, CZN, +3.85% the Stamford, Conn., independent telecommunications provider, reported first-quarter net income rose 34% on 10% higher revenue. Earnings were $67.7 million, or 21 cents a share, compared with $50.5 million, or 15 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $556.1 million from $506.9 million. Excluding Commonwealth Telephone Enterprises, which Citizens acquired on March 8, 2007, revenue rose 5.6%. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced consensus estimates of 16 cents of profit on $519 million of revenue. (Adds Thomson estimates.) Iron Mountain net up 27%; will buy records-management firm (6:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Iron Mountain Inc., IRM, -1.43% the Boston provider of information-protection and storage services, reported first-quarter net income rose 27% on 12% higher revenue. Earnings reached $34.7 million, or 17 cents a share, from $27.3 million, or 14 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue totaled $632.5 million compared with $563.7 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 15 cents of profit on $627 million of revenue. Iron Mountain also definitively agreed to acquire ArchivesOne Inc., a Middlebury, Conn., provider of records- and information-management services in the U.S. Terms weren't disclosed. Time Warner quarterly net profit slips; adjusted EPS beats (6:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Media conglomerate Time Warner, Inc. TWX, -0.08% said first-quarter net profit fell 18% to $1.2 billion, or 31 cents a share, from $1.46 billion, or 32 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 9% to $11.2 billion, boosted by a strong performance of the cable division. Excluding discontinued operations and special items, the company would have earned 22 cents share compared to 20 cents a share. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for earnings of 20 cents a share and sales of $11.2 billion. Time Warner said it expects 2007 earnings before discontinued operations and the effect of accounting changes of $1.05 a share. The company said it plans to complete its $20 billion buyback by the end of the second quarter. Kendle profit slips after amortization charge (6:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Clinical research company Kendle International Inc. KNDL said Wednesday that its first-quarter net profit slipped to $4.2 million, or 28 cents a share, from $4.9 million, or 33 cents a share. Excluding an amortization charge, Kendle said it would have earned 33 cents in the quarter. Revenue for the quarter grew 72% to $132.6 million, driven by a 60% rise in net services revenue to $95.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 41 cents a share on revenue of $96 million. PartyGaming warns 2007 profit will be below expectations (2:42 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Online gambling company PartyGaming(UK:PRTY)on Wednesday warned that its 2007 earnings before tax and one-off items would be "significantly below" the current market consensus, due to higher-than-expected distribution costs. The group said costs were driven higher by a sharp rise in players, with customer sign-ups jumping to 233,900 from 108,000 a year earlier. It added, however, that the increase in active players should lead to higher growth in 2008 and beyond. The firm said revenue for the quarter rose 26% to $94.8 million. PartyGaming also said it had seen a drop in yield per player per day as some of its high value players have been lost to competitor sites that continue to accept U.S. customers. PartyGaming, along with several other gambling sites, ceased dealing with U.S. customers in October after the introduction of U.S. anti-gambling laws. Continental profit climbs 22% on Europe, Asia car production (2:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German tire maker Continental AG(DE:543900)said first-quarter profit rose 22% to 270.5 million euros ($369 million), with sales up 10% to 3.97 billion euros. Growing car production in Europe and Asia and increased replacement sales for passenger and light truck tires in Europe and North America drove its profit. It still expects rising sales and operating profit for the year despite uncertainty in raw materials costs, which it's currently to stabilize at a high level. Credit Suisse tops forecasts with 5% profit growth (2:30 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss banking group Credit Suisse CS, -2.74% said Wednesday that its first-quarter net income rose 5% to 2.73 billion Swiss francs ($2.26 billion), or 2.42 francs a share. Net revenue for the quarter rose 6% to 11.62 billion francs. The performance came in ahead of analyst expectations thanks to a strong quarter for debt underwriting and equity and fixed income trading at the bank's investment banking arm, where pretax profit rose 27%. Profit at the corporate and retail banking arm rose 31% due to higher net interest income. Credit Suisse said its wealth management business generated net new assets of 15.2 billion francs, representing an annualized quarterly growth rate of 7.8%. The bank said its business pipeline remains robust and it is optimistic about the long term growth prospects for its investment banking, private banking and asset management businesses. However, it also warned that it expects an increase in market volatility and said market corrections "cannot be excluded in the coming months." Lonmin's pretax profit jumps 63%, while revenue drops (2:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Lonmin(UK:LMI)said first-half to March 31 profit before tax climbed 63% to $132 million on increased platinum prices and a weaker South African rand, while revenue fell 11% to $631 million. Lonmin said it deliberately deferred substantial revenue and earnings into the second half to preserve margins otherwise lost on the sale of concentrate. That was done after an accident at its Number One furnace, and it's holding its annual sales forecast of around 980,000 to 1 million ounces of platinum. A longer-than-usual Christmas and one-day wildcat strike at Marikana also affected results, Lonmin said. It's lifting its interim dividend by 22% to 55 cents a share. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Owens Corning OC, -2.72% said Wednesday Chairman Mike Thaman, 43, will take over as chief executive officer after current CEO Dave Brown retires by the end of this year. Thaman currently serves as chairman and chief financial officer. A search for Thaman's successor as chief financial officer is underway. In his new role, Thaman will retain the title and responsibilities of chairman of the board.
title: Owens Corning CFO to move up to CEO

content: Pre-open moves Shares looked set for a weaker start, with Hewlett-Packard weighing after ho-hum results. Data showed U.S. consumer prices rose more than forecast in January, led by increases in food, medical care and tobacco prices. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets The Bank of Japan raised its key interest rate a quarter point, judging the world's second-largest economy was tough enough to handle higher borrowing costs. In Europe, banks and earnings lifted broad markets. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action Motorola MSI, -1.60% was downgraded to equal-weight from overweight by Lehman Bros. "We believe handset margins are recovering slower than expected ... and thus Motorola's recovery story may extend into 2008," the broker said. Lehman Bros. upgraded Mattel MAT, -0.46% to equal weight from underweight and cut Hasbro HAS, -0.56% to equal weight from overweight. The broker upped Mattel in part because of Barbie's increased popularity. On Hasbro, even though the broker is more optimistic on 2008 earnings growth, it doesn't see further multiple expansions from current levels. See Upgrades/Downgrades: The Internet's most complete source for analyst comment. Breaking news: See Market Pulse for all the latest Hewlett-Packard Co. HPQ, -4.33% reported a 26% rise in fiscal first-quarter profit on surging sales at its unit that sells personal computers and related hardware and strong revenue from its imaging and printing group. Shares weighed in pre-market action. Discount airliner JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU, -3.54% revised first-quarter and 2007 forecast to incorporate material changes in its projections due to the service disruptions resulting from the Feb. 14 New York area ice storm and related recovery period. JetBlue has come under fire in recent days after its flight schedule was shredded by weather-related cancellations and long delays on the tarmac.
